story:
Overview

Climate change is expected to accelerate the loss of species as land, sea, and freshwater habitats face damage and loss. This is especially true for cold-water fish such as salmonids. This imminent crisis not only concerns biologists. Human beings have been closely connected to the diversity of various species spiritually, culturally, socially, economically, and personally.  The Great Salmon Tour aims to engage people in the conservation of biodiversity of salmon by allowing them to experience the diverse bonds that exist between salmon and people. Every fish has a story – a story that is inseparable from our lives. Whatever that story may be, the Great Salmon Tour seeks to tell it through film, oral history recordings, social media, and publications.

We have a series of species and locations that we plan to visit. In 2020, we journey to uncover the legendary Atlantic salmon fisheries in Maine and the ongoing efforts to save the species from going extinct, visiting salmon cartels in Spain, and documenting reef netters of the Pacific Northwest.

Our Story

My first job after moving to the U.S. from Norway was to work on the recovery of salmon populations in California for the National Marine Fisheries Service. One day a coworker asked me about the European Hucho hucho species.  Although I come from Europe, I drew a blank.

“The large river salmon,” he said. At that time, I just started learning about the many types of salmon in the Pacific Northwest, and I was intrigued.  As far as I was concerned, Europe only had the generic salmon and brown trout, and this new genus spurred my interest in the diversity of these widespread species.

As I learned more about the various species of salmon and the existential threats they face, I decided that I wanted to see them all and explore the status of these fish around the world. However, I soon realized that there was another story that needs to be told –that the story of salmon is as much about people as it is about the fish. There has always been a deeper connection between people and salmon that have gone beyond nutritional or economic needs. This bond consists of cultural and spiritual values, local knowledge and practices, traditions, and social identities. So, when we lose the biological diversity of salmonids, we lose not only the fish species but also our own cultural heritage.   

So, I created the Great Salmon Tour to see all the salmon species and explore the deep cultural and personal connections that people have with these fish. The goal is to engage people in the conservation of salmon diversity through the Great Salmon Tour expeditions.

In 2010, we visited Tanana Village along the Yukon River in Alaska to experience salmon subsistence fishing; we journeyed across Mongolia to see the mythical taimen salmon; we spoke with fishermen on the last small boat fishery for Chinook salmon in California; and we discovered an inspiring story of conservation of softmouth trout in Bosnia-Herzegovina. Afterward, we gave lectures about our findings from our tour in universities and non-governmental organizations in the Washington DC area and West Virginia, published an article about the biodiversity of salmon and their connections to people based on our expeditions, and we produced documentary videos.

This time our goal is to explore and document the stories of fish and men in Washington, Maine, and Spain.

What is the Project About?

Ultimately, it is about conservation of salmon. It is about understanding our own heritage and documenting it before it is lost, and it is about our future.

It is difficult for the general public to be concerned about a species that they do not know. It is particularly hard to engage them in conservation of non-exotic species, such as salmon fishes. Also, given the availability of aquaculture fish in restaurants and markets, the general public is less aware that many of these species are critically endangered. Telling the story of salmon and what it means to various communities will increase awareness about the diversity of salmonids and show that their loss will have a direct impact on us, human beings. We believe that focusing attention on the diversity of salmon and our connections with them will help in the conservation, protection, and recovery efforts of these species. And we will put a limelight on the issue by telling the stories through multiple media and venues.

 

What We Will Do

Expeditions

In 2020, the Great Salmon Tour will visit Maine, USA, and the Autonomous Region of Asturias, Spain, to make a documentary about the native Atlantic salmon and what happens when the salmon runs are lost. Through our visits and interviews, we will compare the two cultures and their similar traditions linked to the Atlantic salmon runs. But the current conditions are not the same between the two places.

Fishing for native wild Atlantic salmon in the U.S. became illegal when the Maine salmon was listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act in 2000. The situation in Maine is an illustration of what people and communities lose when the salmon runs disappear, and it is a stark warning of what the future for Asturias may be if the Spaniards do not find a way to manage sustainable runs. We are excited about continuing our project and expeditions.

We will also travel to Washington to learn about and document salmon reefnet fishing. Wild Pacific salmon reefnet fishing is a historical Pacific Northwest fishing method- the oldest known salmon net fishery in the world. Once practiced throughout the Salish Sea by its many indigenous peoples it is now only done in three places through a cooperative effort between Lummi Nation tribal members and Lummi Island Wild.

We have already cultivated connections and logistical support for each of these locations, but traveling to these sites will ultimately depend on our funding efforts and practical considerations. To tell these stories, my team and I will contribute a significant amount of personal assets, such as equipment and time. Thus, our first goal now is to cover the basic expenses for travel and logistics for team members who will undertake this work.

You as a Participant

The project will allow you to be a vital participant in this tour through film, photographs, and articles. We will keep updates about our journey on social media and our blog so you can interact with us as we prepare, plan, and travel. 

Oral History

Importantly, the essence of the Great Salmon Tour is the recognition that biological diversity is intrinsic to the vitality of human culture and human history. Therefore, we will videotape stories of individuals, families, important events, and everyday life of communities tied to salmon to create oral history recordings. The recordings will be loaded on the Voices of the Fisheries and other historic societies repositories where they will be available for researchers and the public. They will also be available on our website.

The timing of this project is important; the recreational fishery for Atlantic salmon in Maine has been closed for over 20 years; the Atlantic salmon in Spain is on the southern edge of the species distribution and is threatened by climate change; and it is unclear if the young generation is interested in continuing the reef netting in Washington. Thus, the fishermen are getting older, with only a few remaining individuals that can share their experiences. This is a unique time and opportunity to capture their stories, learn from these case studies, and celebrate their knowledge to garner continued support for efforts to restore and conserve salmon.

Films

A video camera will be our primary equipment during our travels. We will produce short videos while traveling and longer documentaries once we are back home and in our editing studio. This will allow us to build an archive of high-quality visual materials about the entire experience. We strive to represent the uniqueness of the salmon fishes and people in stunning places that we will be visiting. Videos will be shared on our website and via social media

Presentations

People do not care about something they have not heard about. So, we spread the word about intricate ties between salmon and people by giving presentations at schools, universities, organizations, etc. Following our expeditions to Alaska, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Mongolia, and Virginia, we gave presentations at university classes, local American Fisheries Society charters, Café Scientifique meetings, and other venues in D.C., Maryland, Minnesota, and West Virginia. We will make a new round of presentations following our expeditions to Washington State, Maine, and Spain.

Publications

We will write about our findings about fish and men on our website and external publications. We will also produce our own magazines covering the great salmon diversity, which can be purchased online but you can be one of the first recipients of our original three first magazines as a prize for your donation!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds for travel expenses to and from our locations, on-site logistics for two team members who will undertake this work, and a translator in Spain.  We also need to update some of our film equipment. At last, we need funds to create a professional and interactive Great Salmon Tour website. Please rest assured that whether or not we reach our ambitious goal, all contributions will only go to the development of the project.

We send a postcard with hand written personal thank you to all of our supporters. We also have cups and t-shirts to share. Or maybe you want to be recognized as a golden sponsor or producer of our films? There is a perk for that. And let us know if you have a business you want to promote and we can add your logo to our sponsor list that comes with the material we produce. If you like to read. Then our magazines are for you.

Understanding Salmon as Food. Restaurants commonly advertise just salmon on their menu despite that in the U.S. alone there are six different species of fish called salmon and that each species is unique in the flavor and texture of its flesh. Adding the other salmonid fishes such as Artic char, steelhead, rainbow trout, brown trout, etc. and you have the possibility of a gourmet fest. Our “Understanding Salmon as Food” magazine introduces you to the gastronomic variation that meets you once you journey beyond farm raised Atlantic salmon, explains the biology that affects the differences between the species in the quality of their flesh, and gives you a series of recipes from around the world to explore. This is a must book for anyone claiming to be a foodie, chef, or salmon connoisseur.

The Diversity of Salmonid Fishes. ​Though biodiversity has become a familiar term in mainstream media, it continues to be an abstract concept for many people. However, sallmon and trout are nor abstract. There are nearly 200 species of salmonids, and the planet is very close to losing several of them. The salmon diversity magazine discusses in engaging ways biodiversity in general and salmonids in particular, presents the reader to many of the salmon species out there and the threats they face, and tells captivating stories of loss and conservation of biodiversity.

Tales from the Great Salmon Tour Expeditions. Between 2010 and 2012 I traveled several places to document salmon and what these fish means to people. I met fishermen from the small boat salmon fishery in California to learn what Chinook salmon means for them, traveled to Tanana village along the Yukon River in Alaska to experience subsistence fishery for salmon, drove across the roadless Mongolian tundra to find out how Buddhism helps conserve taimen salmon, and I visited researchers in Bosnia-Herzegovinia to find out how small fish farms and local pride may help with recovery of the endemic softmouth trout. I also drove up to the mountains in Virginia where I joined a local fly fisherman to find native brook trout. Stories from these trips and the experiences I had are collected in The Great Salmon Tour 2010 magazine.

The Impact

The concept of biodiversity can be abstract. Nature programs on TV and environmental organizations often give the impression that biodiversity is just about endangered animals, such as elephants or rhinos, in exotic places. Therefore, many people think of biodiversity as something remote, but not necessarily something close to where they live or as an integral part of their diet or lives.

The Great Salmon Tour brings the concept of biodiversity home by demonstrating that biodiversity is not only about exotic animals in faraway places, it is also about something as familiar as the fish in your local river or on your dinner plate.

Telling the story of salmon and its deep meaning to people and communities will raise awareness about the threats facing salmonid fishes and what their potential loss may mean to us. Your support will help raise the awareness that will result in conservation, protection, and recovery of these species. It will also result in support to local communities striving to preserve their local knowledge, practices, and social/cultural systems. Preserving the connection between people and fish will help leveraging efforts to conserve the ecosystems that salmon fishes depend on.

As we lose salmon species and populations, we also lose our own heritage. We will provide the oral history recordings to various historical societies where they will be archived and made available to both the public and researchers. Thus, by supporting this project you will help preserve local knowledge and practices, traditions, and social/cultural systems for future generations.

From 2010 to 2012 we covered several species and communities. Following our expeditions, we gave presentations at universities, schools, and non-profit organizations. We created films and published articles about cultural and social connections between salmonids and people in online magazines. In our upcoming expeditions, we will continue to build on the work that we started in 2010. We believe this effort will have a real impact on the conservation of salmonids and you can help in it.

 

Risks and Challenges

There is a risk that planned locations may not be easily accessible, for example, some of the locations are remote and may require special logistical planning. There are a number of factors to incorporate in these decisions, including weather and available resources, but I have successfully overcome and negotiated these obstacles in previous expeditions.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Contact The Great Salmon Tour

Upcoming Expeditions

Please, spread the word about this IndieGoGo campaign with as many people as possible. The IndieGoGo share tool is a good start.

Please, let us know if you have photography, film, or computer equipment in good condition and not outdated that you are willing to donate to The Great Salmon Tour. We may have use for it.  We would especially appreciate donations of a wireless microphone systems or a GoPro camera.

We will need to rent a car during our expeditions. If you have a free upgrade coupon or something similar that you are willing to give away, please, send it our way.

Got extra frequent flier miles? Yes, you can transfer them and we would be happy to accept.

Past Expeditions

We still have interviews from our previous trip to Mongolia that needs to be translated and transcribed. Please, contact us if you are able and willing to translate and transcribe the video interviews.

story:
Summary

Hi friends! My name is Dr. Tamsin Woolley-Barker – anthropologist, evolutionary biologist, biomimic, and futurist. I'm the Dean of Geoversity's School for Biocultural Leadership in Panama, author of the Amazon bestseller TEEMING: How Superorganisms Work for Infinite Wealth in a Finite World, and the CEO of TEEM Innovation Group in San Diego. 

My life-long work has been catalyzing an "evolution revolution"––a radical reset on society's most basic assumptions of how the world works and how to design for it.​  Because in these crazy times, nobody can really know what the future holds. But anyone can learn to see deep processes and local patterns, to get the same kind of adaptive expertise all living things possess. That's what we work on at Geoversity's School for Biocultural Leadership in Panama (at our 12,000 hectare old growth cloudforest and associated matrix of Carribbean and Pacific island coastal campuses), and it's what we will work on at BILD––the Borrego Institute for Living Design! 

2021 marks the beginning of our Geoversity 2030 Global Vision, a decade-long celebration of 30 years of cultivating young leaders and global change-makers working in service of diverse and thriving multi-species communities.

Of course, it's hard for students to get to Panama right now! So we thought we better add a stop on Geoversity's Pacific Flyway to the Evolution Revolution!

It's been a lifelong dream to have a Buckminster Fuller-esque "Black Mountain College"  creative community focused on evolutionary design for richer futures. I found the perfect spot! A deeply historic and ecologically significant 84-acre ranch and canyon in San Diego's Anza-Borrego Desert. The canyon was home to indigenous encampments for thousands of years, and remains a vital ecological corridor for generations of wild creatures. Now I am excited to invite YOU to join these illustrious folks and become a Member of the BILD! 

BILD is where we will do the hard work of rescuing and rehabilitating feral humans, for reintroduction to the wild. Members gain access to unique online and in-person Living Design programming, rooted in Science, Art, and Mythic Story from Western and Indigenous perspectives. Our aim is to cultivate pattern literacy for living design––designs that adapt to change and make more with each generation. Holistic Tracking, Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK), and Wilderness Skills; become familiar with the evolutionary process and local ecological patterns. Experience art mentorship that helps you truly see the world and express your personal synthesis. Mythic storytelling helps diverse people find stories that expand to contain the complex and contradictory nature of our personal tracks while designing the future together. Core programming online in Q1 2021, with invitations to join our on-site events in Borrego Springs and GeoSchool in Panama Q2 and beyond!  https://geoversity.org/en

Come join the Rehumanize Movement and make our Geoversity Global 2030 Vision come to life! 

What We Need & What You Get

Incredibly, we raised 75K in a week as a deposit to secure the opportunity to purchase this incredible place. Wow! I love my community! Now we move into Phase 2. We need $150K by Jan 21, 2021 to close escrow. Here's the plan: your Indiegogo contributions through Jan 31 will become an endowment to support BILD's operations, and will fund our 2021 programming. Meanwhile, we need private donors willing to match our Indiegogo raise through our Geoversity's 501(c)3, or help backstop our $150K payment by January 10. Last, I'll donate any proceeds folks make on my TEEMInnovationGroup.com Marketplace through Feb 1 to the BILD Ranch purchase!

These Founding Memberships will CLOSE Feb 1 (good for a year), so please don't miss this historic opportunity to say you were there when it all began.
 

The Impact

Your support for the Borrego Institute for Living Design helps us work to align human design with the deep evolutionary processes and ecological patterns that govern our world, in service of expanding evolutionary potential and future opportunity. Let's give our kids a chance to show what they can do!

Sponsorship Opportunities

Please consider sponsoring students or help us make our 150K payment, either through a (matching??) donation or backstop loan. You can also help fund our BILD infrastructure needs, join our GeoSchool courses in Panama https://geoversity.org/en , sponsor students and organizations, become a member of our Mamoni100 program, and so much more! All sponsorships/donations are tax deductible through Geoversity's 501(c)3 status. Contact us for a conversation on how we can best put your donation to work for you and your community.

  • > $10k Partner (how can we help your community?)
  • $5k Sponsor (fund a 2 week Residency) - includes large bell tent with three beds, outdoor shower, deck, composting toilet, firepit, shade structure, communal meals and campfire
  • $2k Friend (fund a Weekend Glampsite) - small safari tent with one or two beds, outdoor shower, firepit, shade structure, shared composting toilets
  • $250 Mentor (sponsor a Student)

Other Ways You Can Help

Are we speaking your love language but you can't contribute financially right now? We understand and we still need your support! We are always looking for Dream and Sweat Equity! Reach out to apply for a community, creative, or non-profit sponsorship or to volunteer your time, ideas, help, and creativity! Find some friends and see if someone will sponsor your group! Thank you for supporting this dream for our collective futures.
story_txt:
SummaryHi friends! My name is Dr. Tamsin Woolley-Barker – anthropologist, evolutionary biologist, biomimic, and futurist. I'm the Dean of Geoversity's School for Biocultural Leadership in Panama, author of the Amazon bestseller TEEMING: How Superorganisms Work for Infinite Wealth in a Finite World, and the CEO of TEEM Innovation Group in San Diego. My life-long work has been catalyzing an "evolution revolution"––a radical reset on society's most basic assumptions of how the world works and how to design for it.​  Because in these crazy times, nobody can really know what the future holds. But anyone can learn to see deep processes and local patterns, to get the same kind of adaptive expertise all living things possess. That's what we work on at Geoversity's School for Biocultural Leadership in Panama (at our 12,000 hectare old growth cloudforest and associated matrix of Carribbean and Pacific island coastal campuses), and it's what we will work on at BILD––the Borrego Institute for Living Design! 2021 marks the beginning of our Geoversity 2030 Global Vision, a decade-long celebration of 30 years of cultivating young leaders and global change-makers working in service of diverse and thriving multi-species communities. Of course, it's hard for students to get to Panama right now! So we thought we better add a stop on Geoversity's Pacific Flyway to the Evolution Revolution!It's been a lifelong dream to have a Buckminster Fuller-esque "Black Mountain College"  creative community focused on evolutionary design for richer futures. I found the perfect spot! A deeply historic and ecologically significant 84-acre ranch and canyon in San Diego's Anza-Borrego Desert. The canyon was home to indigenous encampments for thousands of years, and remains a vital ecological corridor for generations of wild creatures. Now I am excited to invite YOU to join these illustrious folks and become a Member of the BILD! BILD is where we will do the hard work of rescuing and rehabilitating feral humans, for reintroduction to the wild. Members gain access to unique online and in-person Living Design programming, rooted in Science, Art, and Mythic Story from Western and Indigenous perspectives. Let's give our kids a chance to show what they can do!Sponsorship OpportunitiesPlease consider sponsoring students or help us make our 150K payment, either through a (matching??) donation or backstop loan. You can also help fund our BILD infrastructure needs, join our GeoSchool courses in Panama https://geoversity.org/en , sponsor students and organizations, become a member of our Mamoni100 program, and so much more! All sponsorships/donations are tax deductible through Geoversity's 501(c)3 status. Contact us for a conversation on how we can best put your donation to work for you and your community.

story:
CAPACITY CHALLENGES

The region of East Maui, Hawaii’s largest single source of surface water, is at a tipping point. The influx of tourism and the lack of its appropriate management has been conflicting with our day to day lives as residents for over a decade. Surveys conducted over the last two years estimates the highway to be four times over visitor capacity and now considered to be insufficient to serve the current level of use which creates issues such as overcrowding, illegal parking, hazardous driving conditions, rampant trespassing on private property leading to visitor injuries requiring emergency rescues, excessive unlicensed commercial activity triggering economic adversities, waste disposal concerns including public facility cleanliness, pluming issues leading to stream and ocean contamination, health hazards and death. 

Read the 9-9-18 StarAdvertise, article here

 

RESTORING BALANCE

Over the last two years we have collected data through roadside surveying, traffic studies, visitor questionnaires, web surveillance and natural resource monitoring. With this information we have formulated a plan aimed to reduce the impact of the visitor industry and further refine the methods to best protect the natural resources of our home. 

Read the 9-11-16 Maui News, article here

 

PREVENTATIVE MEASURES

The Hana Highway Regulation has published a Road to Hana Code of Conduct found at HanaHighwayRegulation.com In partnership with the visitor’s bureau, the Hana Community Association is developing educational resources in the form of an infographic brochure and preparedness video to enhance visitor safety. Additionally the organization is working with the Department of Transportation and Public Utilities Commission to increase roadside signage and commercial industry oversight.

Read the 6-14-17 Maui News, article here

Although the components mentioned above have and will provide some preventative measures, we have determined that in-the-field advising is our only line of effective defense to the level of desecration we are enduring. Visitor actions leading to resident frustrations and environmental turmoil have been identified as illegal parking, private property trespassing, unlicensed commercial activity and commercial activity within a sacred site. Amongst our studies we have recorded a 96% reduction in these four culprits of chaos under the condition that a field advisor is on premises, mediating the offenses as they present themselves by providing visitor education.  

INTERNATIONAL EXAMPLES

We have been greatly inspired by our aboriginal cousins across the Pacific @countryneedspeople, and the successful implementation of their Indigenous Ranger Program through the Australian continent. In particular, whats resonated with us most is the corresponding philosophy that the “Country Needs People”.

INDIGENOUS RANGERS

The resident volunteer program presented here draws upon thousands of years of ancestral knowledge that harnesses the understanding of the intrinsic relationship between indigenous peoples and the land in which they come from. Interested residents will submit an autobiography as an application for the position of resident volunteer, outlining their history of regional protection efforts and why they are interested in serving. Chosen candidates will enter a voluntary agreement and adhere to policies, procedures and protocol to protect the area’s cultural resources which include sacred sites, forests, coastlines and water ways. We seek your support to train and enable our management of district volunteers to impress the effectiveness and value of place-specific expertise. Volunteers will be granted stipends for standing post 8 hours per day, four days per week. Resident volunteers will be guided by the values of Aloha, Malama and Kuleana to protect and manage land and sea across Hawaii. 

WE SEEK YOUR SUPPORT

We plan to crowdfund during the month of January and February, incurring  the financial support necessary to train resident volunteers and implement resident volunteers roadside for the 2019 Summer and Fall seasons. Volunteers will commit to using formalities of Aloha to educate visitors on community policy. This is a grassroots effort to deter illegal parking, trespassing on private property, unlicensed commercial activity and commercial activity within sacred sites.

FUTURE PLANNING

Amidst providing cordial verbal disclaimers, this network of field advisors will be simultaneously collecting intricate roadside data for the half year period. Upon completion of our exercise, this data will provide the community organization with an accurate gauge of impact to determine what the appropriate threshold is for leisure visits of the Road to Hana. This project will assist our community organization’s ability to curate a regional visitor management plan for East Maui that includes turning these volunteer positions into future paid employments. It is critical we conduct this exercise of community regulatory action as the Road to Hana, its parking and comfort station infrastructure, was never designed or intended for the current magnitude of use, its associated traffic and human impact. 

OVERVIEW

More residents are expressing an interest to protect the culture and wildlife along the Road to Hana but government funding  is severely lacking and doesn’t meet the caliber of means necessary to  protect the vast land and sea country of our home. We would like to implement resident volunteers at the various areas seeing heaviest impact and complications therefore we are crowdfunding for the expenses of training and outfitting 28 resident volunteers to post share at 15 critically endangered sacred sites along the Road to Hana.

By implementing these rangers, we will have the ability to drastically reduce the offenses of illegal parking, trespassing on private property, unlicensed commercial activity and commercial activity within sacred sites. We look forward to diminishing the chaos for residents, incurring intricate data to contribute towards future planning and ensure the vitality of our watershed that provides for the majority of Maui's water needs. 

QUOTE SPECIFICS

15 megaphones @ $1,050.00

15 iPads @ $3,360.00 

15 lifeproof Cases @ $840.00

75 long sleeve t-shirts @ $1,000.00

75 short sleeve t-shirts @ $750.00

28 hats @ $300.00

28 boots @ $3,024.00

56 pants @ $6,720.00

28 safety jackets @ $2,100.00

28 CPR and Safety Training @ $1,400.00

28 Belts @ $560.00

28 Leatherman Tools @ $1,400.00

28 Weatherproof Tablets @ $224.00

28 Hydroflasks @ $1,680.00

15 First Aid Kits @ $560.00

15 Umbrellas @ $420.00

15 receptor radios @ $1,886.00

94 vinyl decals @ $471.00

$27,745.00 total for uniforms and equipment 

 

9 Safety Checkpoints -Ranger  booths @ $27,000.00

3  UTV mules - Ranger posts  @ $36,000.00

3 Visitor Information Stations - Ranger stations @ $18,000.00

$81,000.00 total for infrastructure

 

UTV Fuel, 6 months @ $10,080.00

Equipment Maintenance, 6 months @ $3,600.00 

Solar Electric Kits [4] @ $8,000.00 

Compostable Toilets [4] @ $12,800.00

Dishnetwork WIFI system [2] @ $4,000.00

Monthly WIFI, 6 months @ $3,120.00

$41,600.00 total for operational supplies and equipment 

 

Operations Manager, 12 months @ $28,000.00

total for full project oversight, volunteer and data management

Project Administrator, 6 months @ $12,000.00

total for administrative oversight, program applications and fees

Public Relations Manager, 6 months @ $12,000.00

total for media compilations, content curation and correspondence

Volunteer Stipends @ $168,000.00

total for 28 volunteer stipends at $1,000.00/mo. [approx. $33/shift]

$220,000.00 total for project management 

$370,345.00 grand total for Resident Volunteer program implementation

 

COMMUNITY STEWARDSHIP

We appreciate your support of our intention to bring immediate relief and a forecast for long term remedy. Our crowdfunding total entails hard costs of the uniforms, equipment, supplies, infrastructure and management oversight to make this proof of concept possible. Upon the completion, we will provide a thorough report on the challenges, effectiveness, and refinements necessary to curate effective land and sea management for East Maui. This will provide our community organization with an accurate perspective to draft a sound visitor management plan. 

We look forward to your help in architecting this platform for rural people of this place to protect their country… but more than that, we would like to provide our people with solutionary action and hope. These stipened ranger positions will be an opportunity to ensure environmental well-being, a way for residents in rural East Maui to participate in the economy, be recognized for their ancestral knowledge and be proud of a day’s work.

POSITIVE RESULTS

Research that has surfaced from the Indigenous Ranger Project of Australia have proven to cause a ripple effect over remote communities, creating conservation value. Reduced alcohol-related issues and incarceration have been reported where ranger groups are active. Indigenous rangers have become role models for a new generation. They are living examples of sustainable eco-systems, workforce participation, healthier lifestyles and cultural preservation.

story:
SAVE KAFUGA FOREST!


Kafuga Pocket Forest is under threat as tea growers want to clear it to make new plantations. Kafuga is part of a landscape of international importance and the richest conservation area in Uganda owing to the exceptional diversity of its flora and fauna.
Kafuga Forest is on the fringes of the Bwindi Impenetrable National Park - a UNESCO World Heritage site in South West Uganda which is home to many different species of plants and animals and 400 of the world's remaining 880 Mountain Gorillas. This critically endangered species will come under greater threat if the deforestation goes ahead. 
For the local villagers, Kafuga Forest is very important. It is:

o the source of water, fruits, poles and fodder for the cattle;

o the forest that helps to bring rain for the crops;

o their home, where local people have always lived and have developed their cultural heritage for their children to enjoy.

What We Need

With this campaign we are supporting Pro-Biodiversity Conservationists in Uganda (PROBICOU), a non-governmental organisation active in the area and committed to protect Kafuga Pocket Forest against deforestation, to save it from encroachment, restore already lost sections by planting trees and providing for its sustainable management. 
The goals are:
  • to map the forest
  • secure its boundaries
  • engage the local community and local government in its conservation
  • preserve this precious ecosystem against commercial interests.
When we raise enough funds and meet our target PROBICOU will be able to restore Kafuga Forest by planting 30,000 native trees.

YOU can help today!

Be part of the campaign! 
Make a donation NOW and directly help more than 18,310 local people.


Your donation will help to save around 250 hectares of Kafuga Pocket Forest in Uganda*.

*All funds raised toward our target will go to PROBICOU to map and protect the Forest.  Any extra funds over the target will go towards funding similar International Tree Foundation natural forest preservation and restoration projects.

THANK YOU!


Other Ways You Can Help!

  • Please spread the word and share this page now

  • Join us on Facebook today
    https://www.facebook.com/internationaltreefoundation 

  • Sign up to our quarterly e-bulletin which tells you all about what's going on in the world of trees here

story:
Summary

So Reclaim the Power is holding another action camp from Friday 29th May to Monday 2nd June near Didcot Power Station in Oxfordshire.

Reclaim the Power is a direct action network aiming to join the dots between environmental, economic and social justice. The network have organised two successful anti-fracking action camps at Balcombe (2013) and Blackpool (2014). In addition we stand in solidarity with communities fighting fracking in their areas like the Preston Road protection camp in Blackpool, Barton Moss in Manchester, Balcombe in Sussex, Crawbury Hill in Yorkshire among others.

  • This year, we are going to Didcot!

  • This is part of a European day of action against corporate influence on the COP21 process and also to maintain momentum regardless of the General Election result in the UK.

  • The camp will aim to;

  1. Draw public attention to the re-emerging threat of 'old coal' and the government's plans for new gas fired powerstations, partly supplied by fracked shale gas.
  2.  Provide a radicalising and participatory experience for the resurgent climate movement in the UK – which will help to build momentum for COP21 in December 2015.  

Last year in Blackpool, we were able to host a successful action camp in the Blackpool area in support of local residents fighting Cuadrilla's plans for commercial scale fracking. Around 1000 people attended the six day event at Preston New Road; culminating in a day of direct action at thirteen different fracking-related sites across the country including:

  • Occupying Cuadrilla's regional offices in Blackpool

  • A super-glue action at the Department for the Environment and Rural Affairs in protest at their redaction of their report into the impacts of fracking on house prices.

  • A protest blockade of Rathlin's energy drill pad at Crawberry Hill, East Yorkshire drawing attention to the company's well safety failures at another nearby site at West Newton.

  • A blockade of the London headquarters of fracking firm Igas.

  • A blockade of Swansea University's extreme energy research centre.



What We Need

  • We're looking to raise around £2000, this will help us put on the best camp yet!
  • £2000 can pay for;

    • Strawbales for people to sit on during workshops (£300)

    • Wooden walkway boards for wheelchair access (£450)

    • Sound system hire for plenary events (£450)

    • 400 camp programmes explaining the climate threat of fossil fuels and workshop timetable (£250)

    • Phone credit for media and legal teams (£100)

    • Compost loos (£250)

    • Recycling and Waste management (£200)


  • Here is a quote from a participant of the 2014 camp:

    “I just wanted to tell you again how glad I am that I went to Reclaim the Power. So many opportunities have arisen out of it. I'm already involved in a bunch of things here in Bristol that I don't think I would have got involved with so easily and quickly had I not gone to RTP. It feels like RTP was like a right of passage for me or something, it really awakened something inside of me.”


Other Ways You Can Help

You don't need to give money to help, you can help by:

  • Coming to the Camp - the more the merrier! You can meet like-minded individuals who care about the future of the environment. There's loads of ways you can pitch in while you're there, from helping cook delicious food to pitching tents and marquees.
  • You can share this page or our facebook event here: Facebook
story_txt:
Summary 

So Reclaim the Power is holding another action camp from Friday 29th May to Monday 2nd June near Didcot Power Station in Oxfordshire. 
Reclaim
the Power is a direct action network aiming to join the dots between
environmental, economic and social justice.  The network have
organised two successful anti-fracking action camps at Balcombe
(2013) and Blackpool (2014). In addition we stand in solidarity with 
communities fighting fracking in their areas like the Preston Road
protection camp in Blackpool, Barton Moss in Manchester, Balcombe in
Sussex, Crawbury Hill in Yorkshire among others. 

 This year, we are going to Didcot! 
 
This
is part of a European day of action against corporate influence on
the COP21 process and also to maintain momentum regardless of the
General Election result in the UK.

The camp will aim to;


Draw
	public attention to the re-emerging threat of 'old coal' and the
	government's plans for new gas fired powerstations, partly supplied
	by fracked shale gas.
 Provide
	a radicalising and participatory experience for the resurgent
	climate movement in the UK – which will help to build momentum for
	COP21 in December 2015.  

Last year in Blackpool, we were able to host a successful action camp in the Blackpool
area in support of local residents fighting Cuadrilla's plans for
commercial scale fracking.  Around 1000 people attended the six day
event at Preston New Road; culminating in a day of direct action at
thirteen
different fracking-related sites
across the country including:





Occupying
	Cuadrilla's regional offices
	in Blackpool


A
	super-glue action at the Department for the Environment and Rural
	Affairs
	in protest at their redaction of their report into the impacts of
	fracking on house prices.


A
	protest blockade of Rathlin's energy drill pad at Crawberry Hill,
	East Yorkshire drawing attention to the company's well safety
	failures at another nearby site at West Newton.


A
	blockade of the London headquarters of fracking firm Igas.


A
	blockade of Swansea University's extreme energy research centre.




     What We Need  We're looking to raise around £2000, this will help us put on the best camp yet! 
 £2000 can pay for;




	Strawbales
	for people to sit on during workshops (£300)

Wooden walkway boards for wheelchair access (£450)


	Sound
	system hire for plenary events (£450)

400
	camp programmes explaining the climate threat of fossil fuels and
	workshop timetable (£250) 
	



	Phone
	credit for media and legal teams (£100)



	Compost
	loos (£250)



	Recycling
	and Waste management  (£200)





 
	
	
	
	Here is a quote from a participant of the 2014 camp:“I
just wanted to tell you again how glad I am that I went to Reclaim
the Power. So many opportunities have arisen out of it. I'm already
involved in a bunch of things here in Bristol that I don't think I
would have got involved with so easily and quickly had I not gone to
RTP. It feels like RTP was like a right of passage for me or
something, it really awakened something inside of me.”

    Other Ways You Can Help You don't need to give money to help, you can help by:
Coming to the Camp - the more the merrier! You can meet like-minded individuals who care about the future of the environment. There's loads of ways you can pitch in while you're there, from helping cook delicious food to pitching tents and marquees.
 
You can share this page or our facebook event here: Facebook

story:
About the Project:

Comprised of an archipelago of over 7,000 islands, the Republic of the Philippines has one of the highest rates of amphibian endemism on the planet; 79% of the Republic's species of amphibians are found nowhere else in the world[1].  This biodiversity hotspot is currently under threat, as 46% of the amphibian species of the Philippines have been declared at-risk of extinction[2].

As with other areas of the world with rapid development, the Philippines is experiencing the conversion of wild areas to urbanized settings and large-scale agriculture.  The effects of such alteration of the ecosystem are felt much more quickly on an island; the reduction of suitable habitat has resulted in pressure on Philippine amphibians that is compounded by the effects of climate change. A study found that the highly virulent disease Chytridiomycosis was present in the Philippines in 2008 and spread quickly; at a locality in Luzon showed that nearly 75% of individuals tested were infected[3]. The disease can be difficult to defeat; although infected frogs can be successfully treated, once they are released back to the wild, they are vulnerable for reinfection.  One of the more popular conservation methods in use is to develop local ex-situ breeding programs, which involves taking several individuals of at-risk species from the wild, testing them to ensure they are free of Chytrid, and then keeping them in terrariums that attempt to mimic appropriate habitat conditions. The terrariums are kept in a biosecure area, and there are extensive sterilization measures in place to ensure that Chytrid and other diseases cannot be brought into the room where the breeding program is taking place.

I am relocating to Los Baños, Laguna, Philippines, to develop a pilot ex-situ program at the campus. The project will focus on enticing endemic species of the genus Platymantis (Family Ceratobatrachidae) to breed in captivity. Four species, Platymantis luzonensis, P. mimulus, P. corrugatus, and P. dorsalis will be collected for this captive breeding study.  The genus Platymantis was chosen because in addition to conservation issues, there is much to be learned about the life cycle of Platymantis frogs.  

All four species of Platymantis chosen for this project are endemic to the island of Luzon.  P. luzonensis and P. mimulus are listed by the IUCN as “Near Threatened”.  P. corrugatus and P. dorsalis are currently not listed at threatened by the IUCN; however, they are listed as having a population trend of “decreasing”.  This project aims to anticipate and offset what is likely to be a continuing decrease in population, especially as the Philippines continues to develop.

These funds will be used for two purposes: (1) setup materials and ongoing maintenance ($3,000) and (2) a stipend for one academic year for one undergraduate student to assist me with the project ($2,500 USD).  **No funds will be used for a personal stipend for myself**.

Upon arrival, I will purchase the materials for the housing setups for the project- twenty 10-gallon glass tanks, with lids; two metal shelving units, and fluorescent lighting. These materials have already been sourced from local businesses in Los Baños.  The permanent enclosures will contain a facsimile of natural habitats, including plants, substrate, and artificial misting system to simulate natural rain cycles.  The animals will be fed daily with appropriate sized prey items supplemented with veterinary-grade calcium and vitamin powder.  Every animal will be measured and weighed weekly, and growth data will be recorded.  After an acclimation period, the frogs will by “cycled” to breed utilizing artificial manipulation of temperature and humidity to create conditions similar to the rainy season; this method is used by zoos and conservation centers around the world and is highly effective in inducing breeding behavior in many species of frogs.

Very few additional costs will be incurred for the field trips to collect the animals, as I already own much of the field equipment needed for collection of the animals, such as thermometers and hygrometers, as well as a GPS unit to record the location of the collection sites.  As I have already secured the source of necessary materials for my project, I should have the facility set up by the end of August, 2015.

After the facility setup, I will conduct field work throughout the month of September 2015 with interested students to locate the target species.  The collected individuals will be housed separately in plastic terraria in a quarantine area for one month; during that time they will be tested for the presence of Chytrid. Animals that test positive for Chytrid will be treated using an antifungal.  Once all animals are clear of Chytrid, they will be moved into the permanent enclosures in October 2015, and breeding attempts will begin.

I am confident that with your help, this pilot project will be a success; after this initial phase, plans will be made to expand it to other species of endangered Philippine amphibians. During this project, I will be training undergraduate and graduate students at UPLB on the proper methods of the long-term maintenance of this ex-situ project, so that it will be successfully transferred to UPLB staff and students upon the completion of my Fulbright award.

[1]https://www.iucn.org/about/union/secretariat/offices/asia/regional_activities/asian_amphibian_crisis/philippines/

[2]  Ibid.

[3]  http://www.nhm.ku.edu/rbrown/Rafes%20PDF%20publications/Diesmos.et.al.2012.FrogLog.chytrid.pdf

story:
estamos contruyendo una comunidad en el amazonas, tenemos doscientas hectáreas y en estos momentos necesitamos recursos para la construcción de espacios comunes para la comunidad los cuales son una casa de bio construcción de cuatro metros por cinco y otra de cinco por cinco . pueden buscar información sobre todas las cosas que realizamos.

Somos un proyecto social auto gestionado con el objetivo de generar una ecoaldea sustentable en la amazonia peruana, entre Iquitos y Nauta.

Queremos brindar alternativas que vuelvan a recomponer el desgarrado entramado social generado por el capitalismo.

Una base solidaria donde todos puedan cooperar según sus capacidades o siendo ayudantes según sus necesidades. Mediante el fortalecimiento de los lazos sociales, la promoción de actividades culturales y sustentables y la investigación de conocimientos ancestrales se busca generar un nuevo tipo de cultura, que devenga en un nuevo tipo de ser, que accione en este mundo, transformándolo.

contará con construcciones de diverso tipo:

• Comedor popular/ restaurante bio

• Cocina

• Centro ceremonial

• Centro de investigación de plantas medicinales sagradas

• Escuela popular

• Centro cultural para cursos, talleres y todo tipo de expresión artística

• Consultorio médico rural

Además estamos con planes de un huerto orgánico y la cría de animales felices.

La idea es generar una red de cooperativas que fomenten la transformación social generando prácticas culturales que den herramientas para una vida alternativa y autosustentable a las comunidades aledañas al proyecto y los que estén deseosos de participar.

La organización será autogestora y horizontal, como objetivo el preservar los recursos naturales y energéticos, protegiendo el patrimonio mundial que es la amazonia.

Queremos funcionar al servicio de las comunidades, brindar ayuda social con la creación de una guardería y escuela para la gente que trabaje en la cooperativa agrícola.

Nuestro objetivo es crear una alternativa a esta sociedad consumista y auto destructiva, para mejorar el futuro que vamos a dejar a nuestros hijos y actuar con respeto con el planeta y las comunidades nativas.

Como comunidad creemos en el ecoturismo educativo y social.

story:
Alaska Whale Foundation is a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization that has been supporting marine mammal research and conservation in Southeast Alaska for nearly 20 years. We are increasing our commitment to this region by developing a research facility, the Coastal Research & Education Center, in the remote wilderness of Baranof Island. The CREC will serve as a multi-use facility that will host visiting researchers, offer field research programs to undergraduate students, and house our marine mammal stranding response team. 

This will be our first season operating the CREC and we are focusing on establishing long-term ecological monitoring programs. These programs will generate baseline data that will allow us to monitor the health of both marine and terrestrial ecosystems and address conservation concerns as they arise.

In just three weeks we will be joined by a team of passionate students and professionals. These individuals will assist AWF biologists in developing a variety of important and timely monitoring projects that will maximize the CRECs contribution to conservation in the region.

We need your help to purchase some basic equipment to outfit our new lab so that the team will be able to make the most of their time at the CREC. 


Thank you for supporting AWF's vision of a fully functioning research center in the heart of Southeast Alaska! Visit our website and Facebook page for field season updates.

alaskawhalefoundation.org

www.facebook.com/alaskawhalefoundation

story:
We are looking for help to bring innovative tried and tested water harvesting techniques to the attention of more small scale subsistence farmers and community leaders in Zimbabwe.  

Mr Zephaniah Phiri is a recognised pioneer of keeping water in the landscape. Despite living in a very dry region of Zimbabwe he is able to grow a diversity of crops even in times of drought.  Unreliable rainfall patterns can destroy the livelihoods of small-scale farmers across the country.  Mr Phiri is a charismatic teacher and thousands have people have visited his farm since he started developing his unique techniques in the 1960's.  

But for many this is not possible as he lives in a remote part of Zimbabwe.  We plan to set up a demonstration water harvesting plot at Kufunda Learning Village just outside Harare, the capital city of Zimbabwe.  We will invite Mr Phiri to teach young leaders on Kufunda's Environmental Leadership Programme - and they will carry out the practical work to build the plot and learn how to manage it.  In the future visitors to Kufunda will be able to learn about Mr Phiri's techniques and get inspiration from his life-long work through seeing them in practice.

Kufunda Learning Village is visited by well over 500 people every year to take part in a range of activities.  Most of these visitors are involved in some form of community development, so they are ideal candidates for spreading awareness far and wide.  In one week this March there were nearly 200 people visiting us!  So our demonstration plot will bring Mr Phiri's sustainable ideas to so many more people. 

What we need:

Yes, we need money!  To be precise we need 4500 US Dollars to make our vision come true.  This will pay for:

  • Two members of Kufunda Learning Village to spend one week with Mr Phiri, learning his techniques first hand on his farm.  
  • Mr Phiri to spend one week at Kufunda to inspire 23 young leaders aged 18-35 during the six-month 'Communiversity' Programme.  Each year Kufunda hosts 20 + young people through a leadership apprentice programme for sustainable community.
  • Members of Muonde Trust to accompany Mr Phiri to help with the practical training necessary to establish the demonstration plot. This includes mapping out the site and digging Phiri pits, contour ridges and ponds.  Muonde Trust was established in 2014 and works with Mr. Phiri to train and inspire dozens of local farmer leaders, mostly women, to transform agricultural practices in their home area of Mazvihwa and beyond
  • The production of publicity materials. Leaflets, a display board and a short video

Even small contributions will go a long way.

But if you don't have cash to spare that's ok too.  We'd love you to read on and learn about our project and tell others about our campaign.

Read more about the project here

Read more of Mr Phiri's work here

Thank you to Muonde Trust for the use of some of their photos


Those who have not met Zephiah Phiri would find it difficult to imagine the integrity and charisma of this inspirational figure, while those who have met him never forget him.

story:
I am Delphine Robbe, french living in Gili Trawangan, Indonesia, for the last 12 years. I am the project manager and coordinator of a local NGO: Yayasan Ekosistem Gili Indah or Gili Eco Trust. I work with all my heart and passion for this little island! Many projects are successful such as Biorock reef restoration, mooring buoys, cat and horse clinics, renewable energy development, education and socialisation of the local community about the importance of caring for their environment for a sustainable future. Our priority for the last few years is RUBBISH... We (Gili Eco Trust, Head of village, APGT Asosiasi Pengusaha Gili Trawangan, Bank Sampah Bintang Sejahtera, Front Masyarakat Peduli Lingkungan) are now starting a new system of waste management and in paralele an education campaign towards ZERO WASTE, which will ensure jobs and money for locals and a clean island free of plastic and rubbish as an example of ecotourism.


Gili Trawangan is drowning under rubbish as no proper waste management plan in place. We have started a new system of collection and socialization to get everyone to separate their rubbish so we can set up an organic garden from organic (wet) rubbish, and we want to set up a "rubbish Bank" for the local community to bring us their rubbish and get money in return. We need funds to set up facilities on the land that the Government is lending us, so we can run the whole program straight away.

We have no funds at the moment to set up the facilities as we have spent so much money to start the new system (boxes, education, press machine), please help, so we can run everything smoothly and successfully.

Roof, floor, compartments for "rubbish bank": 20,000

Machines: Press*4, Plastic shredding*2, Organic rubbish cutter*2, scales *4: 30,000

Electricity+water installation: 2,500,

Composting facilities+organic garden: 15,000,

Boat to transport rubbish to main land: 12,000,

Educational events+prizes+socialization: 15,000,

2* Solar power golf kart to collect organic rubbish boxes: 22,000,

Methanization tanks*2: 24,000,

Office and rooms to rent 1 year: 12,000,

Staff salaries 1 year: 32,000,

Organic rubbish boxes and rubbish bins: 15,500

We need to get the Rubbish Bank facilities running as soon as possible so we can get some income and support local community by offering them a way to make money by cleaning their island. Boat and machinery are the most important goal for now to get some money in as well as cleaning the island.

We also need funding to set the organic garden from composting the organic rubbish (felita system: anaerobic fermentation of the organic rubbish) that the local community and businesses separate, and that we collect. We need to be able to spread the campaign to the whole island: distributing rubbish bins for inorganic rubbish and boxes for organic rubbish, training everyone about wet and dry rubbish, controlling, giving prizes and awards to the best eco-warriors every month. We also need to have more horse karts or some solar power golf karts to organize a daily efficient rubbish collection.

With YOUR HELP, we will be able to set up the facilities and to run them straight away at a full potential rather than being half of our time trying to find money and the other half of the time trying to run the waste management plan.

As the Government has given us a land for this emergency, we cant wait anymore and so we need your help to build the facilities to run our plan to its full potential to ensure an popular tourist destination island free of smell and free of rubbish!

We have been working so many years on that project, and it is NOW that we can see that with your help we can success. We have a plan, job description and budget for a sustainable future of this little island.

The only risks are if people give up and stop working for us! but every meetings, we keep on saying "tidak boleh gagal" which means NOT ALLOWED OF GIVING UP.

We are about 25 people working now, and we want to expand to 40 to 50 people. These people are taking their job seriously and do not want to fail as this is the only way to save the island from becoming another tourist destination spoiled by rubbish.

If you cannot give us money, please contact us to come and help! there is always a way to help! on site or from home!

Thanks for your support
story_txt:
I am Delphine Robbe, french living in Gili Trawangan, Indonesia, for the last 12 years. I am the project manager and coordinator of a local NGO: Yayasan Ekosistem Gili Indah or Gili Eco Trust. I work with all my heart and passion for this little island! Many projects are successful such as Biorock reef restoration, mooring buoys, cat and horse clinics, renewable energy development, education and socialisation of the local community about the importance of caring for their environment for a sustainable future. Our priority for the last few years is RUBBISH... We (Gili Eco Trust, Head of village, APGT Asosiasi Pengusaha Gili Trawangan, Bank Sampah Bintang Sejahtera, Front Masyarakat Peduli Lingkungan) are now starting a new system of waste management and in paralele an education campaign towards ZERO WASTE, which will ensure jobs and money for locals and a clean island free of plastic and rubbish as an example of ecotourism.


Gili Trawangan is drowning under rubbish as no
proper waste management plan in place. We have started a new system of
collection and socialization to get everyone to separate their rubbish so we
can set up an organic garden from organic (wet) rubbish, and we want to set up
a "rubbish Bank" for the local community to bring us their rubbish
and get money in return. We need funds to set up facilities on the land that
the Government is lending us, so we can run the whole program straight away. 
We have no funds at the moment to set up the facilities as we have spent so much money to start the new system (boxes, education, press machine), please help, so we can run everything smoothly and successfully.


Roof, floor, compartments for "rubbish
bank": 20,000
Machines: Press*4, Plastic shredding*2, Organic rubbish cutter*2,
scales *4: 30,000
Electricity+water installation: 2,500, 
Composting
facilities+organic garden: 15,000, 
Boat to transport rubbish to main land: 12,000, 
Educational events+prizes+socialization: 15,000, 
2* Solar power golf kart
to collect organic rubbish boxes: 22,000, 
Methanization tanks*2: 24,000, 
Office and rooms
to rent 1 year: 12,000, 
Staff salaries 1 year: 32,000, 
Organic rubbish boxes and rubbish bins: 15,500
We need to get the Rubbish Bank facilities running as soon as possible so we can get some income and support local community by offering them a way to make money by cleaning their island. Boat and machinery are the most important goal for now to get some money in as well as cleaning the island.
We also need funding to set the organic garden from composting the organic rubbish (felita system: anaerobic fermentation of the organic rubbish) that the local community and businesses separate, and that we collect. We need to be able to spread the campaign to the whole island: distributing rubbish bins for inorganic rubbish and boxes for organic rubbish, training everyone about wet and dry rubbish, controlling, giving prizes and awards to the best eco-warriors every month. We also need to have more horse karts or some solar power golf karts to organize a daily efficient rubbish collection.
With YOUR HELP, we will be able to set up the facilities and to run them straight away at a full potential rather than being half of our time trying to find money and the other half of the time trying to run the waste management plan.
As the Government has given us a land for this emergency, we cant wait anymore and so we need your help to build the facilities to run our plan to its full potential to ensure an popular tourist destination island free of smell and free of rubbish!
We have been working so many years on that project, and it is NOW that we can see that with your help we can success. We have a plan, job description and budget for a sustainable future of this little island.
The only risks are if people give up and stop working for us! but every meetings, we keep on saying "tidak boleh gagal" which means NOT ALLOWED OF GIVING UP.
We are about 25 people working now, and we want to expand to 40 to 50 people. These people are taking their job seriously and do not want to fail as this is the only way to save the island from becoming another tourist destination spoiled by rubbish.
If you cannot give us money, please contact us to come and help! there is always a way to help! on site or from home!
Thanks for your support

story:
My name is Ulrike Heckmann. I have been living in Costa Rica since 1997 due to health reasons. I have MS. I run a small tourist project in the mountains of Montes de Oro, which I rent because of the aforementioned reasons.

NEWS

http://www.ticotimes.net/2015/06/07/costa-rica-consumes-agrochemicals-per-hectare-country-world

http://www.elpais.cr/2015/04/26/la-crisis-del-acueducto-municipal-de-miramar/

http://www.repretel.com/Costa-Rica-se-uni%C3%B3-a-la-mayor-consulta-p%C3%BAblica-mundial-sobre-el-cambio-clim%C3%A1tico-y-la-energ%C3%ADa

FACEBOOK

 https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=1000086...


VIDEOS YOU TUBE

To bring you the idea closer, we made videos you can watch to get more detailed information:

video in english: details

https://youtu.be/1Z1MbEn8j7A

video en espanhol: nuestra idea del bus sustentable

 https://youtu.be/ku6okQl_1-s

Video auf Deutsch: Unser Projekt

https://youtu.be/WuE1yUhCUFo

Video auf Deutsch: Einmal Ferien in einem Art Bus!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZySkw5EdYYM&amp...

THE IDEA
Young people are interested in my project. We share the following concern: How is our Earth, our food, our water doing now? With these young people, I watched a variety of "Earthships" videos and they have caused me to become hooked. Earthships are houses that were built with recycled materials, among other things, with walls made of tires.

So, I traded my car for an old school bus that has been painted by an artist in Sarchi. Thus, the idea of ​​SUSTANTABLE BUS (Facebook) was born.

SUSTANTABLE BUS
The idea is to supply the bus with alternative energy sources and as its garden the  plantation of organic vegetables. For the furnishings, pallets are used. I have spoken with the INA (National Institute of Learning) and with the ICT (Tourism Institute of Costa Rica) and both agreed to my idea. And the project will start at just the right time.

ORGANIC CULTIVATION

Montes de Oro is known especially for its mining history. But very slowly, the region is also becoming known for its products. Arrancibia delivers good coffee, El Bueyerito. From Laguna, we get dairy products which are sold to the government. Nevertheless, much is lacking and unemployment is extremely high.

I spent nearly 20 years in Tajo Alto where there is nothing but one hotel. But every one of my neighbors has a finca with good soil, so why should they not use this and farm organically? We can create a Cooperative and sell our products to hotels and restaurants. Vegan food is becoming more popular and Monsanto is a household name. In Montes de Oro, Monsanto was strictly denied entrance.
I decided to create a workshop for which I needed 15 signatures and got 22. Each of the participating families has registered in Tajo Alto. This list was passed to the INA and they will contact us as soon as a date for our course is determined. This course will turn the Sustentable BUS into a bungalow and instead of being decorated with flowers, it will have a vegetable garden.The neighbors learn how and when it can be applied at home. I find it amazing how enthusiastic the people are with this, both women and men, young and old.
We are not just talking about farming, but also about compost and biogas, which is made of compost and cow dung. As we know, there are plenty of cows.

THE WATER
Montes de Oro has got a huge water problem, and the mayor will not distribute the water properly. The Bellavista Mine has also been operating in the main sources of water. (Montes de Oro Sustentable - Facebook) Tajo Alto has a separate water pipe. We have good pressure and good water. This will change from January 2016, and people in Tajo Alto should be prepared.
The SUSTANTABLE BUS comes back into play. Two weeks ago, INA was here and gave us tips on how we can collect rainwater. For that we need for the bus a 5x5x2 meter tank, water pipes, a pump and an ozonator. This initiative will begin to benefit people during the rainy season and the neighbors are invited to see how this is done. They can learn how to install and maintain their water reservoir.


THE TOILET
Even the toilet should be considered. It is really bad how large the toilet tanks are here in Costa Rica; so much water is wasted. The toilet manufacturers, in my view, are great accomplices in wasting water. My idea is that washing hands fills the tank, the water then runs into the waste water,which in turn can be used for organic farming.


THE POWER
The bus will be equipped with a solar system, a system that also supplies power, not only hot water. On the FERIA DE CLIMA in Atenas I spoke with a manufacturer who offered me a system for the bus: An electrical outlet to provide power for a cooker and a fan. The system is offered for $ 1,600, only electricity, no hot water.



THE MISSION
This project will show students that it is not necessary to cut trees in order to obtain electricity, gas and in the future probably also water, at a very high cost to our environment. Mother Earth will no longer be looted, as she now is: cement, stone, sand. They will learn that you can re-utilize already existing materials such as buses and containers, and that one can grow food in order to eat healthy. 

THE VISION
The vision is to build in the future with existing materials and take advantage of the energy that Mother Nature provides- implemented using innovative techniques.

I would be very appreciative of a response from you, 

With best regards

Yours sincerely,
Ulrike Heckmann

campaign_city: Tajo Alto, Miramar, Puntarenas, Costa Rica

story:
PERMACULTURE TEACHER TRAINING CENTRE IN EAST AFRICA

You want to make a difference in Africa, something significant, something real.  Yet increasing Africa's dependency on foreign aid is not the answer... How about enabling East African schoolchildren with the life skills needed to produce their own organic sustainable food, plant their own food forests and gardens, manage seeds, rainwater, potable water, significantly creating a healthy future?


Giving to this project is really about giving "the fishing rod" instead of just a fish.  The knowledge of Permaculture (a regenerative, sustainable organic agriculture) will allow us to make a huge difference, together, in creating a self-sustainable future for East Africa.


After two successful schools completed already in Kenya and Uganda, the Seven Ravens Permaculture Academy (from British Colombia, Canada) continues its work in East Africa with the intention to build a third Permaculture Teacher Training Centre in Mt. Meru, Tanzania. This project will take place from Oct 21st to Nov. 14th 2015, and will teach the practical principles of Permaculture to hundreds of primary school teachers.  By including the knowledge of hands-on Permaculture to their students in the school curriculum, the children will carry it on to their respective communities and families.  The ripple effect is phenomenal: educating hundreds of schoolteachers, every year, multiplied by hundreds of students multiplied by family members, community, and genuine hope for the future will quickly result in millions of East Africans empowering each other towards food security, environmental sustainability, and success.


This is a life-changing revolution for those communities and children, living in impoverished, environmentally degraded areas.  Through this sustainable agricultural education, the children learn the skills to grow their own food, manage and access clean water, preserve seeds for the future, and earn income directly from their recent education.  As a successful example, one of the primary schools in Butala (Western Province of Kenya) adopted Michael Nickels’ Permaculture design, and within only ONE year jumped from last to first place academically and athletically - out of the 64 schools within the region.  This is just one of countless cases in which Permaculture has been proven to improve hundreds of lives within a community.


MICHAEL AND THE SEVEN RAVENS ACADEMY

Michael Nickels is the founder of the Seven Ravens Permaculture Academy, on Salt Spring Island BC, Canada.  He has been designing permaculture projects across the world since 1990, including 10 different schools already thriving within Kenya.  Throughout his many years in the region, Michael has ignited the knowledge of permaculture design, through large-scale earthworks as well as the planting of over 10 million trees.  The natural progression was to involve the community and create a foundation for Africans teaching Africans.  With this intention, he has successfully established the first two Permaculture Teacher Training Centres in Butala (Western Kenya) in 2013, and in Calagi (Uganda) in 2014.  With such a solid experience and a 25-year relationship with East Africa, Michael has developed a reliable network of African partners, an ability to plan the costs and the skills necessary to overcome the obstacles of such projects.


Michael brings his own Canadian permaculture students to Africa, through the Fall course of his Academy, and joins a pre-chosen African location with a local workforce to build the self-sufficient Teacher Training Centre.  The building phase includes classrooms, dormitories and composting toilets, and immediately involves local schoolteachers and children to create gardens & forests for food, seed, medicine and wood.  There will be tree nurseries, seed banks, rainwater & fish ponds, potable water access, and so much more.  This centre will transform into a nurturing, healthy, ecological place to learn and spread the knowledge. This will attract more teachers each year, more students, more change. 

This is how we can really make such a difference.


TEACHING FOOD SECURITY & SELF-SUFFICIENCY... $ 1 PER CHILD

In order to build our 3rd Permaculture Teacher Training Centre in rural Mt. Meru, Tanzania we must first raise $165,000 to facilitate the future of self-sustainability in East Africa.

The budget we are raising money towards is managed as follows:

Gardens, Tree Nursery and Water Systems - $ 29 000                                  

Building Expenses - $ 59 000

Local Labour Expenses - $ 33 000                                         

Tanzanian Consulting and Development  - $ 19 000

Travel Expenses - $ 10 150*

Crowdfunding Fees - $ 14 850

*Additional travel expenses are personally funded by Michael Nickels and the wonderful students of The Seven Ravens Permaculture Academy on Saltspring Island, BC, Canad

As with most projects, the greatest financial and physical effort is in the initial phase...  But the results from this school will be staggering.  After just one year of operation, the hundreds of teachers taught through this Training Centre, will go back home to transform their whole primary school, influencing over 140 000 children’s lives. Do the math: that’s almost a dollar per child!  Now, can you imagine this self-sufficient project’s exponential impact over many years? 

Africa is changing, and this is how you can help.


Thank you so much for being a part of it, for contributing, and for taking a few minutes to spread the word about this life-changing initiative.

Asante Sana!

Michael Nickels

http://www.seven-ravens.com


For questions, comments or more information on this fantastic initiative send any inquires to sevenravenspermaculture@gmail.com
