story:
What is Save Musmuki?

Save Musmuki is an innovative enterprise that pursues sustainable funding for the Entrópika Foundation, a Colombian-based NGO dedicated to the protection of tropical biodiversity in the Amazon Forest.

With your contributions, we will develop a product that will be sold and generate permanent income for the organization. The product is a videogame themed around the problem of illegal trafficking of wildlife in the Amazon forest, focusing on the special case of the Musmuki night monkeys, illegally traded for biomedical research.

The main goal is to permanently raise funds but also to educate players in conservation issues and the importance of biodiversity in the Amazon Forest, bringing awareness on these issues.

20% of contributions of this campaign will directly go to Entropika Foundation, specifically to help them fight the trafficking of wildlife while improving indigenous livelihoods.

Once developed and commercialized, 25% of the income generated by the videogame will directly go to Fundación Entropika.


In order to keep contributors informed at all times, BOPIN Games will periodically publish information on the advances in the development of the game.

Our mission is to design videogames that act as interaction mechanisms between the ecosystem and the wider public by strengthening awareness on conservation issues and teaching to care for the planet’s biodiversity.

Make this dream possible! Help the Musmuki find his parents! and become an active part of the solution!

Your feedback is always welcome!

Watch the demo of the videogame, it's looking pretty cool so far!


Fundación Entropika was established in 2007 by a group of dedicated conservationists, from varying backgrounds, based in Amacayacu National Park in the Southern Colombian Amazon. Entropika aims at contributing to the long-term conservation of tropical biodiversity by facilitating community-led projects, establishing programmes of education and research whilst working closely with local indigenous people to tackle conservation issues. Our approach encourages interdisciplinary cooperation regarding the management of biodiversity components, including in-situ conservation, community-based research, environmental policies revision and enforcement, improvement of indigenous living standards, and the feasibility analyses of sustainable economic alternatives.

WebSite Entropika


This species is being illegally traded in the Colombian-Peruvian Amazon. Their vulnerability has led to the loss of its parents and its habitat. Musmuki is the silent hero of this story.

·  Night monkeys, or owl monkeys, are called “Musmuki” by local people in the forests of Peru.

·  Musmuki’s scientific name is Aotus, which in Latin it means “without ears”, because their ears are very small.

·  Night monkeys, or Musmukis, are also called owl monkeys because of their similarity with owls in the shape of the face and size of the eyes.

·  Aotus are the only nocturnal monkey in the new world.

·  Musmukis have disproportionately large brown eyes which have evolved as an adaptation to their nocturnal lifestyle.

·  In captivity, night monkeys are monogamous animals; which means they have only one couple mate for a lifetime. In the wild, they separate regularly.

·  Night monkeys are found from Panama to Argentina. They can live in a wide variety of forest types and elevations that range from sea level to 3.200m.

·  Musmukis are arboreal animals, so they spend their life in the trees.

·  Musmukis live in groups from 2 to 5 individuals; one adult of each sex and their children.

·  Adult Musmuki males carry their children because they are stronger and are able to escape predators more easily, while the female is weaker because it is lactating and spending a lot of energy feeding the offspring.

·  Adult Musmuki males transfer food to children more often that the females.

·  In the Amazonian border between Colombian and Peru there are two types (species) of night monkeys: the Aotus nancymaae or Musmuki (Nancy Ma’s Night Monkey) and the Aotus vociferans or Buri-buri (Spix's Night Monkey).

·  The latest assessment of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN), upgraded the Musmuki’s conservation status from Least Concern (LC) to Vulnerable (VU) owing to increasing threats for these monkeys, such as their extraction for being used in malaria research and the loss of their habitat.

·  Musmukis are one of the few monkey species that are affected by malaria, making them useful as non-human primate experimental models in malaria research.

·  In Peru, Musmukis are reproduced in captivity for malaria research. Sadly, in Colombia, Musmukis are captured from the wild for this purpose.

·  Advanced research in malaria stopped using Musmukis for experimentation, as current vaccines are tested on humans.

· When capturing Musmukis for malaria research, local trappers have to cut down in average 15m of forest around the nest where the Musmukis live. The trapping methods are hence affecting their environment, increasing deforestation of the fragile Amazon rainforest.

It is the largest monkey in the New World. It has a woolly coat and a courageous walk. In this videogame, Churuco is Musmuki’s best friend.

  • Woolly monkeys are called “Churucos” by local people in the Amazon forest in Colombia.
  • Woolly monkey’s scientific name is Lagothrix lagothricha, which relates to its fur; they have beautiful hair like a soft toy.
  • Churucos have a prehensile tail, meaning they can use their tail for grabbing. The tail has a soft skin in the top, like the skin of their hands, and acts as a powerful fifth limb.
  • Churucos can hang from their tail and remain suspended while looking for food or eating fruits in canopy branches.
  • Churucos can only live in primary and well-preserved forests. So they live in the dense Amazon forests of Colombia, Brazil, Ecuador and Peru.
  • Churucos are one of the largest monkeys in South America; their average weight is 9 kg. For this reason, they are hunted (mainly by indigenous people) for their meat.
  • Churucos are mainly frugivorous, meaning they prefer to eat fruits.
  • Churucos live in groups that range from 9 to more than 30 individuals. The groups are composed of several males and females from different ages.
  • Churucos are very social and kind animals. They are very patient with their children and several females and males can take care of the same offspring.
  • Females breastfeed for approximately 20 months and their birth interval ranges from 18 to 24 months.
  • Churucos are very susceptible to hunting; even at a small scale hunting can drive populations to extinction.
  • When hunters target females that are pregnant or with an offspring to be sold in the pet trade, they are drastically affecting their population recovery.
  • Churucos are effective seed dispersers, for this reason, the decrease of their populations will affect forest structure.
  • The latest assessment of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) upgraded the Churuco’s conservation status from Vulnerable (VU) to Endangered (EN). Their main threats are: hunting for the bush meat and pet trade markets, habitat loss and forest degradation.

WHITE COAT CRIMINALS

Laboratory scientists, advocates of animal exploitation and illegal trafficking of wildlife, who never hesitate to snatch their prey from the forest.

SMUGGLERS

They hunt and later sell animals in danger of extinction. The indiscriminate cutting down of Amazonian forest is also present on their extensive criminal record. 

COLONISTS

Accomplices in the illegal trafficking of wildlife. Destructive and ruthless people, they are capable of anything for money.

ANACONDA

A constrictor snake that hungrily squeezes its prey. It immerses itself in the great waters of the Amazon to remain unnoticed.

PIRANHA

They are known for their sharp teeth, powerful jaws, and voracious appetite for meat. With an acute sense of smell, they collectively attack its prey.

BLACK CAIMAN

The black caiman of the Amazon rainforest is often mistaken for an alligator, which it closely resembles. However, true alligators only live in two places in the world, and neither is a rainforest environment: the Southeastern US and the Yangtze River in China.

Like all crocodilians, caimans eat a variety of fish, amphibians, turtles, birds and mammals—whatever creature happens to be unlucky enough to wander near them.

MARGAY

Like most felines, it is solitary and nocturnal, with fiery eyes and intoxicating essence in its roar. As a carnivore, it hides in the shadows.

HARPY EAGLE

It is the largest and most powerful raptor found in the Americas, and among the largest extant species of eagles in the world. They are known to prey on monkeys and other mid-sized arboreal mammals.


ENVIRONMENTAL POLICE

Specialized Corps of the Police that support the community in defending and protecting the environment.

PINK DOLPHIN

The world's largest river dolphin. Its characteristics give it great manoeuvrability so it can navigate the flooded forest. Naturally intelligent, legend says that it held humanity in its core, but the gods envied it and decided to transform it from human to animal.

SCARLET MACAW

Popular in the jungle for its friendly behavior, it is a multi-colored bird whose body expresses sublime powers of singing and flying.

SHAMAN

The story goes that Yuche, who has always lived in the world accompanied by Musmukis and all fauna and flora of the universe, saw the earth age, gaining extensive knowledge of his environment and sacred rituals to understand it.


· $70,000 USD: Videogame for Android, iOS and Windows Phone platforms

· $120,000 USD: Videogame for Wii, Xbox One and PlayStation 4



AOTUS PROJECT – FUNDACIÓN ENTROPIKA 

During our census fieldwork work we realized that there is an international trade of night monkeys for biomedical research. These are sourced illegally from Peru and Brazil to Colombia. So, in 2008 we started an investigation that quantified this trade and their wild populations.

Our results suggest that Aotus vociferans, which is widely distributed in Colombia, was not found in the Colombian side of the Amazon River anymore. This, because of being overharvested for its use in malaria research. In addition, the species Aotus nancymaae, whose natural distribution has been described to be in Peru and Brazil, is now found in Colombia.

Recent studies demonstrate that there is an endemic population of this species in Colombia with a very small distribution. And there is another population whose origins come from the releases of the animals captured in Peru, used in Colombia for malaria research and then released back into the wild in Colombia, for almost 40 years.

In order to stop this trade we filed a popular benefit law suit against the biomedical laboratory, the Colombian Ministry of Environment and the regional environmental authority from the Amazon. In 2014, we won the law case. This set a historical precedent in Colombia regarding the sustainable use of biodiversity and the enforcement of environmental law.

The laboratory’s permit to capture wild individuals of Aotus vociferans in the Colombian Amazon was resumed as a result of an unconstitutional Court’s ruling and they will continue releasing monkeys in areas where studies suggest not to in order to preserve these species. Therefore, we urgently need to continue research and the follow-up of our legal actions.




Dr. Angela Maldonado - MSc, PhD, Conservationist, Colombia

Founder member - Legal representative & scientific director

She has a BSc in Business management, an MSc in Primate Conservation and a PhD in conservation granted by the Department of Anthropology and Geography, at Oxford Brookes University (UK). She is the scientific director of the Fundación Entropika since 2007 and the representative of the Colombian Primatological Society in the Amazonia since 2009. Her long-term field experience for more than 17 years in the Colombian Amazon has shaped specialist knowledge in conservation biology and community based-research alongside indigenous communities from Colombia and Peru. She was the winner of the Whitley Gold Award in 2010, also called “The Green Oscar” and also won the Colombian prize “El Defensor del Año” “The Animal Defender of the Year” in 2015. Thanks to Whitley Gold Award she was nominated by Revista Gerente as one of the 100 most influential people in Colombian society and one of the 15 most important people of the year in Colombia by El Espectador newspaper.


Thomas Lafon - BSc, MPhil, Software Engineer, Belgium

Associate member - Substitute legal representative

Graduate from Oxford Brookes University with a BSc in Software Engineering and an MPhil in Numerical Modelling, Thomas has got experience in the use of a wide variety of programs. For two years he has worked at the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology in Wallingford, England, where he began his work in climatology. Thomas is currently working as coordinator of the Water Cycle Project which aims at improving access to clean drinking water in 14 indigenous communities located along the Amazon River through the use of bio-sand filters at community and household levels. This project includes a study on the levels of the Amazon River to predict future floods and droughts in the area.


Daniel Aristizabal - BA, MA, Sociologist, Colombia

Associate member

He has a Masters in development studies from the Institute for Social Studies of the Erasmus University of Rotterdam and a Bachelor of Arts in Sociology from York University. His MA research focused on the rights to self-determination of the only recognized indigenous group of the Colombian Amazon in voluntary isolation. He was a volunteer in Brazil and then for Fundación Entropika during 2008. Since 2011, he has been part of the professional team of the Amacayacu National Natural Park and since 2013 he is in charge of writing the national policy for the protection of isolated indigenous people. His interests lie in finding bridges for the intercultural management of the Amazon, especially regarding the relationships between conservation, traditional practices, productive alternatives and cultural changes.


Eliana Martínez - BSc, MSc, Conservationist, Colombia

Founder member

Graduate of a BSc in Animal Management and an MSc in Development and Natural Resources Management. She has been working in the Colombian Amazon for 20 years conducting research on wildlife and its use by local communities and sustainable projects for indigenous communities (7 ethnic groups). She has worked in Amacayacu National Park for three years as part of the Sustainable Productive Strategy, was park director of Puré National Park and currently is the director of Amacayacu National Park.   


María José Bermudez - BA, MA (c), Journalist, Colombia 

Associate member

Student of Communication for Development at the University of La Sabana, Colombia. She has been a volunteer for Entropika between 2011 and 2012 where she worked in the development, from an audio-visual point of view, of various Amazonian indigenous communities. Her interest focuses in using audio-visual tools for growth and social change. In Bogotá, she has worked with communities of women, abused children, and groups in extreme poverty, among other activities, doing workshops in photography and video to provide alternative tools to these groups. In Amazonas, with the foundation, she has lead the participatory video initiative which began as her undergraduate project. The projects consists in training a group of an indigenous community in video production and editing in order for them to generate a collective memory at community-level, and recover and document traditional knowledge to be passed down from generation to generation.


Luisa Duarte - BSc, Biologist, Colombia 

Associate member

Graduate in biology from the Universidad INCCA de Colombia, Luisa is currently completing a specialisation in Conservation of Natural Resource in the Universidade do Estado do Amazonas, Brazil. She has experience with wildlifeex-situin reception, rehabilitation and release centres and in activities such as behaviour, feeding, bird rehabilitation techniques, and raising of hatchling birds and mammals. In-situ, she has experience in the taxonomic identification of birds and mammals, census, and training of villagers in the care and conservation of fauna. In Entropika, Luisa is in charge of environmental education on issues such as solid waste management and recycling plastic materials for making crafts. Currently, she is working ineducation, teachng about issues such as conservation, climate change and environmental impacts. She is also interested in deepening her knowledge in ornithology and wildlife photography.


Lina Peláez - BSc, MSc (c), Veterinarian, Colombia 

Associate member 

Wildlife veterinarian graduated from Universidad Nacional de Colombia, she is currently doing her Masters in Amazonian studies in Leticia, Amazonas, Colombia. Lina has been working with primates in the Amazonian region of Colombia since 2004. In 2006, she participated in the Woolly Monkey Project (First Entropika’s project) and continued working against the illegal trade of primates in the Aotus Project since then. She has been the wildlife veterinarian for the primates of Fundación Maikuchiga, situated in the Amacayacu National Park since 2006. She has also given medical care to domestic animals of indigenous communities, such as Mocagua and San Martín. Lina is interested in the study of infectious diseases affecting wild and domestic animals. Conservation, and the veterinarian and behavioural management of wildlife in captivity are also substantial topics in her daily work. Currently she works in the Amacayacu National Park.


Xavier Echavez - BSc, Biologist, Colombia

Volunteer

He Works in participatory video with two schools in Leticia where children learn about filming and editing  videos related to environmental issues. This year, they have been working on the critical state of waste management in Leticia. The children are leaders of the project and decide what they want to show about this problem. They are doing this to raise their awareness about the implications of a bad waste management for their own well-being. He is also in charge of the fieldwork to collect baseline information on the ecology of night monkeys in Tanimboca Private Reserve.


Tamara Bonilla - BSc, MSc, Veterinarian, Colombia 

Associate researcher

Since 2014 she has been working in animal welfare campaigns to improve the deplorable conditions of domestic animals in Leticia. During these campaigns Entropika has managed to deworm, vaccinate and sterilize around 250 stray dogs and cats. Tamara also gives classes in schools of Leticia on the care and wellbeing of domestic animals. 


Juan Rodriguez - Expert in Traditional Ecological Knowledge, Colombia

Local coordinator

He is a native of the Tikuna tribe and has captured night monkeys for malaria research for 14 years.  Since 2010, he has left the trade to become the local coordinator of the Aotus Project and contribute to the conservation of the night monkeys.


Alejandro Botero 

Technology Consultant

Senior programmer in Colombian technology companies, with over 20 years of experience in the field. Co-founder of PDA ADVANCED LTD, a games and tools company, whose products include the video games PDAPacXtreme and PDARubix, as well as the tool PDAGraphix.


Felipe Botero 

CEO / Producer

A business administrator with a specialization in Business Management, he has worked in various positions in the Colombian technology sector. Currently, he directs BOPIN Games and leads technological alternatives to raise awareness about conservation.


William Ramos 

Creative / Art Director

Artist, physiognomic caricaturist and illustrator with 20 years of experience in digital drawing. He has an extensive background in illustration of characters and has participated in multiple versions of the Bogota book fair as a guest cartoonist.


Daniel Mauricio Porras Bulla 

Programmer

Programmer with 7 years of experience in unity 3D. Also a 3D modeler, 2D and 3D animator and songwriter for video games.


Alejandro Parra 

Plastic artist

A Colombian artist recognized for his contributions to peace through art. He holds the Guinness world record for most hugs for peace. His work reflects why he is considered one of  Colombia’s top artists.


Giovanni Paez 

Illustrator

Illustrator and teacher with experience in different techniques, including screen printing and aerography, with knowledge of digital illustration and use of Photoshop, Corel Draw and Illustrator. He has been an illustrator for magazines and newspapers for youth organizations and has worked as a teacher in arts workshops for children and youths in schools and foundations.


Thomas Lafon 

Programmer

Software engineer from Oxford Brookes University, UK, Thomas has long used his programming skills for the conservation of the Amazonian rainforest, mainly through the analysis of data on wildlife and the design of material to raise awareness on conservation issues. He has worked with Fundación Entropika for 5 years, a local NGO located in the Colombian Amazon, dedicated to the conservation of wildlife and the improvement of indigenous living standards.


Alejandro Navia

Graphic Designer and Social Media Marketing Expert

Social media expert with five years of experience managing professional social media accounts. 



COMPANY PROFILE

ProyectoEZ is a brand-building studio. We are passionate about brands.We design and define them. We mix strategy and passion to create memorable brands. Our approach is to generate results that reflect positively on a business.


Alejandro Giraldo

Graphic Designer

Throughout his career, he has had the opportunity to work on different branding and packaging projects. Currently working with ProyectoEZ where he has spent more than two years developing branding and packaging projects.

Pablo Gomez

Graphic Designer

Within the broad field of design he has focused his attention for the last few years on the development of strategy and brand design projects, he is passionate about understanding how a brand is presented and fits perfectly into the mindspace of every consumer.


MUSMUKI FAMILY


PERKS

COTTON HAMMOCK

A hammock made from cotton using top quality yarns. Due to its natural color, it does not fade in any environment. Product handmade by Colombian artisans.


TEDDY

Teddy made from hypoallergenic polyester fiber and manufactured by single mothers.


LAPTOP CASE

Carry and protect your computer with a bag made from 100% biodegradable material, made by single mothers.


ECO-BAG

An earth-friendly bag made by single mothers from 100% biodegradable material.


APRON

Environmentally-friendly apron made using 100% biodegradable fabric, manufactured by single mothers.


CUP FOR HOT DRINKS

BPA-free material, using environmentally-friendly materials, fully reusable.


AVATAR

Custom-made dolls in cold porcelain that are made and hand painted with the support of the Good Samaritan Foundation, which helps low-income youth to learn crafts.


FINGER PUPPETS

Six Finger Puppet characters related to the game, made of polyester fiber, using hypoallergenic materials, handmade by single mothers.


DIGITAL ART COMPENDIUM

Compendium of digital art from the game, handmade by our skilled artists.


ORIGINAL SOUNDTRACK CD

Collection of exclusive music from the game.


PERSONALIZED AVATAR CARICATURE

Customized avatar caricature designed by hand draw experts


POSTER

Exclusive poster related to the game.


BUST SCULPTURE

Customized bust made and painted by hand in cold porcelain, caricaturesque art.


WAYUU BAG

Wayuu bags are authentic hand made by indigenous women from the Wayuu tribe.

One bag may take between 3-4 full time weeks to complete. The Wayuu bags are an artistic and philosophical way of expressing their cultural beliefs and values, and remembers the colours of animals, flowers and sceneries that surround the Wayuu tribe.


ARHUACO BAG 

100% sheep wool hand-woven by women from the Arhuacos community.

The bags are woven using both hands and feet to tightly crochet one thread in a circular manner, radiating out from the center of the base, in the same way that the Arhuaco believe Serankwa created the earth.


APPEARANCE AS POLICE IN THE GAME

Environmental police appear in the game, capturing criminals.


DONATE A BIOSAND FILTER - FUNDACIÓN ENTROPIKA!

Biosand filters: Since January 2014 we have installed biosand filtration systems for obtaining clean water in 80 households of the indigenous communities of Mocagua, Colombia, and Chinería, Peru, as well as 2 communitarian filtration systems in the communities of Mocagua and San Martín, Colombia, benefiting a total of approx. 1350 people. We also monitor communitarian and household filters in 11 other communities and supervise the installation of water systems in 3 communities, 2 schools, an orphanage and a retirement home. Biosand filters are cost-effective and have been used successfully in various parts of the world (e.g. Africa and Latin America). Studies assessing the effectiveness of the system found that between 88% and 100% of E. coli bacteria (causing, amongst others, diarrhoea) are removed by the filter (e.g. Baker et al., 2006), reducing on average by 44% cases of diarrhoea in the population. Furthermore, Liang et al. (2007) have determined that 88% of the filters installed in a community in Cambodia are still in use after 8 years of operation; demonstrating the feasibility and viability of this alternative in rural areas. One significant advantage of the filter is that it does not require any chemicals to function. Water processed by the filter is not "potable" in the scientific sense; however the filter significantly improves the quality of the water and, as such, health in general.


FULLY PERSONALIZED CARICATURE

Customized Caricature. Hand draw by experts


ACKNOWLEDGMENTS 

Needless to say, we want to give special thanks to all those whose contributions are already part of this wonderful journey to raise awareness of conservation.


Other Ways You Can Help



Please SHARE this page with all your friends!

Follow us on social media! Join us now as this exciting save Musmuki mission.  Like us on facebook, follow us on Twitter, and visit our Website.

Tell people it's important to save Musmuki(More info here)

Talk to us - we'd love your feedback about this project! (www.bopingames.com)

Thank you for your support !
story_txt:
What is Save Musmuki?
Save Musmuki is an innovative enterprise that pursues sustainable funding for the Entrópika Foundation, a Colombian-based NGO dedicated to the protection of tropical biodiversity in the Amazon Forest.
With your contributions, we will develop a product that will be sold and generate permanent income for the organization. The product is a
videogame themed around the problem of illegal trafficking of wildlife in the
Amazon forest, focusing on the special case of the Musmuki night monkeys, illegally traded for biomedical research.
The main goal is to permanently raise funds but also to educate players in conservation issues and the importance of biodiversity in the Amazon Forest, bringing awareness on these issues.
20% of contributions of this campaign will directly go to Entropika Foundation, specifically
to help them fight the trafficking of wildlife while improving indigenous livelihoods.
Once developed and commercialized, 25% of the
income generated by the videogame will directly go to Fundación Entropika.
In order to keep contributors informed at all times, BOPIN
Games will periodically publish information on the advances in the development
of the game.

Our mission is to design videogames that act as
interaction mechanisms between the ecosystem and the wider public by
strengthening awareness on conservation issues and teaching to care for the
planet’s biodiversity.
Make this dream possible! Help the Musmuki find his parents! and become an
active part of the solution!
Your feedback is always welcome!

Watch the demo of the videogame, it's looking pretty cool so far!





Fundación Entropika was
established in 2007 by a group of dedicated conservationists, from varying
backgrounds, based in Amacayacu National Park in the Southern Colombian Amazon.
Entropika aims at contributing to the long-term
conservation of tropical biodiversity by facilitating community-led projects,
establishing programmes of education and research whilst working closely with local indigenous people to tackle conservation issues. Our approach
encourages interdisciplinary cooperation regarding the management of
biodiversity components, including in-situ
conservation, community-based research, environmental policies revision and
enforcement, improvement of indigenous living standards, and the feasibility
analyses of sustainable economic alternatives.


WebSite Entropika







This species is being illegally traded in the Colombian-Peruvian Amazon.
  Their vulnerability has led to the loss of its parents and its habitat. Musmuki
  is the silent hero of this story.
· 
  Night monkeys, or owl monkeys, are called “Musmuki” by local people in the forests
  of Peru.
· 
Musmuki’s
scientific name is Aotus, which in
Latin it means “without ears”, because their ears are very small.
· 
Night monkeys, or Musmukis, are also called owl monkeys because of their similarity
with owls in the shape of the face and size of the eyes.
· 
Aotus are the
only nocturnal monkey in the new world.
· 
Musmukis have
disproportionately large brown eyes which have evolved as an adaptation to
their nocturnal lifestyle.
· 
In captivity, night monkeys are monogamous
animals; which means they have only one couple mate for a lifetime. In the
wild, they separate regularly.
· 
Night monkeys are found from Panama to
Argentina. They can live in a wide variety of forest types and elevations that
range from sea level to 3.200m.
· 
Musmukis are
arboreal animals, so they spend their life in the trees.
· 
Musmukis live in
groups from 2 to 5 individuals; one adult of each sex and their children. 
· 
Adult Musmuki
males carry their children because they are stronger and are able to escape
predators more easily, while the female is weaker because it is lactating and
spending a lot of energy feeding the offspring. 
· 
Adult Musmuki
males transfer food to children more often that the females.
· 
In the Amazonian border between Colombian
and Peru there are two types (species) of night monkeys: the Aotus nancymaae or Musmuki (Nancy Ma’s Night Monkey) and the Aotus vociferans or Buri-buri (Spix's Night Monkey).
· 
The latest assessment of the International
Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN), upgraded the Musmuki’s conservation status from Least Concern (LC) to Vulnerable
(VU) owing to increasing threats for these monkeys, such as their extraction
for being used in malaria research and the loss of their habitat. 
· 
Musmukis are one
of the few monkey species that are affected by malaria, making them useful as
non-human primate experimental models in malaria research.
· 
In Peru, Musmukis are reproduced in captivity for malaria research. Sadly,
in Colombia, Musmukis are captured
from the wild for this purpose.
· 
Advanced research in malaria stopped using Musmukis for experimentation, as current
vaccines are tested on humans. 

· When
capturing Musmukis for malaria
research, local trappers have to cut down in average 15m of forest around the
nest where the Musmukis live. The
trapping methods are hence affecting their environment, increasing
deforestation of the fragile Amazon rainforest.

indigenous communities from Colombia and Peru. She was the winner of the
Whitley Gold Award in 2010, also called “The Green Oscar” and also won the
Colombian prize “El Defensor del Año” “The Animal Defender of the Year” in 2015.
Thanks to Whitley Gold Award she was nominated by Revista Gerente as one of the
100 most influential people in Colombian society and one of the 15 most
important people of the year in Colombia by El
Espectador newspaper.

Thomas Lafon - BSc, MPhil, Software Engineer, Belgium






Associate member -
Substitute legal representative
Graduate from Oxford Brookes University with a BSc in Software
Engineering and an MPhil in Numerical Modelling, Thomas has got experience in
the use of a wide variety of programs. For two years he has worked at the
Centre for Ecology and Hydrology in Wallingford, England, where he began his
work in climatology. Thomas is currently working as coordinator of the Water
Cycle Project which aims at improving access to clean drinking water in 14 indigenous communities located along the Amazon River through the use of
bio-sand filters at community and household levels. This project includes a
study on the levels of the Amazon River to predict future floods and droughts
in the area.

Daniel Aristizabal - BA, MA, Sociologist, Colombia




Associate member
He has a Masters in development studies from the Institute for Social
Studies of the Erasmus University of Rotterdam and a Bachelor of Arts in
Sociology from York University. His MA research focused on the rights to
self-determination of the only recognized indigenous group of the Colombian
Amazon in voluntary isolation. He was a volunteer in Brazil and then for
Fundación Entropika during 2008. Since 2011, he has been part of the
professional team of the Amacayacu National Natural Park and since 2013 he is in
charge of writing the national policy for the protection of isolated indigenous
people. His interests lie in finding bridges for the intercultural management
of the Amazon, especially regarding the relationships between conservation,
traditional practices, productive alternatives and cultural changes.


Eliana Martínez - BSc, MSc, Conservationist,
Colombia



Founder member


Graduate of a BSc in Animal Management and an MSc in Development and
Natural Resources Management. She has been working in the Colombian Amazon for 20
years conducting research on wildlife and its use by local communities and
sustainable projects for indigenous communities (7 ethnic groups). She has
worked in Amacayacu National Park for three years as part of the Sustainable
Productive Strategy, was park director of Puré National Park and currently is
the director of Amacayacu National Park.   

María José Bermudez - BA, MA (c), Journalist,
Colombia 

Associate member

Student of Communication for Development at the University of La Sabana,
Colombia. She has been a volunteer for Entropika between 2011 and 2012 where
she worked in the development, from an audio-visual point of view, of various
Amazonian indigenous communities. Her interest focuses in using audio-visual
tools for growth and social change. In Bogotá, she has worked with communities
of women, abused children, and groups in extreme poverty, among other
activities, doing workshops in photography and video to provide alternative
tools to these groups. In Amazonas, with the foundation, she has lead the
participatory video initiative which began as her undergraduate project. The
projects consists in training a group of an indigenous community in video
production and editing in order for them to generate a collective memory at
community-level, and recover and document traditional knowledge to be passed
down from generation to generation.


Luisa Duarte - BSc, Biologist, Colombia 




Associate member


Graduate in biology from the Universidad INCCA de Colombia, Luisa is
currently completing a specialisation in Conservation of Natural Resource in
the Universidade do Estado do Amazonas, Brazil. She has experience with
wildlifeex-situin reception, rehabilitation and
release centres and in activities such as behaviour, feeding, bird
rehabilitation techniques, and raising of hatchling birds and mammals. In-situ,
she has experience in the taxonomic identification of birds and mammals, census,
and training of villagers in the care and conservation of fauna. In Entropika,
Luisa is in charge of environmental education on issues such as solid waste
management and recycling plastic materials for making crafts. Currently, she is
working ineducation, teachng about issues such as conservation, climate change
and environmental impacts. She is also interested in deepening her knowledge in
ornithology and wildlife photography.

Lina Peláez - BSc, MSc
(c), Veterinarian, Colombia 



Associate member 


Wildlife veterinarian graduated from Universidad
Nacional de Colombia, she is currently doing her Masters in Amazonian studies
in Leticia, Amazonas, Colombia. Lina has been working with primates in the
Amazonian region of Colombia since 2004. In 2006, she participated in the
Woolly Monkey Project (First Entropika’s project) and continued working against
the illegal trade of primates in the Aotus
Project since then. She has been the wildlife veterinarian for the primates of
Fundación Maikuchiga, situated in the Amacayacu National Park since 2006. She
has also given medical care to domestic animals of indigenous communities, such
as Mocagua and San Martín. Lina is interested in the study of infectious
diseases affecting wild and domestic animals. Conservation, and the
veterinarian and behavioural management of wildlife in captivity are also
substantial topics in her daily work. Currently she works in the Amacayacu
National Park.

Xavier
Echavez - BSc, Biologist, Colombia

Volunteer

He Works in participatory video with two schools in Leticia where
children learn about filming and editing 
videos related to environmental issues. This year, they have been
working on the critical state of waste management in Leticia. The children are
leaders of the project and decide what they want to show about this problem.
They are doing this to raise their awareness about the implications of a bad
waste management for their own well-being. He is also in charge of the
fieldwork to collect baseline information on the ecology of night monkeys in
Tanimboca Private Reserve.


Tamara Bonilla - BSc, MSc, Veterinarian,
Colombia 


Associate researcher

Since 2014 she has been working in animal welfare campaigns to improve the
deplorable conditions of domestic animals in Leticia. During these campaigns Entropika
has managed to deworm, vaccinate and sterilize around 250 stray dogs and cats.
Tamara also gives classes in schools of Leticia on the care and wellbeing of
domestic animals. 

Juan Rodriguez - Expert
in Traditional Ecological Knowledge, Colombia




Local coordinator


He is a native of the Tikuna tribe and has captured night monkeys for
malaria research for 14 years.  Since
2010, he has left the trade to become the local coordinator of the Aotus Project and contribute to the
conservation of the night monkeys.





Alejandro
Botero 

Technology Consultant

Senior programmer in Colombian
technology companies, with over 20 years of experience in the field. Co-founder
of PDA ADVANCED LTD, a games and tools company, whose products include the
video games PDAPacXtreme and PDARubix, as well as the tool PDAGraphix.


Felipe Botero 


CEO / Producer


A business administrator with a specialization in Business Management,
he has worked in various positions in the Colombian technology
sector. Currently, he directs BOPIN Games and leads technological alternatives
to raise awareness about conservation.


William Ramos 
Creative / Art Director


Artist, physiognomic caricaturist and illustrator with 20 years of experience
in digital drawing. He has an extensive background in illustration of
characters and has participated in multiple versions of the Bogota book fair as
a guest cartoonist.


Daniel Mauricio Porras Bulla 
Programmer


Programmer with 7 years of experience in unity 3D. Also a 3D modeler, 2D
and 3D animator and songwriter for video games.


Alejandro Parra 
Plastic artist


A Colombian artist recognized for his contributions to peace through
art. He holds the Guinness world record for most hugs for peace. His work reflects why he is considered one of  Colombia’s top artists.



Giovanni Paez 
Illustrator
Illustrator and teacher with experience in different techniques,
including screen printing and aerography, with knowledge of digital
illustration and use of Photoshop, Corel Draw and Illustrator. He has been an
illustrator for magazines and newspapers for youth organizations and has worked
as a teacher in arts workshops for children and youths in schools and
foundations.



Thomas Lafon 
Programmer


Software engineer from Oxford Brookes University, UK, Thomas has long
used his programming skills for the conservation of the Amazonian rainforest,
mainly through the analysis of data on wildlife and the design of material to
raise awareness on conservation issues. He has worked with Fundación Entropika
for 5 years, a local NGO located in the Colombian Amazon, dedicated to the
conservation of wildlife and the improvement of indigenous living standards.



Alejandro
Navia
Graphic Designer and Social Media Marketing Expert
Social media expert with five years of experience
managing professional social media accounts. 




COMPANY PROFILE 


ProyectoEZ is a brand-building studio. We are passionate about brands.We
design and define them. We mix strategy and passion to create memorable brands.
Our approach is to generate results that reflect positively on a business.



Alejandro Giraldo

Graphic Designer
Throughout his career, he has had the opportunity to work on different
branding and packaging projects. Currently working with ProyectoEZ where he has
spent more than two years developing branding and packaging projects.



Pablo Gomez 

Graphic Designer


Within the broad field of design he has focused his attention for the
last few years on the development of strategy and brand design projects, he is
passionate about understanding how a brand is presented and fits perfectly into
the mindspace of every consumer.



MUSMUKI
FAMILY



PERKS 


COTTON HAMMOCK

A hammock made
from cotton using top quality yarns. Due to its natural color, it does not
fade in any environment. Product handmade by Colombian artisans.



TEDDY


Teddy made from
hypoallergenic polyester fiber and manufactured by single mothers.



LAPTOP CASE


Carry and protect
your computer with a bag made from 100% biodegradable material, made by single
mothers.





ECO-BAG


An earth-friendly
bag made by single mothers from 100% biodegradable material.




APRON


Environmentally-friendly apron made using 100% biodegradable fabric, manufactured by single
mothers.



CUP FOR HOT DRINKS


BPA-free material, using environmentally-friendly materials, fully
reusable.



AVATAR


Custom-made dolls in cold porcelain that are made and hand painted with
the support of the Good Samaritan Foundation, which helps low-income youth to
learn crafts.




FINGER PUPPETS


Six Finger Puppet characters related to the game, made of polyester
fiber, using hypoallergenic materials, handmade by single mothers.



DIGITAL ART COMPENDIUM

Compendium of digital art from the game, handmade by our skilled
artists.




ORIGINAL SOUNDTRACK CD

Collection of exclusive music from the game.




PERSONALIZED AVATAR CARICATURE
Customized avatar caricature designed by hand draw experts






POSTER

Exclusive poster related to the game.




BUST SCULPTURE


Customized bust made and painted by hand in cold porcelain,
caricaturesque art.




WAYUU BAG


Wayuu bags are authentic hand made by indigenous women from the Wayuu
tribe.
One bag may take between 3-4 full time weeks to complete. The Wayuu bags
are an artistic and philosophical way of expressing their cultural beliefs and
values, and remembers the colours of animals, flowers and sceneries that
surround the Wayuu tribe.



ARHUACO BAG 


100% sheep wool hand-woven by women from the Arhuacos community.
The bags are woven using both hands and feet to tightly crochet one
thread in a circular manner, radiating out from the center of the base, in the
same way that the Arhuaco believe Serankwa created the earth.




APPEARANCE AS POLICE IN THE
GAME 
Environmental police appear in the game, capturing criminals.





DONATE A BIOSAND FILTER - FUNDACIÓN ENTROPIKA!
Biosand filters: Since January 2014 we have installed biosand filtration systems for obtaining clean water in 80 households of the indigenous communities of Mocagua, Colombia, and Chinería, Peru, as well as 2 communitarian filtration systems in the communities of Mocagua and San Martín, Colombia, benefiting a total of approx. 1350 people. We also monitor communitarian and household filters in 11 other communities and supervise the installation of water systems in 3 communities, 2 schools, an orphanage and a retirement home. Biosand filters are cost-effective and have been used successfully in various parts of the world (e.g. Africa and Latin America). Studies assessing the effectiveness of the system found that between 88% and 100% of E. coli bacteria (causing, amongst others, diarrhoea) are removed by the filter (e.g. Baker et al., 2006), reducing on average by 44% cases of diarrhoea in the population. Furthermore, Liang et al. (2007) have determined that 88% of the filters installed in a community in Cambodia are still in use after 8 years of operation; demonstrating the feasibility and viability of this alternative in rural areas. One significant advantage of the filter is that it does not require any chemicals to function. Water processed by the filter is not "potable" in the scientific sense; however the filter significantly improves the quality of the water and, as such, health in general.







FULLY PERSONALIZED CARICATURE
Customized Caricature. Hand draw by experts






ACKNOWLEDGMENTS 


Needless to say, we want to give special thanks to
all those whose contributions are already part of this wonderful journey to
raise awareness of conservation.



Other Ways You Can Help
Please SHARE this page with all your friends!
Follow
 us on social media! Join us now as this exciting save Musmuki mission. 
 Like us on facebook, follow us on Twitter, and visit our Website.
Tell people it's important to save Musmuki(More info here)
Talk to us - we'd love your feedback about this project! (www.bopingames.com)Thank you for your support !

story:
On behalf of the Amphibian Survival Alliance and the team on the ground in Ecuador, I would like to personally thank everyone for their adoptions, donations and shares throughout this campaign. It is not every day that we may be able to save an entire species that is on the brink of extinction for less money than many people will spend on a new vehicle. Thank you for making a difference!

Because of the nature of this rescue operation, additional funds will still be needed to care for and breed these frogs for the long-term, as the plan is developed to return the species to its historic range.

If you would like to further support this effort, please visit DONATE on amphibians.org. Under “Please direct my donation to:” on the form, be sure to select “Quito rocket frog.” 

Once you’re on our site, be sure to sign up for our mailing list to receive the latest developments, success stories and more in amphibian conservation, research and education delivered straight to your inbox. You will also be notified of future campaigns like this one where you will become a partner in the conservation success stories of tomorrow.

Thank you everyone! More soon!

Quito rocket frog. Photo:  Santiago Ron.

The potentially imminent eruption of the Cotopaxi Volcano in Ecuador is threatening to wipe out the last surviving population of one of Ecuador’s flagship species, the Critically Endangered Quito rocket frog (Hyloxalus jacobuspetersi). 

So the Amphibian Survival Alliance, the worlds largest partnership for amphibian conservation, has launched this adopt-a-tadpole campaign* to raise $14,500—the cost for Dr Santiago Ron and his team at the Museum of Zoology, Balsa de los Sapos and Catholic University in Ecuador to conduct a swift rescue and pull these rare frogs from the path of this deadly volcano.


The Cotopaxi Volcano continues to release ash, water vapor and sulphur. Photo: Silvia Fernandez.

The Quito rocket frog, which is less than an inch in length, once had a wide distribution in the central and northern Andes of Ecuador, but the population declined precipitously in the ‘80s and ‘90s, probably as the result of disease and climate change. Scientists last recorded evidence of the species in 1989 until rediscovering one remaining population on the banks of the Pita River in 2008.  In early October, the Geophysical Institute of the National Polytechnic School of Ecuador reported increased volcanic activity and President Rafael Correa declared a state of emergency.  

“If we let these frogs go extinct, it won’t be the result of natural causes,” said Don Church, executive director of the Amphibian Survival Alliance. “The reality is that human-driven changes in the environment forced this species to hang out on the edge of a volcano.” 

The Quito rocket frog lives along small streams next to Río Pita. Photo: Santiago Ron.
Scientists are prepared to collect individual frogs and tadpoles from the Pita River. They will then move them to a lab at Balsa de los Sapos, where they will be kept safe in captivity and bred as scientists wait out the volcanic eruption and develop a plan to return the species to its historic sites.

“Even before the eruption, the rocket frog was among the most endangered frogs on Earth,” said Santiago R. Ron, curator of amphibians at the Museum of Zoology in Ecuador. “Here we have a unique opportunity to take action before disaster strikes. By adopting a tadpole with a small donation, conservation-minded individuals can play a direct role in helping us save this species.”

So how can we save an entire species from extinction for less than the purchase price of a new car? 

  • The materials needed will cost $500.
  • The water cooling system needed to maintain and breed these frogs will cost $2000.
  • A keeper to look after these frogs for one year once they have been safely relocated will cost $6000.
  • The fieldwork to locate and remove the frogs from the path of this volcano will cost $6000.
That's it! Then these frogs are safe in captivity while plans are developed to return them to the wild where they belong and out of harms way. And with the holidays just around the corner why not give a very special gift that makes a difference for generations to come?

Together we CAN make a difference.

*Thank you for your symbolic adoption of a Quito rocket frog tadpole: please note that no animals will be sent! Because the real cost of rescuing and raising a Quito rocket frog tadpole exceeds $25, each tadpole may be adopted by multiple people. 
We thank you for your generous support of the Quito rocket frog rapid recovery project. 
--
The Amphibian Survival Alliance (ASA) is the world’s largest partnership for amphibian conservation, formed in response to the decline of frogs, salamanders and caecilians worldwide. Without immediate and coordinated action we stand to lose half of some 7,000 species of amphibians in our lifetimes. The ASA draws on cutting-edge research to protect amphibians and key habitats worldwide, in addition to educating and inspiring the global community to become a part of the amphibian conservation movement. www.amphibians.org

story:
Rapid Steamer is a revolutionary green bulk cooking system that will allow to save money, time and to make an impact in the environment while supporting the cause of feeding the poor.

By using Biomass fuels, Rapid Steamer reduces the fuel costs to a 60% and it will also allow you to cook food 60-70% faster.

Using modest cooking techniques Rapid Steamer can cook healthy food hygienically in a short time (food for 500 individuals in 2 hours).

Steam cooking is considered to be the healthiest way of cooking. The microelements, vitamins and proteins remain on the food after cooking while retaining food taste and color.

It is developed domestically and has been patented by the Government of India.


Biomass is a renewable source of fuel to produce energy. The term refers to organic matter derived from living, or recently living organisms such as plants or plant-based materials which are not used for food.

Rapid Steamer supports the use of firewood, coconut shell briquettes.coconut husk, wood flour, bagasse, shells of cashew nut, rubber seeds and other plant waste can be used as alternative.



Nowadays, high fuel cost and dependency on LPG are major challenges faced on cooking industries as LPG increases the cost of food and those that rely on firewood or coal are prone to major health hazards and cause environmental damages.

There was no technology adaptation that was both eco-friendly, cost-effective and and that helped promote social causes. Until Now.  



Rapid Steamer uses less fuel in a closed combustion compartment and can retain heat for a long time and also emits less smoke. Rapid Steamer is ideal for bulk cooking that too in a short time, at low cost. Also, one can cook in Rapid Steamer for just .60 cent per person. Apart from basic cooking, Rapid Steamer is also available with other technologies which allows preparation of food items, beverages and so on.


Rapid steamer is very easy to use.  Users should fill the chamber with the biomass fuel, close it while cook it to prevent smoke from spreading. When burning the biomass, the boiler will heat water and will generate steam with a minimum amount of water and fuel.  

Rapid Steam allows rapid air flow and will keep the heat inside the chamber for a long time.  The steam will be sent to many vessels and it will just start cooking!



Rapid Steamer is not only a technology, it’s an efficient weapon that fights for Social Causes.

Here are some ways in which Rapid Steamer will address some World Problems:

There are 1 million Schools in India that offer Mid Day Meal programs. With Rapid Steamer, the rate of cooking can be brought down to 50-60%, which will be 1/5th of the actual cost.



Rapid Steamer can increase the productivity and profitability of small hotels by saving huge costs of LPG while making the entire industry sustainable.



In India, more than 50 Million people are engaged in Street Vending, and it’s carried out in an unhygienic way. Cleanliness of such units and hotels can be improved with Rapid Steamer.



1000s of domestic kitchens across developing and underdeveloped countries are still depending on firewood and Rapid Steamer would make a huge difference in their lives. 




Press Report by The Hindu, the Prominent National News Paper



This campaign aims to raise funds to develop different sizes of Rapid Steamer that helps to have compact units suitable for households and for street vendors, small hotels etc. This would help to reduce the cost, save environment and to make programmes like mid day meal more feasible in developing or under developed countries. 

Technology is already developed, tested and functional in many locations. Now the challenge is to design cooking systems for households, small hotels, street shops, etc. Currently the system developed is only for big hotels and institutions where cooking for 500 + persons a day is happening. Through this campaign and contributions, we would be able to develop three different products and also to cater to all segments of the society. This would help to cut down carbon emission, save cost and also make cooking viable. 

We are looking for developing $ 100000 to do Research & Development and to introduce three models of Rapid Steamer. 


1. Household Model -that can help cooking a small household of 4 to 5 people using Biomass based Steam System and to completely avoid LPG based cooking fuels

2. Compact Mobile Street Kitchen – that can automate the complete cooking of a ordinary street shop- After use they can move away the system ( Biomass based)

3. Unit for Small Hotels- This system can help a hotel to make tea-coffee- rice- curry cooking- breakfast preparation etc

On developing the complete product ranges and implementation, we would be looking at reducing Carbon Emissions, Reducing the dependency over fossil based fuels, Promoting the use of sustainability by using biomass based fuels, cutting down the fuel cost to help bulk cooking as low as .60 cents per meal and making the programmes like Mid day meal cooking more viable - which is existing in developing and under developed countries. 

We will also be setting up Community Kitchen in some of the neglected poor areas as a model project. Parts of funding will be used for this cause. 






Team behind this project has successful implemented many projects such as Akshaya, INE, e Toilet (all are socio- economic- environment friendly projects). Team is lead by Vinod Subramaniam. All the projects are highly successful and together won more than 50 International- National awards/grants/recognitions. Major awards are Gates Foundation RTTC (Reinvent the Toilet Challenge) Grant for eToilet, Nasscom for INE, Sankalp for eToilet, Computer Society of India award for e toilet, Fast Company Award for eToilet, Prime Minister's Swatch Bharath Award for eToilet, Ministry's of Commerce Award for Best Innovation for e Toilet, National Water & Sanitation Award for eToilet, IIM Ahmadabad Best Business Plan award for Video Analytics Solution etc.

News Stories on Team

http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/variety/toilet-train/article4074703.ece

http://www.rediff.com/business/slide-show/slide-show-1-special-interesting-story-of-indias-first-e-toilet/20111216.htm

http://www.gatesfoundation.org/media-center/press-releases/2012/08/bill-gates-names-winners-of-the-reinvent-the-toilet-challenge


1.  What is Rapid Steamer?

Rapid Steamer is an eco-friendly steam-based cooking technology that can be used for bulk cooking at the fuel consumption rate of just .60 cent per person using coconut shell,  coconut husk or briquettes of solid wastes (bio-fuels can also be used) .

Using modest cooking techniques rapid steamer can cook hygienic and healthy food in a short time (food for 500 individuals in 2 hours). It is developed domestically and has been patented by the Government of India.

2.  What are the differences between rapid steamer and the steamers currently available in the market, their advantages and disadvantages?

Two types of steamers are available in the market. One which works on LPG and the other using firewood or coconut shells. LPG-based steamers won't be as economical. Even those steamers that use coconut shell or firewood would need large quantity of the fuel because of continuous and open combustion, high smoke emission and space constraints for storing fuel apart.

While, Rapid Steamer uses less fuel in a closed combustion compartment and can retain heat for a long time and also emits less smoke. Rapid Steamer is ideal for bulk cooking that too in a short time, at low cost. Also, one can cook in Rapid Steamer for just .60 cent per person. Apart from basic cooking, Rapid Steamer is also available with other technologies which allows preparation of food items, beverages and so on. 

3.  Is solar steamer technology available?

Steamers which work on solar energy are available. Cost of ownership of solar steamers that can prepare food for about 500 people would be rather expensive and can go up to $ 8000 per steamer and will not be fuel efficient for all.

4.  What if firewood or coconut shells are not available?

Instead of firewood and coconut shell briquettes of coconut husk, wood flour, bagasse, shells of cashew nut, rubber seeds and other plant waste can be used as alternative. Briquettes are available at very low cost in the market. Use of these briquettes may not be economical in regular steamers.

5.  What are the fuel options that can produce large amount of heat?

Amount of heat depends on the calorie value of available fuel options in the market. For example, tamarind wood, coconut shells, coal and so on have a calorie value of more than 5000 and therefore, it can generate a lot of heat even with less fuel. If fuel options with less calorie value is used its quantity will have to be increased.

6.  Are two hours enough to prepare food for 500 individuals at the rate of .60 cent per person?

Yes, this is achievable if Rapid Steamer worked in favorable conditions. Cooking on Rapid Steamer once everything is ready will help us utilize the steam beneficially. It takes only fifteen minutes to cook pulses such as green gram, black gram and so on if they are soaked well otherwise it may take up to 30-40 minutes. Also, it would take only 15 minutes to cook good quality rice and takes up to 30-40 minutes to cook low quality rice. Since we use different vessels to cook simultaneously cooking gets done in 2 hours. If Rapid Steamer is used in the ideal manner its expense will only come up to .60 cent per person. Several government agencies and associations have approved Rapid Steamer.

7.  What is more effective, coconut shell or husk?

Coconut shells are good for quick combustion. Water starts boiling when 50 coconut shells are used and later husk, firewood and other such fuel alternatives can be used. Compared to coconut shells, coconut husks are available at a lower price. Once combustion starts coconut husk should be used.

8.  What is the technology used in Rapid Steamer? Is this an approved technology?

Using natural air drafting technology Rapid Steamer can absorb air and this absorbed air will help rotate the heat through a particular cabin. This is the peculiarity of Rapid Steamer as this technology is not available in other steamers. The product has been patented by the Government of India. Indian Institute of Technology- Mumbai has verified this patented technology. Kudumbashree units of the Kerala Government have tested Rapid Steamer. This evaluation and analysis of the Rapid Steamer has proved that it can function at the mere cost of .60 cent per individual. The Kerala State Education Department has set up the Rapid Steamer and it is working at just below .60 cent per person. Many cooking related agencies such as Kerala Hotels and Restaurant Associations, Kerala Auditorium Association and Kerala Catering Associations have also testified this claim.

9.  How much smoke or ash is emitted by the Rapid Steamer?

Since the Rapid Steamer needs only a small amount of fuel the amount of ash residue is less. Excess ash falls into the tray which is placed below the cabin. The smoke emitted as a result of combustion is released through the exhaust pipe.

10.  The rate of fuel consumption is at .60 cent per person in the Rapid Steamer. On what basis is this calculated?

For preparing food for 500 individuals 500 coconut shells are used. One kilo coconut shell would have 17 coconut shells. Therefore 500 coconut shells would be around 29 kilos. 1 kilo coconut shell is available at 1/ 6th of a USD. Therefore, to prepare food for 500 individuals $ 4 would be spent which means less than .60 cent an individual. One coconut husk costs only .40 cent and if we used husk as fuel then the rate will go down further. So will it for other briquettes.

11.  Can you cook in a Rapid Steamer for 50 individuals that is usually used to cook food for 500 individuals? What will be the expense?

Yes, it is possible. But to heat the boiler a particular amount of fuel is needed which is equal to the fuel needed to cook food for 500 individuals. So, to prepare food for 50 individuals it is better to use a Rapid Steamer of low capacity.

12.  Is it safe to use Rapid Steamer?

Rapid steamer does not come under the Boiler Act. If the steam exceeds 15 PSI it will act just like a pressure cooker. To cook, steam of 10-15 PSI is enough. Like other steamers, Rapid Steamer is built using iron of 6-8 mm thickness. The vessels of Rapid Steamer have the capacity to withstand 35-40 PSI.

13.  How does a Rapid Steamer work?

Burn coconut shell/firewood in the NAD ( Natural Air Drafting) chamber.Ensure that the boiler has enough water. After 30 minutes steam is formed in the boiler. The steam thus formed reaches different cooking vessels through the insulated pipe lines.

Facilities are available for the opening and closing of the vessels.  Start cooking when the steam reaches 15 PSI in the meter. If it exceeds 15 PSI it opens on its own and the heat is maintained. If steam exceeds 15 PSI, do not use coconut shells or firewood and when it is below 15 PSI use shells and firewood through the side chambers. Special PSI meter is fixed on the steamer. Usually there will be steam in the steamer even after cooking. We can release the steam if further cooking is not required.

14.  Is Rapid Steamer manufactured in a fixed size?

Rapid Steamer of different sizes and needs are available. Based on the requirements of clients different boilers and cooking vessels are available. But we need to do the R&D for small units for households, small hotels etc and we are now trying to develop such models. There are design challenges when the system is becoming compact, R&D has lot many challenges.

15.  What is the cost of a Rapid Steamer?What are the specific instruments available, presently?

The rate of the instruments range between $ 2000 to $ 8000. These are available for various purposes. Among these steamers there are instruments for making many food items. 

16.  Is it healthier to cook food using steam?

Steam cooking is an old method. The micro elements, vitamins and all other proteins remain in the food even after cooking. Also, it retains much of the taste and colour of the food.Since cooking is done in 212 Fahrenheit the proteins and other nutrients will remain in the food. Steam cooking preserves more nutrients and is way healthier.

17.  Is coconut shell available in abundance?

In Kerala, As of now only 30% of coconut trees are being used and in an area of 1.935 million hectares 12,833 million coconuts are being produced. If the entire lot of husk and shells are used 3.8 billion gasoline will be produced. In other words 14000 crore litres of petroleum is being consumed.  But if the whole husk and coconut shells are used we can produce 380 crore litres of petroleum. This is the case with many tropical areas, South East Asian Countries, Africa etc

18.  How eco-friendly is Rapid Steamer?

It should always be such that the fuel used in Rapid Steamer is type of a bio waste. Coal, firewood and such fuels should be avoided. This should bring down the usage of LPG and other fossil fuels. Since Rapid Steamer uses coconut husk, coconut shells and other low sulfur emitting materials it is an eco-friendly instrument.

19.  What is the area required to place a working Rapid Steamer?

Depending on the size and number of steamers,the area varies from 100 sq. ft. to 500 sq.ft.

20.  What goes into the manufacturing of a Rapid Steamer?

Both the boiler and the NAD base of the Rapid Steamer are steel-based. Cooking units are made in stainless steel.

21.  Can Rapid Steamer work on an ordinary steamer?

Yes, but it is not encouraged.

22.  For how long can the Rapid Steamer be put to work in a day?

There is no restrictions on the usage duration of the Rapid Steamer.

23. What could be the possible reason if a Rapid Steamer stopped working for over a month?

The steamer should be cleaned out regularly and the water in the boiler should be replaced.

23.  What are the after-sales services offered to clients by Rapid Steamer?

In case of any manufacturing defect, Paschim Biospace will offer free service for one year. From the very next year Annual Maintenance Contract service will be available at 8% of the basic value of the machines. Service assistants or executives will be present in every district to attend to service needs.

24.  Are there any loans or subsidies available for the purchase of Rapid Steamer?

Kudumbashree- Govt of Kerala offers a 30-35% subsidy on the Rapid Steamer through many schemes. Long-term loans too are available for purchases from the public sector banks.

25.  Can the Rapid Steamer be moved from its initial installation space to another without much hassle?

Of course, you can move the steamer as per your requirements,but certain safety precautions should be in place considering the weight of the steamer.

26.  Is there any insurance cover for the Rapid Steamer?

Yes, the National Insurance Company ( Govt of India) gives an insurance cover of $ 20 per year.

27.  Can Rapid Steamer work on LPG?

Yes, but it is optional and not encouraging the usage.

28.  What is the warranty period offered by Rapid Steamer?

Rapid steamer, as such is damage-proofed in its built and yet the company gives a free warranty of up to a year.

29.  How many litres of water is used in a Rapid Steamer (for 500 individuals)?

In order to cook for 500 individuals, boiler with the capacity of 200 litres of water is used and 100 litres of water is enough to serve 500 people.

30.  Is Rapid Steamer labour-intensive (for  500 individuals) ?

Rapid Steamer is the antithesis of labour-intensive. All it takes is one person.

31.  Who owns Rapid Steamer?

Rapid Steamer is owned by the India based Paschim Biospace Research  Parks (P) Ltd.
story_txt:
Rapid Steamer is a revolutionary green bulk cooking system that will allow to save money, time and to make an impact in the environment while supporting the cause of feeding the poor.
By using Biomass fuels, Rapid Steamer reduces the fuel costs to a 60% and it will also allow you to cook food 60-70% faster.Using modest cooking techniques Rapid Steamer can cook healthy food hygienically in a short time (food for 500 individuals in 2 hours).Steam cooking is considered to be the healthiest way of cooking. The microelements, vitamins and proteins remain on the food after cooking while retaining food taste and color. It is developed domestically and has been patented by the Government of India.Biomass is a renewable source of fuel to produce energy. The term refers to organic matter derived from living, or recently living organisms such as plants or plant-based materials which are not used for food.Rapid Steamer supports the use of firewood, coconut shell briquettes.coconut husk, wood flour, bagasse, shells of cashew nut, rubber seeds and other plant waste can be used as alternative.
Nowadays, high fuel cost and dependency on LPG are major challenges faced on cooking industries as LPG increases the cost of food and those that rely on firewood or coal are prone to major health hazards and cause environmental damages.
There was no technology adaptation that was both eco-friendly, cost-effective and and that helped promote social causes. Until Now.  



Rapid Steamer uses less fuel in a closed combustion compartment and can retain heat for a long time and also emits less smoke. Rapid Steamer is ideal for bulk cooking that too in a short time, at low cost. Also, one can cook in Rapid Steamer for just .60 cent per person. Apart from basic cooking, Rapid Steamer is also available with other technologies which allows preparation of food items, beverages and so on. 

Rapid steamer is very easy to use.  Users should fill the chamber with the biomass fuel, close it while cook it to prevent smoke from spreading. When burning the biomass, the boiler will heat water and will generate steam with a minimum amount of water and fuel.  


Rapid Steam allows rapid air flow and will keep the heat inside the chamber for a long time.  The steam will be sent to many vessels and it will just start cooking!









Rapid Steamer is not only a technology, it’s an efficient weapon that fights for Social Causes.
Here are some ways in which Rapid Steamer will address some World Problems:
There are 1 million Schools in India that offer Mid Day Meal programs. With Rapid Steamer, the rate of cooking can be brought down to 50-60%, which will be 1/5th of the actual cost.



Rapid Steamer can increase the productivity and profitability of small hotels by saving huge costs of LPG while making the entire industry sustainable. 


In India, more than 50 Million people are engaged in Street Vending, and it’s carried out in an unhygienic way. Cleanliness of such units and hotels can be improved with Rapid Steamer. 

1000s of domestic kitchens across developing and underdeveloped countries are still depending on firewood and Rapid Steamer would make a huge difference in their lives. 

Press Report by The Hindu, the Prominent National News Paper


This campaign aims to raise funds to develop different sizes of Rapid Steamer that helps to have compact units suitable for households and for street vendors, small hotels etc. This would help to reduce the cost, save environment and to make programmes like mid day meal more feasible in developing or under developed countries. 
Technology is already developed, tested and functional in many locations. Now the challenge is to design cooking systems for households, small hotels, street shops, etc. Currently the system developed is only for big hotels and institutions where cooking for 500 + persons a day is happening. Through this campaign and contributions, we would be able to develop three different products and also to cater to all segments of the society. This would help to cut down carbon emission, save cost and also make cooking viable. 
We are looking for developing $ 100000 to do Research & Development and to introduce three models of Rapid Steamer. 



1. Household Model -that can help cooking a small household of 4 to 5 people using Biomass based Steam System and to completely avoid LPG based cooking fuels


2. Compact Mobile Street Kitchen – that can automate the complete cooking of a ordinary street shop- After use they can move away the system ( Biomass based)



3. Unit for Small Hotels- This system can help a hotel to make tea-coffee- rice- curry cooking- breakfast preparation etc


On developing the complete product ranges and implementation, we would be looking at reducing Carbon Emissions, Reducing the dependency over fossil based fuels, Promoting the use of sustainability by using biomass based fuels, cutting down the fuel cost to help bulk cooking as low as .60 cents per meal and making the programmes like Mid day meal cooking more viable - which is existing in developing and under developed countries. 
We will also be setting up Community Kitchen in some of the neglected poor areas as a model project. Parts of funding will be used for this cause. 











Team behind this project has successful
implemented many projects such as Akshaya, INE, e Toilet (all are socio-
economic- environment friendly projects). Team is lead by Vinod Subramaniam.
All the projects are highly successful and together won more than 50
International- National awards/grants/recognitions. Major awards are Gates
Foundation RTTC (Reinvent the Toilet Challenge) Grant for eToilet, Nasscom for
INE, Sankalp for eToilet, Computer Society of India award for e toilet, Fast
Company Award for eToilet, Prime Minister's Swatch Bharath Award for eToilet,
Ministry's of Commerce Award for Best Innovation for e Toilet, National Water
& Sanitation Award for eToilet, IIM Ahmadabad Best Business Plan award for
Video Analytics Solution etc.

Stories on Team

http://www.rediff.com/business/slide-show/slide-show-1-special-interesting-story-of-indias-first-e-toilet/20111216.htm

of solid wastes (bio-fuels can also be used) . 
Using
modest cooking techniques rapid steamer can cook hygienic and healthy food in a
short time (food for 500 individuals in 2 hours). It is developed domestically
and has been patented by the Government of India.
2.

are the differences between rapid steamer and the steamers currently available
in the market, their advantages and disadvantages?
Two

other using firewood or coconut shells. LPG-based steamers won't be as
economical. Even those steamers that use coconut shell or firewood would need
large quantity of the fuel because of continuous and open combustion, high
smoke emission and space constraints for storing fuel apart.
While,
Rapid Steamer uses less fuel in a closed combustion compartment and can retain
heat for a long time and also emits less smoke. Rapid Steamer is ideal for bulk
cooking that too in a short time, at low cost. Also, one can cook in Rapid

is also available with other technologies which allows preparation of food items, beverages and so on.

solar steamer technology available?
Steamers

story:
2015 History

In 2015 we released a 13 episode home-based, grass roots, boot-strapped documentary series titled The Search for Sustainability where we traveled the United States and interviewed 49 experts on sustainability.

Within only a couple of months the series had received over 150,000 views and thousands of positive comments pouring in.

It was a fantastic success and we helped a lot of people and were able to get reimbursed for our efforts in getting the series out to the public.

2016 Improvements

In 2015 we heard that so many people loved the series, we knew we had to do it again.  We also heard that people wanted it to be more professionally edited, better music, and more practical how-to stuff added in.

So now in 2016, we are traveling the globe to see what other countries and territories like Costa Rica, Hawaii, Europe, Canada, and Australia are doing to live more sustainably, self-reliant, and closer to the land.

We are also planning to improve the sound, music, and editing with graphics and animation so it is not only informative and inspiring, but engaging visually and auditorialy. 

This is why we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we need to make this happen at a professional level:

  • $11,000 for editing
  • $7,500 for graphics and animation
  • $17,500 for travel, cinematography, and sound

All of the awesome perks are available on the right side of this page.  Check them out to see what you like best and we're very grateful to have your support to help make this important global initiative happen.

The Impact

Most of the world is struggling economically, ecologically, politically, healthily, and socially - this series will:

  • Empower you to live with more health, vibrancy, and longevity
  • Live more sustainably and closer to the land
  • Create meaningful connections in your local community
  • Bring struggling countries together to work towards a common cause
  • Experience a sense of true freedom by having independence, interdependence, and self-reliance
  • Teach sustainable food, water, and medicine practices
  • Uplift economies to implement sustainable systematic changes
  • Reveal political and social changes to globally impact our local economies
  • And a lot more!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please share this campaign on Facebook and twitter.
  • Send an email to your 3 closest friends and ask them to support.
  • Watch episode 1 from The 2015 Search for Sustainability series and get inspired to make a change: http://thesearchforsustainability.com/

And that's all there is to it.

Extended Goal - Translate to 7 Languages

In an effort to get this life-saving information out to as many people as possible around the world, we envision translating the entire series into at least 7 major languages.

This will allow the information to be disseminated to the largest number of people worldwide.

With your help we know we can make this happen.

Please support the campaign today.
