story:
At a glance:

A proposed new road along the border of Peru’s Manu National Park, in the heart of the Amazon rainforest, is an environmental disaster waiting to happen—a new road in this region would open up vast tracts of pristine rainforest to illegal loggers, lead to the loss of biodiversity and wildlife habitat, and increase greenhouse gas emissions.

We want to conduct a study to outline the negative consequences of this ill-conceived road and offer policy-makers alternatives that are friendlier to local people and the environment.

The Manu Road cuts right through the jungle: the current road is shown in solid red, dashed red line is the proposed road extension.

The ‘Manu Road’ project: background

Manu National Park is the biodiversity gem in Peru’s network of protected areas—more species of plants and animals can be found here than almost any other place on the planet. Just a few hectares (1 ha=2.5 acres) of tropical rainforest in Manu, for example, contain more species of tree than all of northern Europe. The Manu region is also a hotspot for butterfly diversity: working at one site within the park and another in the nearby Tambopata National Reserve, Peruvian researchers have identified over 1,500 species. Compare that to fewer than 800 butterflies in all of North America!

Historically, the Manu region’s isolation has kept it relatively safe from the effects of illegal logging, agriculture, gold mining, and rampant colonization that have devastated other forested areas in Peru. The construction of the so-called ‘Manu Road,’ however, which began in the 1960s and which traverses the area bordering the National Park, has vastly increased access to the region. The colonist population along the road and in adjacent areas has grown as a result, and with the increased human population has come increased pressure on the region’s natural resources. Conflicts with local indigenous groups, some of which still live in voluntary isolation inside the rainforest, are also increasingly making headlines as these people flee loggers and other intruders to their territories, as well as the disease and deforestation they often leave behind.

Now, economic interests are pushing for further road construction and aim to extend the road to Boca Manu, at the mouth of the Manu River and the entrance to the core area of the National Park. If this happens, illegal loggers and a likely flood of new colonists will gain access to immense areas of untouched rainforest and, if the results of new road construction elsewhere in Amazonia—including along the current length of the Manu Road itself—are any guide, a frenzy of deforestation and resource extraction will continue to erode the biological integrity of the National Park. Together, the direct and indirect consequences of road expansion in and around Manu may mean the beginning of the decline of the park as the greatest reservoir of biodiversity the world has ever known.

What will we do?

Our goals are threefold:

1. We will write an article aimed at scientists, conservationists, and Peruvian policy-makers that will highlight the Manu Road and its negative environmental and social consequences.

The article will begin with a discussion of the history of the road’s construction to the present date, as well as its proposed extension. We will summarize the negative impacts of the road that have already occurred, and we will model potential future impacts if the road is expanded. These impacts include land use changes (i.e., deforestation), the loss of biodiversity and wildlife habitat, and greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation. We will end the article with a series of suggestions to achieve the stated goals of road expansion by other, more environmentally-friendly and cost-effective means. These might include increased investment in the local river transport network, or more money for schools and medical facilities.

2. Our Peruvian undergraduate researcher, Gustavo Larrea Gallegos, will use data gathered from the field to quantify the direct impacts of road construction using Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) techniques. This analysis will form the backbone of Gustavo’s undergraduate thesis.

3. Finally, we will conduct a social media campaign designed to share our findings with the general public within Peru and abroad, to spread awareness of this issue and the negative consequences of road expansion, and to foster support for more environmentally-friendly alternatives to new construction.

Who are we?

Geoff Gallice, PhD. Geoff recently obtained his PhD in Entomology (study of insects) at the University of Florida, where he studied the ecology and conservation of butterflies in the Amazon rainforest, as well as other pressing issues in tropical ecology and conservation.

Ian Vázquez-Rowe, PhD. Holds his doctorate in Chemical and Environmental Engineering. Ian is currently a professor at the Catholic University in Lima, Peru, where he is an expert in Life Cycle Assessment and other environmental management tools such as Carbon Footprint Analysis.

Gustavo Larrea Gallegos. Gustavo is an undergraduate student studying Civil Engineering at the Catholic University in Lima. He will be performing most of the field work as part of his undergraduate thesis project.

Isabel Quispe Trinidad. Holds a Master’s degree in Industrial Engineering. Isabel is the coordinator of the Peruvian Life Cycle Assessment Network and the main coordinator of the Manu Road project.

What do we need?

We are not looking for salaries here. Instead, we only want to cover the costs of traveling to the Manu study area from Lima to conduct interviews with local stakeholders and to gather the data needed to assess the direct environmental impacts of road construction.

Roughly US$3,000 will cover all of our costs, a bargain considering the urgency of the issue and the impact our study will have. This amount will cover all of the following:

  1. $750—Domestic airfare (Lima-Cusco) for our three team members
  2. $600—Local transport in the Manu area (transport here is slow and costly)
  3. $700—Lodging and food
  4. $310—Local guide, seven days
  5. $440—Equipment (e.g., hand-held GPS device) and misc. supplies (e.g., first-aid, rubber boots for rainforest mud, etc.)
  6. $200—Publishing expenses

What do you get in return for your financial support?

We plan to make the results of our project as visible to the general public as possible. However, our contributors will be the VIP public that will receive detailed information first about our field work and findings.

Please also see some of the cool perks you can receive by donating!!

I cannot support the project financially. How else can I help?

No problem! You can also help us sharing the project on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter or any other social network. By sharing and endorsing our project you can help us find other backers. Please help us get the word out!

In summary...

Roads mean the death of a rainforest, and we need your help to prevent this from happening in Manu. With your support, we will spread awareness of the negative impacts of new road construction in the Manu region and highlight healthy alternatives that do not destroy the environment or the cultural integrity of the rainforest's indigenous inhabitants. We also hope that our study will serve as an example for others working elsewhere, in other rainforest areas facing similar challenges. Together, let’s save Manu!

construction.
Roughly US$3,000 will cover all
of our costs, a bargain considering the urgency of the issue and the impact our study will have. This amount
will cover all of the following:


$750—Domestic airfare
(Lima-Cusco) for our three team members


$600—Local transport in the Manu
area (transport here is slow and costly)


$700—Lodging and food


$310—Local guide, seven days


$440—Equipment (e.g., hand-held
GPS device) and misc. supplies (e.g., first-aid, rubber boots for rainforest
mud, etc.)


$200—Publishing expenses


What do you get in return for your financial support?
We plan to make the results of
our project as visible to the general public as possible. However, our
contributors will be the VIP public that will receive detailed information
first about our field work and findings.
Please also see some of the cool perks you can receive by donating!!
I cannot support the project
financially. How else can I help?

No problem! You can also help us sharing the project on Facebook,
Instagram, Twitter or any other social network. By sharing and endorsing our project you can help us find other backers. Please help us get the word
out!In summary...Roads mean the death of a rainforest, and we need your help to prevent this from happening in Manu. With your support, we will spread awareness of the negative impacts of new road construction in the Manu region and highlight healthy alternatives that do not destroy the environment or the cultural integrity of the rainforest's indigenous inhabitants. We also hope that our study will serve as an example for others working elsewhere, in other rainforest areas facing similar challenges. Together, let’s save Manu!

story:
Once a stray in a high-kill shelter about to be euthanized, Truman was sick, hungry, and had no hope. Now he has a new life, a new home, and a new job.

He is training to be my PTSD service dog.

From the moment I met Truman (not his name at the time) I knew he was a gift beyond words. He ran up to me and leaned into my legs. At that moment we both knew we were meant to be together.

With the help of supporters I was able to pay Truman’s rescue fees and get him started in his training program with 3K9 Working Dogs. But we need your help. We still need to raise about $2000 to pay for the rest of his training.

So much more than a family pet, although they are amazing, Truman will give me life. He will be trained specifically to deal with the issues that impact me on a daily basis, the issues that hold me back and keep me from living the life I am created to live.

He will be trained to do pressure therapy, interrupt panic attacks, interrupt night terrors, provide crowd control, and be a rear-facing guard. For specifics on each of these tasks, as well as my journey with PTSD please visit my website here.

Truman’s Diary

Truman is publishing a diary on his journey from the shelter through Service Dog School and beyond. You can read what he has to say about his new life here.

As a bonus, you’ll read about which movie star he embodies.

Updates

I have been publishing updates on his progress, including pictures, as well. You can read those here. (Scroll to the bottom of the page.)

What the 3K9 Working Dogs Trainers are Saying

In talking about his progress, Allie said, “What a guy!”

Michelle says he loves walks, especially in nature and is the poster child for a “velcro dog.” She says he also has a great “happy no matter what” personality. (He is perfect for me!)

Michelle also says, “Truman is doing amazing. His confidence has grown tremendously and he is progressing through all obedience commands. I hope to begin task [training] next Monday.” (Because he had been a stray he was an empty slate and had to start with the basics. Task training encompasses the things I mentioned above that he will be doing specifically for me.)

And the praise continues to roll in.

To Learn More

To learn more about me and my life visit StephanieHester.com

For specific information on how PTSD has impacted my life visit my blog and search PTSD. Here are a few of the more popular topics:

An Open Letter to My Stalker … PTSD

PTSD: Not Just a Soldier’s Fight

PTSD and Faith

To view my PTSD Artwork visit my website or my Pinterest board.

Thank You

Truly there are no words to thank you for your support and encouragement. To say that Truman will be a blessing is an understatement. In the time I’ve been able to spend with him I have been so blessed. As, I believe, has he. Here is a short video we took at the shelter shortly after we met.

story:
Introducing

(Eco Friendly) FreeFracking


Chemical + Water Free Fracking System

With all of the recent headlines regarding the carelessness of the federal
government in regard to the inadequate and irresponsible regulation of
fracking practices (along with current oil and gas practices), Colorado native
Dennis Cortese innovated a solution and is eager to partner with local,
nationwide and global environmental organizations.


After years of research and development, Mr. Cortese has developed a method he
has coined ‘Free Fracking’, utilizing only a vacuum pump with a special augur
to draw out desired materials from the ground without the use of water, harsh,
dangerous chemicals, giving off no odor.



The Implications


70 to 140 billion gallons of water used to fracture 35,000 wells in the U.S
alone each year would be saved


Chemicals make up 330 tons (0.5 to 2%) of fracturing fluid


Statistics courtesy of
premierfoundationrepair.com


This system promotes water conservation and ends groundwater contamination.
His system functions with minimal operator risk, unlike current fracking
methods in use.



 

Our team of oil experts are on board with the public outcry to give control to
local governments to regulate gas and oil development and are ready to start
with Colorado, expanding to the rest of the country and the world.


All we need is your help to get this message in front of the correct
environmental organizations as well as local, state and federal government
officials to establish a partnership and begin the manufacturing and
implementation process.



Please visit these websites for more insight and information:


Inventor websiteswww.freefracking.comwww.theinventorsdepot.com

Dangers of Fracking (Informative website)www.dangersoffracking.com

Article, The Colorado Statesman: ‘Oil and Gas Regulation Fracturing
Relationships'www.coloradostatesman.com/content/994680-oil-and-gas-regulation-fracturing-relationships


Images Courtesy of:


www.sierra club.orgwww.premierfoundationrepair.com


Help Us Meet Our Goal of Becoming a Not-for-Profit
Organization



Thanks for Your Support!



If you are unable to donate, please spread the word! Share our link, our message and our campaign via word of mouth, our
Fundanything link and your social media page

story:
A Snapshot of the Plight

             of Congolese Women

It has been said that it is more dangerous to be a woman in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Republic of Congo than it is to be a soldier. The threat of violence of both of a sexual and non-sexual nature is constant, it is estimated that since the year 2000 over 2 million women have been raped in The DR Congo alone. The idea of women being inferior to men has always been embedded in the indigenous social system of both countries and reemphasized through current times. Women face many obstacles from birth and are often not allowed to access to an education which continues the cycle of violence and prohibits women’s growth in society and maintains the violent patriarchalcycle.

Many times Congolese women are continued to be held back by the misogynist teachings of society even if they leave their home country. Women from both the Democratic Republic of Congo the Republic of Congo are in need of empowered female role models to look up to and a historic opportunity has presented itself and we need your support.


                                  What is the
                           Miss Earth Pageant?

MISS EARTH is an annual international beauty pageant that emphasizes environmental awareness and conservation. The titleholders dedicate their year to promote protection of the environment and other global issues. The winner of MISS EARTH is the spokesperson for the United Nations Environment Programme and THE MISS EARTH FOUNDATION. The annual competition is televised in over 189 countries.


                        A Historical Opportunity

In years past over 85 countries have had representation in the MISS EARTH PAGEANT; 2015 will be the first year that both the Democratic Republic of Congo at the Republic of Congo will be represented at the Pageant. This is a historic opportunity for the people of both countries and the girls that will be representing!

Not only will the pageant allow these young women to represent both the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Republic of Congo on the global stage but it will give them the opportunity to grow through self-empowerment and become a role model to other young women both in their home countries and abroad. It will also give them the opportunity to spread the word of peace and proper conservation techniques to the people of both countries. These young women will also show the diverse beauty and tenacity of Congolese women.

We cannot give these women the opportunity of a lifetime without your financial support.


What We Need & What You Get

To be able to represent the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Republic of Congo on the international stage we must first host a qualifying pageant. With the bare minimum money of $5,000 raised from this campaign we will be able to cover the costs for the first National MISS EARTH Congo Pageant and Fashion Show.

The Pageant will be held from JULY 28th 2015 to AUGUST 1st 2015 at the Ritz Raleigh in Raleigh North Carolina.

There’s just one problem do to unfortunate situations and with sponsors, we need to fund the pageant ourselves. Now, we are reaching out to you, our friends on the internet in our time of need!

And because we love to thank our friends, we have thought of you every step of the way!

WE HERE AT MISS EARTH ARE BIG THINKERS!

So we wanted to give you, our loyal internet friends a sneak peak of the things we have planned!

With $5,000 and beyond we can take the Miss Earth Congo to the next level!  We have big plans for this pageant and we would love to share them with you! So, take a sneak peak of some of our stretch goals, overfunding plans, and bonus perks!

• The ability to hire people who can take this pageant to the next level through media, marketing and mogul skills.

• Security, with a pageant this epic we need some authority figures on hand!

• Flashier sets, effects, and pyrotechnics.

-Even more glamorous jewelry and accessories on the girls!

• Cameos and performances from hot celebrities…Can you say Maroon 5?? Because we can!

• More exclusive access packages that features YOU.

• More full time workers, to keep everyone having the time of their lives!

AND MOST IMPORTANTLY….

More fun for YOU (Most of our perk packages let you see your event in action. Take advantage of it!!!)

If you help us get this historic pageant made today, you won’t have to pay again to see the pageant live and in person. When you contribute to this event it will go directly to making the pageant EPIC! No one’s pockets will be getting fuller from this event.  Why would you want to wait and fight the public for tickets?

PLEDGE NOW! And make sure you share this campaign with YOUR internet friends!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about the Miss Earth Congo Peace Pageant 2015 campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

Thank you for being on this journey with us! We are looking forward to having you with us every step of the way!

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
My name is Geshe Choekhortshang Rinpoche (Nyima Woser). I am a Bonpo monk currently teaching at Charles University in Prague. This campaign is on behalf of my friend Lama Tsering Norbu in Ghiling village, Upper Mustang.

Tsering Norbu hails from a lineage of famous Bonpo astrologers in Mustang. His entire family plays a crucial role in the life of the local Bon community through astrology, healing rituals, and acting as a spiritual guide. His family has served the Bon community of Ghiling in this way for literally generations. Lama Tsering Norbu studied in Menri monastery and Saranath University in Benares, India. 

On April 25, 2015, Tsering Norbu's house was destroyed in the earthquake that hit Nepal this year. Tsering Norbu needs funding in order to rebuild his house, not only for himself, but for his family. At the current time, they are living in tents.

Tsering Norbu's residence is a historical Bonpo building of considerable importance. The foundations of the house date back many hundreds of years, and the house embodies the traditional Tibetan-style architecture of the Upper Mustang region. The house as well serves as a repository for many dozens of precious ritual artefacts which have been preserved by Tsering's family.

As the most highly educated person in his village, Tsering has been entrusted with overseeing all of the local earthquake relief efforts. Therefore, he has no time to attend to his own reconstruction needs. It is for this reason that I have decided to commence this fundraising campaign, so that his focus may fully remain on helping his community.

I greatly hope that you might be able to assist in the rebuilding of this historical Bonpo residence in Upper Mustang. I offer my heartfelt thanks in advance.

story:
Safely Eliminate Gray Hair!

Gray 2 Natural is the simple, safe, and effective way to recapture the hair color of your youth.  Just add the all-natural Gray 2 supplements to your regular diet and in 90 days or less, your natural, youthful hair color will shine through again, free of ugly gray!  Guaranteed!

Worried about side effects?  Check these out:

  • Boost Your Immune System
  • Glowing Hair, Skin, and Nails
  • Abundant Energy and Vitality

...just to name a few!

My name is Sarah Weinstein and I am the Founder of Sarbo Health.  I love helping people bring back their natural hair color in a safe manner! 

Years ago, my child was diagnosed with cancer.  I would have done anything at that time to find a healthy cure.  During my research and studies, I came across an interesting discovery. 

There is a little-known enzyme, called the catalase enzyme that functions to maintain a healthy balance of naturally occurring hydrogen peroxide in the body.

Gray hair more rapidly occurs when a deficiency of this essential catalase enzyme allows hydrogen peroxide build-up, bleaching our hair to gray. The body's ability to produce this enzyme deteriorates with age. 

I hate when I see people using hair products loaded with chemicals that harm the body and damage the hair and scalp. It does not have to be this way!

Among some harmful impacts from a chemical in most hair dyes, is that it may cause dermatitis and breathing difficulties.

Some doctors state that the permanent dark hair colors may contribute to development of a cancer of the blood, and eats away bone.

My breakthrough product, "Gray 2 Natural" is a safe and effective way to reverse the graying process. 

Quick Facts:

  • Get back the healthy, natural hair color of your youth!
  • An affordable way to improve your overall health and appearance.
  • Eliminate the use of harsh and unsafe chemicals in your body.
  • Adopt an environmentally friendly solution for your hair care needs.



Does It Really Work?

Most people see measurable results in the first 90 days!:

  • New hair sprouts will emerge starting at the bottom, in your original, natural color!
  • You'll look and feel better, too!.

The Impact

You'll be doing your part to eliminate unnecessary pollutants both in your body and in the environment:

  • Billions of toxic hair dyes are being washed down the drain every day.
  • Toxins ultimately show up in our water supply, our soil, and even in our blood.
  • Switching to Gray 2 Natural is an effective way to make a real impact.
  • Product is carefully tested for purity and safety.       
  • Product is vegetarian


It All Starts With You!

Even if Gray 2 Natural isn't right for you, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Tell your friends about this effective and much-needed product.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!



WHAT I NEED:

If I can reach the funding goal of $9,500, I should have enough to cover costs of supplies, manufacturing, shipping and miscellaneous items.


GRATEFUL

From the funded goal I will donate to the L.A. homeless charity, called Chrysalis.

Helping someone less fortunate gives me a quiet joy. 


I appreciate any donation and even if you didn't, thank you for reading my campaign. 

Health Hint: Some products flavored with raspberry, strawberry derive

this natural flavor from beavers glands, called Beavers Butt Juice.


Sarah Weinstein- CEO/Sarbo Health

story:
THE ISSUE 

The vast freshwater reserves of some of the the largest North American aquifers, spanning across South Dakota, Nebraska, Wyoming, Montana and North Dakota, are URGENTLY THREATENED by the plans of international URANIUM MINING companies seeking to drill unsafe Uranium extraction wells into the ground. 

This scientifically unstable and toxic process will leak RADIOACTIVE Uranium, Arsenic, Selenium, Radium and Lead into the aquifers and POLLUTE SURFACE AND GROUND WATERS PERMANENTLY, rendering these waters toxic to all life and a danger to future generations.  

After mining, the corporations plan to pump the HIGHLY TOXIC wastewater underground into "deep injection pools", threatening the interconnected aquifers in the region -- the Deadwood, Madison, Minnelusa, and Inyan Kara.

In addition to the toxic pollution of our lands,  the extracted Uranium gets shipped abroad and sold on the foreign market for further unsafe use, mainly in China, Russia and India. 


THE CLEAN WATER WARRIORS

The Committee to Protect the Water is based in South Dakota and created by local citizens in response to this CRITICAL ISSUE threatening our water resources. Our purpose is to educate the public and spread awareness about the IMMEDIATE and long-term dangers of these mining activities.

We will not allow corporations profit from pillaging our mineral reserves and sell them to foreign entities who could conceivably create Weapons of Mass Destruction, while simultaneously destroying the precious waters of the Heartland of America.

Now we are committing our time and energy to create solid ways of stopping the destruction of our waters and sustainably protecting this delicate, limited and vital natural resource upon which all our people, ranches and animals depend. 


THE SOLUTION

To solve this serious issue, we must take strong legal action to permanently protect our waters from new mining operations being licensed. 

Right now, we are organizing our amazing team to immediately gather 20,000 local signatures necessary to place an initiative on the ballot for the 2016 elections, so we can PASS A LAW that will permanently protect our waters from irreversible damage. 

Please help us raise $50,000 to activate a strong grassroots campaign and fund this important water protection campaign! 


STANDING TOGETHER 

This threat is also a historic opportunity for all of us to STAND TOGETHER for something that affects us all equally: OUR WATERS OF LIFE. 

We - ranchers and townspeople, Native and white, business owners and teachers, parents and grandparents - have been uniting together in this region for many years to protect our precious waters. 



WHAT YOU CAN DO NOW!

There are many ways YOU CAN HELP US achieve our fundraising goal:

1) DONATE whatever amount you can give towards this plan now! 

[If you can give more than $100, please provide your name and address as this is required by South Dakota campaign laws. Your information will not be shared publicly]


2) Write a comment and SHARE THIS LINK with your friends and family now! Please take a few moments to USE YOUR VOICE and share this info on social media, send an email, text message or make a phone call to share the word and spread this information! 


3) Visit the website of our sister organization for more information on this issue and other ways to take action by lobbying your Congressional representatives at:  www.bhcleanwateralliance.org  


4) Join the Committee to Protect the Water mailing list at: protectthewater16@gmail.com

Or send us your correspondence to:

Committee to Protect the Water, P.O. Box 7831, Rapid City, South Dakota 57709


THANK YOU FOR TAKING ACTION TO PROTECT OUR WATERS. 

TOGETHER WE WILL STOP URANIUM MINING IN OUR WATERS!

story:
Alternatiba Todmorden

Alternatiba Todmorden is a festival of climate alternatives on 3rd May. It will run from 11am until late in various Todmorden venues including the Town Hall and Pollination Street. It will be a fun event for all the family that will show practical ways for everyone to fight climate change. In the town hall there will be an Incredible Conference, speeches, debates, information stalls and a cafe with local sustainable and fair-trade vegan food. On Pollination Street there will be stalls, a polar bear and a puppet show. In pubs and cafes there will be live bands, folk music, poetry and world music DJs.

What We Need & What You Get

We have match funding and the more we raise the more we can put on, to give you an idea of what we will do with the money, if we raise:

  • £100 we can get Honley Samba Band to come and play and we can get Laura Blake and Philip James up from the Centre for Alternative Technology in Wales
  • £250 Honley Samba and Tod Brass Band can play, Laura and Philip can come and we can feed all the volunteers and speakers
  • £600 all of the above and we can have Mr Wilson's Second Liners and decorate the town in bunting made from recycled fabric
  • £1000 all of the above and we can have Handmade Parade bring their flags and fantastical bikes

Festival of Climate Alternatives

We are trying to raise awareness of climate change in the run up to an important summit on the climate in Paris this December. Extreme climatic events like Cyclone Pam or Hurricane Katrina could quickly become the norm if we don't act now to get internationally agreed emissions limits.

  • People can come and learn about ways they can fight climate change
  • We are organising a hustings and we have invited the political parties to be present
  • It will be a fun day out in an Incredible Edible Town

What does Fighting Climate Change Involve?

  • Eating less meat and dairy - fighting climate change is also good for your health
  • Commuting less - which is good for air quality and the environment
  • Buying things locally and using the town centre - which is good for the economy

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Sign up to our newsletter
  • Email us and offer to help out on the day info@altertod.eu
  • Like our FaceBook Page and follow our Twitter

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Wow! 

Thanks to everyone for the amazing support! This campaign has ended, but we are still raising money to build the water wells, and the more we raise the more we can build this year.So please visit our website!

www.GCEarth.org


And in the News!

 This Awesome Guy  is Fighting to Save This IRL Fern Gully


One million acres of pristine rainforest have been conserved on Lac Tumba in the Congo Basin Rainforest. We need your help to keep this land protected while providing clean water, health care, education, and more to the communities living here.


Lac Tumba is a beautiful, life-sustaining, and unspoiled lake in the heart of the Congo Basin Rainforest, the 2nd largest rainforest in the world, second only to the Amazon. The Congo Basin Rainforest has one of the most bio-diverse ecosystems on the planet and is extremely resistant to climate change. Rainforests are the lungs of the earth. They remove tremendous amounts of carbon dioxide from the air while producing great amounts of oxygen, stabilizing Earth's climate.

The Congo Basin Rainforest provides food, shelter, water, and medicine to over 75 million people. Of the hundreds of mammal species discovered in the Congo River Basin so far, 39 are found nowhere else on Earth. Of its estimated 10,000 plant species, 3,300 are unique to the region.

The area around Lac Tumba, and our conservation area specifically, is home to many endangered animals, including bonobos and forest elephants. The endangered bonobo is a very special kind of ape, sharing 98.7% of its DNA with humans and showing profound intelligence and deep emotional capacity. Bonobos are highly endangered and only live in the Democratic Republic of Congo section of the Congo River Basin.



Go Conscious Earth is a U.S. 501(c)3 non-profit organization founded and directed by Godi Godar, who grew up in the Bantomba tribe on Lac Tumba in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). As a child, Godar, the eldest son of the chief of his tribe, dreamed he would move across oceans and return home to support and protect his people. At the age of 21, he moved to the United States. Almost 30 years later, just before her death, Godar’s mother revealed the dire situation of his people and how he could save them. She told him to stop the rainforest destruction that is devastating the lives of his people, killing endangered animals, and ruining the air of our planet.

Since then, Godar and the many volunteers who believe in him and his work have worked tirelessly to do just that. And in 2014, GCE successfully lobbied the DRC government to protect the first one million acres of rainforest on Lac Tumba.

At Go Conscious Earth (GCE), we have developed an approach that preserves large tracts of rainforest while fighting poverty and cultivating long-term sustainable practices within the communities living there. This approach will lead to millions more acres of rainforest conservation.

We have asked the communities there what they need and we are working with them to make that happen - simple projects that work. Freshwater wells, schools, health clinics, sustainable farming and fishing, and long-term income generation. And as we implement our anti-poverty initiatives, we are also in the process of conserving another million acres.



The Congo Basin Rainforest is being destroyed by multinational corporations using it for timber, mineral extraction, and commercial farming. Its destruction threatens to destroy the communities that depend on it, irrevocably harm the global climate, and cause the extinction of many species of wildlife.

Lac Tumba is home to 100,000 indigenous people. All of the people living here live without adequate food, clean water, healthcare, education, electricity, or transportation.  In their efforts to survive and feed their families, they are forced to use unsustainable farming and fishing techniques that harm the rainforest and the lake. They want to preserve their rainforest home, but they need more resources in order to implement alternatives to these practices.




In order for the tribes living here to keep their lands protected, GCE signed an agreement with the DRC government and the indigenous communities, including the Bantomba tribe and Ba'aka pygmy people, to build a sustainable infrastructure. 

If GCE does not reach its goals, the nearly one million acres of rainforest will be returned to the DRC government and would inevitably be sold or leased to corporations that would destroy it.

GCE's commitments to the 40 villages here include:

 - Building 100 water wells

- Building and staffing schools

- Building and staffing health clinics

- Buying a boat to bring in materials and supplies to even the most remote villages

- Building a simple dirt road/path and bridges to facilitate inter-village trading

- Initiating and supporting women's income generation projects

- Initiating and supporting sustainable fishing and farming techniques and programs.

The success of this project not only saves the lives of people and animals but also prove the viability of community-based anti-poverty initiatives to the DRC government, which in turn will allows GCE, and other similar groups, to save more rainforest here in the Congo River Basin. 



Working within the communities on Lac Tumba to protect tribal lands rights helps alleviate poverty and is an extremely effective way to save rainforest.

Your donation will go directly toward providing the resources and infrastructure that fulfill GCE’s commitment and which also empower the local tribes toward sustainable practices and a higher quality of life. GCE needs to break ground on building the water wells this year. To fulfill our promises to the DRC government for 2015, and keep this land protected, we need to buy a boat, buy a well drill and begin building wells.

But this can only happen with your help!


The destruction of the Congo Basin Rainforest harms the communities that depend on it, contributes to the global climate crisis and causes the extinction of wildlife. The future of this rainforest - that has truly astounding biodiversity and bountiful wildlife, that nourishes and supports millions of people, and that regulates Earth's climate and produces much of our oxygen - is depending on you, and your vision and generosity. 

You can help in two ways:

1.  Donate here today! Help us fund this big and challenging, long-term and sustainable project.
2. Spread the word! Tell your friends about this opportunity. Please share our campaign link on Facebook, Twitter and other social media.

Only by working together can we save this beautiful and unique rainforest, home of the Ba'aka pygmy people, the Bantomba tribe, and the endangered Bonobo.
 

From all of us at Go Conscious Earth, thank you for making a difference!

And thank you to our partners and supporting organizations!



$10 – Melesi Moninga!

Melesi moningo means "Thank you friend!" in Lingala, the primary language in the Congo River Basin. Your contribution means so much to the people of this rainforest!

$25 – An acre of rainforest

Every $25 contributed to our organization saves one acre of rainforest! Together we can save this highly diverse rainforest and the people and animals who live here.

$39 - Did you know?

There are 39 known mammal species found only here in the Congo Basin Rainforest and nowhere else in the world! Your donation will help save the lives of all the animals here and keep species like the highly endangered Bonobo and from going extinct by enabling us to keep their home intact. As a thank you from the animals, enjoy an 8 X 10 print of the beautiful Bonobo . Pick from two options, just let us know which one you prefer - 'Bonobo close-up' or 'Bonobo in a tree'.


$75 - Save the earth! It’s the only planet with chocolate…

When farmed correctly, cocoa crops in the DRC prevent deforestation, promote biodiversity, and are a great source of income for women. Enjoy chocolate from the socially responsible, environmentally conscious and incredibly delicious Theo chocolate, made from 100% Congolese chocolate! (For more info on Theo chocolates, visit their website.)


$120 - GoBonobo!

We share 98.7% of our DNA with the Bonobo, and now you can say so with fashion, designed by us at GCE for this campaign! (We will email you later for your size. All t-shirts are black with white writing, men's with regular neck, women's with v-neck. They will ship out about a month after the campaign has ended.)



$180 - Drill baby drill!

Okay, so it's not that kind of drilling! In order to build the 100 water wells needed for the villages here to have clean water, our first priority is to raise $18,000 to buy the drill. If 100 people choose this option, we will have our drill! And as a thank you, you will receive this cool Bonobo printed metal water bottle, all proceeds of which benefit Friends of Bonobos, a supporting organization for the world's only Bonobo sanctuary, located in the DRC, Lola Ya Bonobo.


$250 - Be a Water Champion!

Help us buy a boat for the village so they can transport the drill and materials to make the water wells. Your name will be carved in the side of the boat to commemorate your contribution!

(This is how the villagers transport goods. Some have to walk 15 km daily. Without a boat, we cannot get the materials to the villages for the water wells!)


$1000 - It takes a village…

The Ba'aka pygmy people are one of 150 different ethnic groups living in the Congo Basin, where humans have lived for tens of thousands of years. The Ba'aka people are the most representative of an ancient hunter-gatherer lifestyle left on the earth today. They possess incredible knowledge of the forest and its plants and animals. On his next trip to the villages, our founder will bring back 15 baskets made by the Ba'aka women, each one incredibly rare, unique and irreplaceable.

   


$9000 – Adopt-a-boat

There are no roads to these remote villages. In order to get the drill and materials for the wells (and future school and health clinic building), we need to purchase a large boat for transporting large materials. Pick this perk and we'll ask you to name the boat! And of course we will also send you photos of the boat, and the people using it!


$10,000 - Adopt-a-well

Sponsor one of our water wells! Each of the 40 villages in the area will be getting at least one well, and each one costs about $10,000 to build (though they do get less expensive the more we build). You will be responsible for naming one! We will add a plaque to the well with the name of your choice and then send a photo to you of the well and the villagers whose lives will be changed because they'll have clean water. This is a wonderful way to honor a loved one.

(This is the state of the drinking water available now. Let's change this together!)


From all of us at Go Conscious Earth, thank you for making a difference!


Interested in more information?
Check out this Greenpeace report: Carving up the Congo.

Here is more about the Bonobo, from the World Wildlife Fund.

Want to understand more about why clean water matters so much? Read this.


And more in the news...

A Million Acres of Rainforest Protection Meets Community Ownership...

Also on:

 

 NBC News 12

Check out this Greenpeace report: Carving up the Congo.


Here is more about the Bonobo, from the World Wildlife Fund.
Want to understand more about why clean water matters so much? Read this.


And more in the news...
A Million Acres of Rainforest Protection Meets Community Ownership...
Also on:
 
 NBC News 12

story:
Short Summary

Hi Everybody!

My name is Christi Wahlstrom and I am currently attending the University of Minnesota in pursuit of a Bachelor of Science degree in Environmental and Ecological Engineering.  I recently  was introduced to a joint project with the University of Minnesota and Mizoram University that is trying to bring clean and safe drinking water to the people of Mizoram, India.  Little to no data has been gathered or documented for this hilly Northeastern Indian state, making steps toward a clean water solution very difficult.  I have been asked to accompany a University of Minnesota graduate student to travel to Mizoram and set up several weather monitoring stations as well as water instrumentation stations at strategically selected sites all over the state. Data can then be collected and information about the state of water in Mizoram can be used to inform solutions to the current water crisis.  The donations that I am looking for would be to fund my travel to Mizoram exclusively. 

The cost required to travel to Mizoram is approximately $2,000.00.  The money that you give will go directly to fund my travel to Mizoram.  Regardless of whether or not the goal is reached, any funds donated will be put towards traveling to Mizoram, India.
Initial data collection is an integral part of a much larger process, finding a solution to ensure that people in Mizoram can count on clean and safe water year round. Moving forward with formulating solutions to clean water scarcity problems in Mizoram requires this data collection.
Please spread the word.  If you know anybody who would be interested in contributing please share my page.  Thanks everyone!!!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Mark Dennis. I'm a 33 year old Jamaican professional engineer with a passion for sustainable energy, environmental preservation and innovative thinking. I've always been highly driven, and a doer. I prefer to make myself a part of the solution, than be one of those that only discuss and debate the issues. For these reasons, I'm daring to take on two of Jamaica's most critical issues - energy security and sustainable waste management.

Jamaica spends around 16% of its total GDP per year to secure imported oil for around 92% of its energy needs. That's almost USD 2.5 billion leaving our country per year - in a country in desperate need for financing of its health and education sectors, to name a few. The high dependence on imported oil also has its own severe consequences; high CO2 levels in the atmosphere, high risk energy security and most critical - unpredictable and high energy costs. Jamaica has one of the highest energy costs in the world, peaking at US$0.44 per kWh in recent times. The high costs, plus their unpredictability, has led to a loss of global competitiveness for Jamaican manufacturers and even a loss of in-country competitiveness against imported products made with much cheaper energy. The high and unpredictable energy costs has also served to oppose the country's agenda for poverty eradication. Jamaica's solid waste management is also in crisis. There are no engineered landfills, just selected dumpsites with limited restrictions to public access. The result of this has been significant pollution of land, air and water mediums, high risk contamination to humans and animals, and very frequent fires (the latest landfill fire in March 2015 cost Jamaicans around USD 2.3 million resulting in health problems, closure of businesses and combating the blaze).

I'm proposing a solution that helps to resolve both issues with one swipe. Diverting solid waste to a well engineered and sustainable, clean plant; and converting this solid waste to usable electricity at a cheap cost to the public.

Your contribution to this cause will help to achieve savings to the country of around USD 27.2 million per year by avoiding the importation of 262,000 barrels of oil; you will help to increase Jamaica's electricity supply diversification by 5% - which goes a far way in lowering energy security risks; you will help me to produce 18 Megawatts of reliable power from an indigenous source; you will help to provide employment for 200 Jamaicans during construction of the plant and 50 during operation of the plant; you will help to reduce Jamaica's carbon footprint by over 100,000 tonnes of CO2 per year; you will help to divert up to 620 tonnes of solid waste away from dumpsites, and you will help Jamaica achieve a greener and cleaner image.

What We Need & What You Get

With this dream in mind, I've finally been given an opportunity by my government to propose a full scale plan, at investment grade quality. Between myself, my family and close colleagues, we've already spent around USD 80,000 in cash and kind.

  • I need USD 500,000 to develop a full scale investment grade proposal that will meet the proposal requirements of my government and financiers who have already committed to financing the building of the plant. The USD 500,000 will cover administrative costs, international consultancy fees (for mechanical-electrical studies, civil studies, topography studies, geotechnical studies, interconnection studies, environmental impact assessment, power simulations and analysis, waste studies), travel and accommodation for these consultants, legal costs, accounting costs and permit costs. I have about three months to do this as I've been given a deadline of January 27th, 2016.
  • The truth is, I'm challenging the status quo and attempting to make history. If I'm successful in this venture, this will be Jamaica's first waste to energy plant, I will be the youngest national from a poor to middle class family to execute his own project resulting in benefits valued in millions to all Jamaicans, and I would have smashed the misconception that young un-wealthy Jamaicans like myself cannot be successful entrepreneurs with a product of national - and potentially regional impact. Help me to demonstrate to other youths such as myself, the power of an idea.
  • If I fail to reach my goal of USD 500,000, my plan is to negotiate with the consultants, whom I know are sympathetic to my cause. We will have to stretch what we have. I'm also avidly working with other individuals and agencies to raise additional funds that hopefully will be enough to offset any shortfall in this campaign for USD 500,000

The Impact

Your contribution will have a significant impact on Jamaicans all over, but particularly the next generation of Jamaicans that will inherit this land, and will have to decide at some point to either work for someone and talk about the issues, or become an entrepreneur and help to solve the issues.

The project will reduce the negative impact caused by unsanitary dumpsites on the health of Jamaicans and the environment, reduce the country's CO2 footprint, provide 250 jobs to Jamaicans over its lifetime, provide energy from an indigenous source to around 45,000 households, help Jamaica to save around USD 27 million per year which can be spent in other critical sectors such as health and education and prove that our young Caribbean professionals do not have to have connections or wealth to cause national positive impact on a large scale.

This venture was just an idea of mine in 2009, but it became real when I decided to quit my job as a project engineer for the Government of Jamaica. I managed to get a full Chevening scholarship, then successfully completed my Masters in Sustainable Energy Technologies and Management  in London, England. I came back to Jamaica, and immediately went to work in making the dream a tangible one - through feasibility studies, meetings and building a team. I've been told numerous times, explicitly and implicitly, that I'm in over my head. I'm too young, I have no connections, and I'm not wealthy - are just some of the reasons I've been given by others to shelve this dream. We're now in 2015 and I'm closer than ever to proving many wrong, to achieving something that will have a massive impact. I know this dream is big enough, because the scale of its impact "scares me". Help me to achieve this dream.

Risks & Challenges

The only risk of this project/venture is that the government of Jamaica can refuse and reject it. The relevant Jamaican laws are such that the project/venture must be accepted and endorsed by the Government of Jamaica.

This risk is one of the reasons why my team and I have put so much preparation work into this venture, with multiple meetings with all public and private stakeholders involved. We now have the blessing of all these stakeholders, and have tweaked the project so that its objectives and goals align with government policy, and all the project characteristics are aligned perfectly with the both public and private sector's requirements and goals. We've done our due diligence and are confident that this project will be welcomed, accepted and endorsed by the Government of Jamaica.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're unable to contribute, you can still help. Get the word out, share our story and campaign with as many as you can find. The wider the audience, the better our chances of achieving success. So please, share share share!!!

story:
About me:

  • I'm a young Student who can't afford a Tesla model S
  • 2014 I applied for a Tesla Testdrive but I wasn't allowed to drive by myself because you have to be 25yrs old. That made me really sad.
  • Please help me to drive my own Tesla before the age off 25.

What you give & what you get

I want to show people in Europe, that electric cars are the future.

Since Tesla started developing electric cars, I was catched by the futuristic sounding ideas. So i decided to persuade as many people as I can to think about alternative Cars like the Tesla Model S.

  • Look at my interesting perks for you and decide which one to take.
  • If we don't reach our goal, the money will help me financing my education in future.


Thank you very much. I hope to see you soon on a TestDrive.

story:
About the project

This feeling, finally, that we may change things - this is at the center of everything we are. Lose that... lose everything.               

Sir David Hare 1947

This belief is behind the Ocean Virtual Reality (VR) Documentary and Awareness Project – called OCEAN IMMERSION. If you share this belief then read on – and join us! We are going to change things and we are going to have fun doing it together!

INTRODUCING CEDRIC FAYOLLE

Ocean Immersion Project Director

Born in Mauritius in 1981, Cedric Fayolle was 6 years old when his father introduced him to scuba diving. Before he knew it, Cedric was connected with the ocean in ways he would not understand until years later.

In 2000, Cedric became a CMAS 2* Instructor and worked at the biggest PADI 5* dive center in Mauritius. In 2001, he opened ‘Ocean Spirit Dive center’ with the help of his father.

Since then, Ocean Spirit has become a well-established name in the Mauritius and Indian Ocean diving scene and has built a strong reputation as a safe, fun seeking and conservation conscious professional dive center.

Cedric has also ventured into making underwater movies and using movies to inspire and change perceptions. ( see some movie samples and clips in the gallery)

In November 2014, Cedric received a "Honorable mention" in the Blue Ocean film festival and conservation summit" in the Category "Emerging Film makers"


Now Cedric has a much bigger dream! Cedric wants use video, photography and most importantly exciting new Virtual Reality (VR) technology to launch an educational drive in Mauritius that will change perceptions and change the way coral reefs are managed and protected in the country.

With this educational drive as the basis of the project, Cedric is partnering with talented creative people both from Mauritius and abroad for an exciting journey, and we want to include YOU in this journey too!



OCEAN IMMERSION - PHASE 1 

Goal – Get Underwater Footage that is Mind-Blowing!

We are going to do something that has not been done before - we are going to take Mauritians and the rest of the world underwater without actually being underwater.

How? With ground breaking 360º video technology. This virtual reality video is truly amazing – it transports the viewer into the environment in a way that normal documentaries can’t.

We will be amongst the world pioneers in 360º video technology in underwater documentary. This latest high tech system for studying and filming subjects will enable envisioning options with the Augmented reality Spectacles. We will have people explore the ocean and experience it as if they were there! We’ve tested it with people here and it’s a mind-blowing experience! 

Examples of spectacles that can be used for the visioning of the 360º videos.  https://www.oculus.com/dk2/    or      http://avegant.com/


Detailed shooting objectives are as follow:

  • The first step of the project will be to get some good footage in 360º. While going out on expeditions for that purpose, the team will take the opportunity to document the work and promote it in underwater film festivals worldwide. First, it will serve as project updates on the web site and indiegogo.com so you can follow our progress. Secondly, if we succeed in getting recognition for this work, we might influence such educational approaches world wide! And you will be a part of this ;-)
  • A 52-minute underwater documentary and a 26 minute terrestrial documentary will be produced. The documentary film will recount the human as well as the nature story that unfolds while on 360º shooting expeditions, featuring a compilation of the most astonishing places and sights of the Island of Mauritius both above and below water. It will tell the story of the challenges faced and overcome, and the successes achieved through dedicated teamwork! It will document the shooting stages, the discussions, the education campaigns and the ongoing education drive through the formation of a self-sustaining marine conservation association in Mauritius.

The documentary will be sent to 5 international film festivals:

1.  The Blue Ocean Film Festival and Conservation Summit 2015/2016

2.  Ocean Film Festival Australia 2016 

3.  San Francisco International Ocean Film Festival 2016

4.  Festival Mondial de l'image Sous Marine 2016

5.  Wildlife Conservation Film Festival 2016


Examples of ocean stories we will introduce in the documentary:

The life of the amazing Mauritian Guitar Shark (aka Giant Ray Shark) - Rhyncho Batus Djiddensis. This amazing animal is currently Red listed by the IUCN (International Union for Nature conservation). We will research its behavior patterns (including at night!), feeding methods and show how their habitat is under threat.

 

  • We will document the unique shark habitats in Mauritius – the famous shark pit and shark caves of the northern Islands of Mauritius. These unique places are being promoted as dive destinations but without sufficient ecological concern. They are under great threat – and together we can change this! One of the deliverables of the project is to set in motion a campaign with the objective of gaining World Heritage Site protection for these sites. We believe that when the people of Mauritius and the rest of the world see these amazing creatures in these special habitats it will change their perceptions and make them want to protect them with pride.


  • The story of the annual breeding passage of large pelagic (e.g. tuna, Humpback whale, mackerel, jacks etc ) off the island of Mauritius.

  • We will also tell the human story – the meetings with local ministries to discuss ocean related issues and how we can help them promote and protect our heritage for generations to come. We want to work with them and showcase their efforts as together we find better sustainable solutions to protecting our precious reefs and marine ecosystems. Some of the specific causes we want to push forward include:
    • Obtaining the support of the Government to gain World Heritage Site protection for some or all of the area around the group of small islands lying to the north of Mauritius. These are world-class underwater habitats that currently have NO protection at all;
    • Better management around the usage of anchors on the coral reefs around Mauritius. At the moment there is indiscriminate use of anchors by dive operators and fishermen – this is slowly destroying our precious reefs.


OCEAN IMMERSION - PHASE 2 

Goal –Raise Awareness/Educate!

We will launch an education drive in schools, universities and through public exhibitions to educate our fellow Mauritians on the wonder of the their underwater heritage.

With this educational drive as the basis of our project, we aim to use the opportunity to touch on sensitive subjects such as plastic pollution in our oceans, pollution of reefs from agricultural chemicals, overfishing and the need for proper marine protected areas in Mauritius.

Upon the completion of shooting and editing 360º video footage, events will be organized to educate and promote ocean awareness. The primary objective is to organize 5 public exhibitions and 10 visits in local schools with 4 independent augmented reality sets and computers.

The programs will be composed of small workshops with specific subjects discussed related to the coast and ocean followed by a 2-5 minute film with the 360º augmented reality technology.

Through this approach, we will be able to make people experience the ocean as if they were there and discover what is in our Mauritian seas. (Did you know: 60% of the Mauritian population do not know how to swim let alone appreciate what lies beneath the surface of the sea around the island).

We believe that to protect something, we have to know it, see it and understand it and experience it. And this is exactly what we will do through the VR technology.

The public events will be arranged in strategic places to attract large crowds of people of all ages, classes and cultures.

Finally, a fund raising event will be held targeting up to 50 large Mauritian enterprises aimed at creating awareness of the project and its objectives, which are:

1.  To promote a sustainable future for Mauritius;

2.  To reinforce environmental awareness and conservation through local and international scientific, artistic contribution and conservative actions;

3.  To create educational support using new technologies on a long-term basis.

4.  Finally, to establish an organization that fights and dares to speak out for the things that can be changed for a better environment.


OCEAN IMMERSION - PHASE 3 

Goal – Create a Living Legacy!

The final goal of the project will be to raise enough funds (using this campaign to leverage public and private funds in Mauritius and around the world) to create and run (first 2-3 years) an OCEAN IMMERSION ASSOCIATION that will have ongoing campaigns, projects and goals – building on the successes and lessons learned from Phase 1 and 2 of this campaign. The association will include core team members of the Ocean Immersion documentary production team.

This association's primary goal will be continue the awareness and advocacy work started with this campaign – working with concerned government ministries and local communities and other partners around the world to better protect and appreciate the precious marine environment of the Indian Ocean that surrounds the beautiful island of Mauritius.


RISKS AND CHALLENGES

We have a highly qualified, skilled, experienced and motivated team  - but given the nature of this project (working out at sea and underwater with specialised equipment etc.) there will be inherent challenges and risks.

Main risks and challenges, and how we will work to mitigate them, include:

Risks

Risk detail

What we will do to minimize this risk

The weather

We need permits with dates for shooting certain scenes and actions on specific locations. Postponing them will be difficult, as we will have rented logistics such as boats, technicians and team members, rental equipment. Forecasting and timing will be crucial.

To mitigate the risk, we have scheduled more shooting expeditions as a safety margin.

The wildlife species

As we intend to film wildlife species, there is no certainty in actually meeting them. Secondly, if we manage to find the species, demonstrating some behavioral patterns for us to study is another part of the difficulty.  

We have scheduled more shooting expeditions and have researched the area to map the animal’s habitat. We will also make use of remote equipment to extend the observation length and chances of recording and providing safer team shifts and operations. We will also make use of Nitrox gas for safer and longer dives within decompression margins.

Cooperation

We will need many permits and support from certain ministries in Mauritius. We also intend to add one or two ministers into the documentary, hoping that they will support the cause and promote their aims and objectives locally and internationally through the documentary film.

To cope with this, we have some key people that can influence positive outcomes. We have a humble and noble approach and above all, we have patience and a never-give up attitude. 

Finance

Getting the required finance will be a great challenge. The project is a massive one and involves a long list of expenditures. We are conscious that the amount may be hard to get, but we have faith in our objective.

We can only work hard to inspire further funding through out the way and hope that people will see value in what we are doing and share it with their network.


WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO?

The different phases of the project each have their own targets and plans to reach these targets. Cedric owns a dive center, Ocean Spirit. Ocean Spirit will cover all the costs related to scuba diving equipment, tanks and the staff of Ocean Spirit. Some expeditions, however, will require renting larger boats and other logistics such as food for the crew etc. whilst staying out at sea around more remote places (e.g. the northern Islands of Mauritius).

Other shooting sessions will be on land and will require the uses of drones, planes, and other equipment such a tripods, back up cameras, the 360º cameras, reflectors, stabilizers, filters, hard disks (the 360º video is in full HD and just 10 min of film can be as big as 80GB! Loads of storage will be required for this particular video technology).

The budget also includes paying for sound engineers, editors, studio rental, models, food and beverage, transportation logistics, insurance and other unavoidable miscellaneous expenses. 

Phase 2 will require materials such as projectors, conference halls with their food and beverage services, permits and marketing materials. Computers to accommodate the Rift spectacle sets will also have to be purchased.

Some funding will also go towards perks as gifts for those supporting the projects with their Indiegogo donations such as t-shirts, caps, coffee mugs, flight tickets for expeditions and for supporters, accommodations for hosting the supporters. These will be according to the amount donated by supporters (see details below).

Lastly, a contingency budget has been set on 15,000 USD.

Budget breakdown:

No

Items

USD

1

Camera and other filming and shooting equipment

25,000

2

Transport/ Logistics

23,500

3

Insurance

1,500

4

Free lance wages

20,500

5

Permits and other applications

5,500

6

Rental of accommodation

2,500

7

Exhibition, campaign and presentations

6,500

8

Marketing

8,500

9

Perks

8,000

10

Contingency

15,000

Total:

116,500



We will endeavour to do everything we do at the lowest costs (without compromising safety) and will look to leverage the support and cooperation of service providers who could benefit from the exposure of being associated with the project. We have set the bar high to be sure that we can reach our objectives. Whatever is in excess once the project is completed will go to the association as a start-up donation.

If we do not reach our full funding goals, what we do raise will go towards the most important part of the project – which is educating kids using the 360º VR video and through short demos and small workshops. 

THE PERKS!

We have small and big rewards for all supporters. From t-shirts, 360 video and Google cart-boards, flights to Mauritius, and all expenses-paid hotel stays in Mauritius. Woohoo! Check out our perks!

                    


We can’t do this without YOU. This project is by nature ambitious, noble but mighty and daring. Together we can make a massive difference both locally in Mauritius and internationally, for this project can and will travel!  This technology is meant to grow and our unique approach can only do good on several levels. Your influence counts!


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN GET INVOLVED!

If you cannot make a donation, we would still be very grateful if you could share this project with your social networks, your friends and loved ones. 

You can also apply on the career page of www.oceanimmersion.com and express your interest to join our team as a volunteer or intern. We have several options to make this happen coupled with scuba training or exposure to other fields such as communication, marketing, shooting underwater and more. 

Please come on-board! Join us and get OCEAN IMMERSED. Make this part of your life’s legacy. Let’s work together to change things!
