later.

In 2000, Cedric became a CMAS 2* Instructor and worked
at the biggest PADI 5* dive center in Mauritius. In 2001, he opened ‘Ocean
Spirit Dive center’ with the help of his father. 
Since then, Ocean Spirit has become a well-established
name in the Mauritius and Indian Ocean diving scene and has built a strong reputation as a safe, fun seeking and conservation conscious professional dive center. 


Cedric has also ventured into making underwater movies and using movies
to inspire and change perceptions. ( see some movie samples and clips in the gallery)


In November 2014, Cedric received a "Honorable
mention" in the Blue Ocean film festival and conservation summit" in
the Category "Emerging Film makers"






Now Cedric has a much bigger dream! Cedric wants use video, photography
and most importantly exciting new Virtual Reality (VR) technology to launch an
educational drive in Mauritius that will change perceptions and change the way
coral reefs are managed and protected in the country.
With this educational drive as the basis of the project, Cedric is
partnering with talented creative people both from Mauritius and abroad for an
exciting journey, and we want to include YOU in this journey too!




OCEAN IMMERSION - PHASE
1 
Goal – Get Underwater Footage that is Mind-Blowing!
We are going to do something that has not been done before - we are going to
take Mauritians and the rest of the world underwater without actually being
underwater. 
How? With ground breaking 360º video technology. This
virtual reality video is truly amazing – it transports the viewer into the
environment in a way that normal documentaries can’t.


We will be amongst the world pioneers in 360º video technology in
underwater documentary. This latest high tech system for studying and filming
subjects will enable envisioning options with the Augmented reality Spectacles. We will have people explore the ocean and
experience it as if they were there! We’ve tested it with people here and it’s
a mind-blowing experience! 
Examples of spectacles that can be used for the visioning of the 360º
videos.  https://www.oculus.com/dk2/    or      http://avegant.com/







Detailed shooting objectives are as follow:
The first step of the project will be to get some good footage in
     360º. While going out on expeditions for that purpose, the team will take the
     opportunity to document the work and promote it in underwater film
     festivals worldwide. First, it will serve as project updates on the web
     site and indiegogo.com so you can follow our progress. Secondly, if we
     succeed in getting recognition for this work, we might influence such
     educational approaches world wide! And you will be a part of this ;-)



A 52-minute
underwater documentary and a 26 minute terrestrial documentary will be
produced. The documentary film will recount the human as well as the nature
story that unfolds while on 360º shooting expeditions, featuring a compilation of the most astonishing places and sights of the Island
     of Mauritius both above and below water. It will tell the story of the
     challenges faced and overcome, and the successes achieved through
     dedicated teamwork! It will document the shooting stages, the discussions,
     the education campaigns and the ongoing education drive through the
     formation of a self-sustaining marine conservation association in
     Mauritius.

The documentary will
be sent to 5 international film festivals:


1. 
The Blue Ocean Film Festival and Conservation Summit 2015/2016
2. 
Ocean Film Festival Australia 2016 
3. 
San Francisco International Ocean Film Festival 2016
4. 
Festival Mondial de l'image Sous Marine 2016
5. 
Wildlife Conservation Film Festival 2016

Examples of ocean stories we will introduce in the documentary:


The
life of the amazing Mauritian Guitar Shark (aka Giant Ray Shark) - Rhyncho Batus Djiddensis.
This amazing animal is currently Red listed by the IUCN (International Union for Nature
conservation). We will research its behavior patterns (including at night!),
feeding methods and show how their habitat is under threat. 
  



We will document the unique
     shark habitats in Mauritius – the famous shark pit and shark caves of the northern Islands of
     Mauritius. These unique places are being promoted as dive destinations but
     without sufficient ecological concern. They are under great threat – and
     together we can change this! One of the deliverables of the
project is to set in motion a campaign with the objective of gaining World
Heritage Site protection for these sites. We believe that when the people of
Mauritius and the rest of the world see these amazing creatures in these
special habitats it will change their perceptions and make them want to protect
them with pride.






The story of the
     annual breeding passage of large pelagic (e.g. tuna, Humpback whale, mackerel, jacks etc ) off the island of
     Mauritius.








We will also tell the
     human story – the meetings with local ministries to discuss ocean related
     issues and how we can help them promote and protect our heritage for
     generations to come. We want to work with them and showcase their efforts
     as together we find better sustainable solutions to protecting our
     precious reefs and marine ecosystems. Some of the specific causes we want
     to push forward include:

Obtaining the support of the Government
      to gain World Heritage Site protection for some or all of the area
      around the group of small islands lying to the north of Mauritius. These
      are world-class underwater habitats that currently have NO protection at
      all;
Better management around the usage of
      anchors on the coral reefs around Mauritius. At the moment there is
      indiscriminate use of anchors by dive operators and fishermen – this is
      slowly destroying our precious reefs.








OCEAN IMMERSION -
PHASE 2 
Goal –Raise Awareness/Educate!
We will launch an education drive in schools, universities and through
public exhibitions to educate our fellow Mauritians on the wonder of the their
underwater heritage.
With this educational drive as the basis of our project, we aim to use
the opportunity to touch on sensitive subjects such as plastic pollution in our
oceans, pollution of reefs from agricultural chemicals, overfishing and the
need for proper marine protected areas in Mauritius.
Upon the completion
of shooting and editing 360º video footage, events will be organized to educate
and promote ocean awareness. The primary objective is to organize 5 public
exhibitions and 10 visits in local schools with 4 independent augmented reality
sets and computers.
The programs will be composed of small workshops with specific
subjects discussed related to the coast and ocean followed by a 2-5 minute film
with the 360º augmented reality technology.
Through this approach, we will be able to make people experience the
ocean as if they were there and discover what is in our Mauritian seas. (Did you know: 60% of the Mauritian
population do not know how to swim let alone appreciate what lies beneath the
surface of the sea around the island).
We believe that to protect something, we have to know it, see it and
understand it and experience it. And this is exactly what we will do through
the VR technology.


The public events will be arranged in strategic places to attract large crowds
of people of all ages, classes and cultures.
Finally, a fund raising event will be held targeting up to 50 large Mauritian
enterprises aimed at creating awareness of the project and its objectives,
which are:
1. 
To promote a sustainable future for Mauritius;
2. 
To reinforce environmental awareness and conservation through local and
international scientific, artistic contribution and conservative actions;
3. 
To create educational support using new technologies on a long-term
basis.
4. 
Finally, to establish an organization that fights and dares to speak out
for the things that can be changed for a better environment.




OCEAN IMMERSION - PHASE
3 
Goal – Create a Living Legacy!
The final goal of the project will be to raise enough funds (using this
campaign to leverage public and private funds in Mauritius and around the
world) to create and run (first 2-3 years) an OCEAN IMMERSION ASSOCIATION that will have ongoing campaigns,
projects and goals – building on the successes and lessons learned from Phase 1
and 2 of this campaign. The association will include core team members of the
Ocean Immersion documentary production team.
This association's primary goal will be continue the awareness and
advocacy work started with this campaign – working with concerned government
ministries and local communities and other partners around the world to better
protect and appreciate the precious marine environment of the Indian Ocean that
surrounds the beautiful island of Mauritius. 



RISKS AND CHALLENGES
We have a highly qualified, skilled, experienced and motivated team  - but given the nature of this project (working
out at sea and underwater with specialised equipment etc.) there will be inherent
challenges and risks. 
Main risks and
challenges, and how we will work to mitigate them, include:





Risks


Risk
  detail


What
  we will do to minimize this risk




The weather


We need permits with dates for shooting certain
  scenes and actions on specific locations. Postponing them will be difficult,
  as we will have rented logistics such as boats, technicians and team members,
  rental equipment. Forecasting and timing will be crucial.


To mitigate the risk, we have
  scheduled more shooting expeditions as a safety margin.




The wildlife species


As we intend to film wildlife species, there is no
  certainty in actually meeting them. Secondly, if we manage to find the
  species, demonstrating some behavioral patterns for us to study is another
  part of the difficulty.  


We have scheduled more
  shooting expeditions and have researched the area to map the animal’s
  habitat. We will also make use of remote equipment to extend the observation
  length and chances of recording and providing safer team shifts and
  operations. We will also make use of Nitrox gas for safer and longer dives
  within decompression margins.




Cooperation


We will need many permits and support from certain
  ministries in Mauritius. We also intend to add one or two ministers into the
  documentary, hoping that they will support the cause and promote their aims
  and objectives locally and internationally through the documentary film.


To cope with this, we have
  some key people that can influence positive outcomes. We have a humble and
  noble approach and above all, we have patience and a never-give up
  attitude. 




Finance


Getting the required finance will be a great
  challenge. The project is a massive one and involves a long list of
  expenditures. We are conscious that the amount may be hard to get, but we
  have faith in our objective.


We can only work hard to
  inspire further funding through out the way and hope that people will see
  value in what we are doing and share it with their network.







WHERE WILL THE
MONEY GO?
The different phases of the project each have their own targets and plans
to reach these targets. Cedric owns a dive center, Ocean Spirit. Ocean Spirit
will cover all the costs related to scuba diving equipment, tanks and the staff
of Ocean Spirit. Some expeditions,
however, will require renting larger boats and other logistics such as food for
the crew etc. whilst staying out at sea around more remote places (e.g. the
northern Islands of Mauritius).
Other shooting sessions will be on land and will require the uses of
drones, planes, and other equipment such a tripods, back up cameras, the 360º
cameras, reflectors, stabilizers, filters, hard disks (the 360º video is in full HD and just 10
min of film can be as big as 80GB! Loads of storage will be required for this
particular video technology).
The budget also includes paying for sound engineers,
editors, studio rental, models, food and beverage, transportation logistics,
insurance and other unavoidable miscellaneous expenses. 
Phase 2 will require materials such as
projectors, conference halls with their food and beverage services, permits and
marketing materials. Computers to accommodate the Rift spectacle sets will also
have to be purchased.
Some funding will also go towards perks as
gifts for those supporting the projects with their Indiegogo donations such as
t-shirts, caps, coffee mugs, flight tickets for expeditions and for supporters,
accommodations for hosting the supporters. These will be according to the amount
donated by supporters (see details below).
Lastly, a contingency budget has been set on 15,000 USD.
Budget breakdown:





No


Items


USD




1


Camera
  and other filming and shooting equipment


25,000




2


Transport/
  Logistics


23,500




3


Insurance


1,500




4


Free
  lance wages


20,500




5


Permits
  and other applications


5,500




6


Rental
  of accommodation


2,500




7


Exhibition,
  campaign and presentations


6,500




8


Marketing


8,500




9


Perks


8,000




10


Contingency


15,000




Total:


116,500








We will endeavour to do everything we do at the
lowest costs (without compromising safety) and will look to leverage the
support and cooperation of service providers who could benefit from the
exposure of being associated with the project. We have set the bar high to be
sure that we can reach our objectives. Whatever is in excess once the
project is completed will go to the association as a start-up donation.
If we do not reach our full funding goals, what we do raise will go
towards the most important part of the project – which is educating kids using
the 360º VR video and through short demos and small workshops. 


THE PERKS!
We have small and big
rewards for all supporters. From t-shirts, 360 video and Google cart-boards, flights to
Mauritius, and all expenses-paid hotel stays in Mauritius. Woohoo! Check out our
perks!

                     

We can’t do this
without YOU. This project is by nature ambitious, noble but mighty and daring.
Together we can make a massive difference both locally in Mauritius and
internationally, for this project can and will travel!  This technology is meant to grow and our
unique approach can only do good on several levels. Your influence counts!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN
GET INVOLVED!
If you cannot make a
donation, we would still be very grateful if you could share this project with
your social networks, your friends and loved ones. 

You can also apply on the career page of www.oceanimmersion.com and express your interest to join our team as a volunteer or
intern. We have several options to make this happen coupled with scuba training
or exposure to other fields such as communication, marketing, shooting
underwater and more. 


Please come on-board!
Join us and get OCEAN IMMERSED. Make
this part of your life’s legacy. Let’s work together to change things!

story:
What We Are Doing

We are a nonprofit with a mission to educate students about four core values: life sciences, sustainability, eco-literacy, and healthy eating.

To improve our healthy eating classes, we need to upgrade our basic garden kitchen to include better facilities than the hotplates and the BBQ grill we currently use. The centerpiece of this upgrade project will be the brick oven, providing heating and cooking space and a way to convert our garden waste into biochar.

Our current kitchen setup

With an outdoor brick oven, we can expand our mission to advocate for a Diet for a Healthy Planet, while reducing waste output and maximizing efficiency. We use the garden to host events, cooking classes, and workshops. By holding successful events and renting out our space, our garden can generate revenue and be self-sustaining. Our goal at the CNGF is to create an example of a self-sustaining teaching garden for our partner school gardens around the state.  With projects like the oven and other infrastructure improvements, schools will have garden income, which will allow the self-sustaining garden to serve the student population in the long term. (And everyone loves pizza.)

Fall Harvest 2014: A new kitchen will make our gala events even better


Where we started

California Native Garden Foundation started ten years ago when I had a vision in a parking lot: Why not form a non-profit foundation to help current and future generations realize the importance and benefits of native plants? From that idea we turned a bus parking lot into a teaching garden that has become a model for schoolyards all over the San Francisco Bay Area. Since that time we have worked with over 50 schools in California to install teaching gardens.

What We Are Asking For

We are a relatively small non-profit, and we need your help getting this project off the ground.  We have volunteers and labor sources lined up, and we have designed the oven build as a series of workshops, so the community can learn and be a part of the process. 

We need $1,000 to pay for the professional planning and design of the oven. We have a designer lined up who is willing to give us a steep discount for his services -- both designing the oven and overseeing the build itself. Another $1,000 will go toward buying building materials for the project, including special brick that can withstand high temperatures.

The next $2,000 will make this project a major success. We want to make our garden kitchen the ideal space for holding events by improving the existing kitchen area. This includes renovating the sink and adding gas-burning stovetops.

We also plan to work with Chef Joni Sare to create a cookbook and guide to the kitchen and oven, so anyone can easily make use of the facility. The cookbook will allow us to share recipes and cooking techniques with any school that adopts our outdoor kitchen model. We estimate the cost for Chef Joni’s time and materials will be $1,000. Eventually, we hope to publish this cookbook.

If we are lucky enough to get more than $5,000, we can afford to make the oven really beautiful. An extra $1,000 will pay local artist Christina Yaconelli to do a mosaic for the oven. Art in the garden!


How It Will Help Us

This project will have a massive impact on our garden and the Foundation. It will be a lynchpin in our Diet for a Healthy Planet initiative. To pull that off we need a functional kitchen. This oven will also prove our model garden concept by showing prospective schools that a garden can be a self-sustaining and even profitable system, making it an even more attractive concept for schools.

Thank you!

Alrie Middlebrook

CNGF Founder and President


FAQ

Who are you?

We are the California Native Garden Foundation, a nonprofit organization focused on promoting the importance and benefits of California native plants.  We partner with schools throughout California to build native and edible gardens in their yards, where we teach healthy eating, gardening, sustainability, and environmental science.  We also host weekly community sustainability events and workshops at the Middlebrook Center, the site of our model teaching garden and the CNGF office.

What are we doing?

We are updating our outdoor kitchen to include a beautiful oven, a better sink, and more counter space.

Why?

The kitchen improvement project will enable us to host more community events and make our facilities a successful model of a self-sustaining teaching garden -- a model that we will share with our partner schools to ensure the longevity of their teaching gardens.

story:
Kalsakau (3rd from left) is an indigenous landowner of the Loru rainforest and spokes person for a project for its protection. Along with the chief and other land owners, Kalsakau cares deeply about Loru. Their vision is that the younger generation grow to understand its cultural and environmental significance and preserve these values into the future.

The Loru Community Conservation area is one of the last remaining lowland rainforest areas in Santo (the largest island in the Vanuatu island chain). Its supports a unique biodiversity including many endemic and rare species.

Unfortunately there are very few opportunities for residents of nearby Khole village to earn an income. In the absence of alternatives, the Loru rainforest, like many others, would soon make way for coconut plantations.

The Loru project is part of the Nakau Programme www.nakau.org. This program is introducing a new 'conservation economy' assisting indigenous landowners to replace activities that degrade their environment with activities that protect and enhance it.

By funding this campaign you are 'buying' conservation outcomes and allowing indigenous landowners to meet their basic needs - and fulfil a dream. The Loru landowners dream that one day one of their kids will get a university degree. They see the project as an opportunity to make this dream come true. 

The conservation area also reduces greenhouse gas emissions and decreases the villages vulnerability to natural disasters, such as cyclones. Vanuatu was recently ravaged by Cyclone Pam and is considered the World's most at risk nation to natural disasters.

The funds raised through conservation are reinvested into community development projects, including improving water supply and sanitation, and establishing an indigenous nut farming business operated by the local women. If this campaign exceeds its target, funds will also be used to purchase conservation outcomes from a sister project in Drawa, Fiji.

story:
Pay for your environmental sins, we do the rest

Contributors can get the full, green absolution.

  • You drive a humvee? 
  • You used RoundUp in your garden?
  • You did not separate the garbage?
  • You used plastic bags?

The suffering for lesser sins like these.. Fear not, we can help you! 

  • You  have mass-murdered trees?
  • You use RoundUp on big scale for fruit- and vegetable farming?
  • You  work for Shell, Exxon, Monsanto
The suffering for bigger sins like these.. You should really be afraid! But, we also forgive those evils, if you are truly willing, never to do it again.
 

Other sins

We are not the Roman Catholic Church, but if you feel bad, help us plant a few trees and wildflowers on former monocultures, to improve the soil and water quality and regain biodiversity in Europe.

story:
Climate Resilience through Community Empowerment

Across the African continent climate change is having catastrophic consequences such as unpredictable and extreme weather, drought and famine, and species extinction. Tragically, these effects are leading to conflict, social dislocation and poverty for thousands of communities.

For decades and in recognition of such challenges, the Global Ecovillage Network (GEN) and thousands of ecovillage communities worldwide have been pioneering and demonstrating best practices and success stories both to mitigate and adapt to climate change.

GEN is spotlighting how locally-led climate resilience can be replicated and scaled up to achieve dramatic results and substantially improve the lives of people living in poor and rural communities - especially in the Global South.

Introducing the Pan-African Ecovillage Development Programme: an initiative forwarding participatory community consultations that couple locally-led needs analysis with international expertise in holistic design. This process is bringing regenerative solutions to African communities to support climate change mitigation and adaptation.

With your support, we can continue to expand the Ecovillage Development Programme across Africa.

Why Ecovillage Development?

Experience is showing us that community-led regenerative development works for communities. Now this approach is beginning to become recognised in the mainstream. GEN is supporting continued lobbying and implementation of the ecovillage development model. 

  • The Senegalese government is transforming 14,000 rural villages into ecovillages across the country.
  • In Egypt, the Sekem Farm and Ecovillage has developed programmes and initiatives over the last four decades that have transformed sustainable agricultural practices, provided access to herbal medicines and teas, and provided employment opportunities and holistic school programs that have benefited more than 40,000 local villagers.
  • The Democratic Republic of Congo is considering setting up a Ministry of Ecovillages.
  • Burkina Faso has decided to transition 2000 traditional communities to ecovillages by 2020.
  • Many ecovillage projects and national networks in other Sub-Saharan African countries such as Kenya, The Gambia, Zimbabwe, and Zambia are also adopting this approach.

Across the globe, ecovillages are already demonstrating that accessible solutions exist to mitigate and adapt to climate change. From low-tech natural carbon sequestration techniques, regenerative agricultural practices, large scale water retention landscape regeneration methods, and radically low ecological footprints, ecovillages are showcasing that the changes in lifestyle and consumption necessary to achieve ecological sustainability are attractive and attainable.

In addition to working on-the-ground, GEN is directly engaging governments and other powerful actors across Africa to spotlight the evident benefits of ecovillage development from countries already using the approach. Thus far we have seen remarkable buy-in. In this way, our strategy involves working directly with communities, national governments, United Nations agencies, and allied international civil society organisations to bring the benefits of the Pan-African Ecovillage Development Programme to communities across the continent.

GEN is supporting long-term climate resilient strategies that are transforming lives here and now.

We need to boost our funding by £10,000 in order to continue supporting ecovillages across the African continent. Simultaneously, we are enabling a platform for climate activists from the Global South to attend the UN COP23 Climate Conference to spotlight practical solutions to climate change.

In exception of a 5% Indiegogo administration fee, 100% of your donation will support African communities through the expansion of the Pan-African Ecovillage Development Programme.

Perks

As a big thank you for your support, we are offering:

  • - £5 = A shout out on our Wall of Contributors!
  • - £20 = E-Book of Ecovillage: 1001 Ways to Heal the Planet (Kosha Joubert & Leila Dregger)  + wall of contributors
  • - £35 = Digital Communities Magazine: Ecovillages Around the World (#171) + E-book of Ecovillage: 1001 Ways + wall of contributors
  • - £50 = All of the above + Print book of Ecovillage: 1001 Ways + Print Communities Magazine (#171) (please specify your delivery address)
  • - £75 = All of the above + Personalised signed copy from Kosha Joubert of Ecovillage 1001 Ways & Communities Magazine (#171) (please specify your delivery address)
  • - £250 = All of the above + One hour consultancy session (with your choice from ecovillage experts: Kosha Joubert, Luc Lutala, Margarita Ozethelius, Samuel Kaboba, or Sarah Queblatin). You can find descriptions of their expertise in the perk sidebar.
  • - £500 = All of the above + Tap into the ecovillage expertise held within the GEN team: join us for a two hour creative session on any ecovillage questions of your choice.

To choose a perk, please select directly from the right-hand of your screen.

Changing Climate Change

Increasingly urgent action on climate change is vital.  NASA has announced that 2016 was the third hottest year running on record. Recent scientific modelling reveals that continued business as usual will score the range of temperature increase by 2100 between 4.78C to 7.36C -  temperatures not reached for at least 784,000 years... The extremity of hurricane Harvey weather events in the US has been linked to climate change...

Interestingly, the recent US government political backsliding on Paris climate agreements have in fact rallied US states and cities to uphold the agreement and evidence shows that the majority of US citizens oppose the administration’s decision. This has only strengthened our belief that active concerned citizens are central to the realisation of a carbon-neutral future. Against a backdrop of increasingly concerning data, thousands of community activists are taking action. We are here reaching out in solidarity to support climate mitigation in the economically poorest regions of the world. 

We have a long way to go in ensuring meaningful action on the part of all states. We believe it is up to concerned citizens to call for action and propose how our carbon footprint can be lowered while also addressing the other UN pillars: peace, the Sustainable Development Goals and human rights.

Together let’s stand together to catalyse the power of community to combat climate change

The Global Ecovillage Network

GEN was founded in 1995 to support communities that sustain and regenerate their social and natural environments. Today we represent thousands of communities globally and span five continental regions.

GEN believes that sustainable development can only emerge from local level, participatory collaboration and implementation. Therefore, the Ecovillage Development Programme begins from carefully inclusive community consultations led by communities every step of the way. GEN acts as a conduit for external expertise and guidance according to community need. Examples include support for ecological agriculture practices that regenerate topsoil, water collection techniques that support water security, community decision-making-processes that value all, including women, or low-tech clean cooking technologies.

Not able to donate?

We recognise that everyone has different financial means. Please only donate if you are capable and comfortable to do so.

If at this time you cannot donate to support the Pan-African Ecovillage Development Programme, we invite you to share this campaign on social media, with friends, family and colleagues!

You can also keep up to date with GEN's work by subscribing to our newsletter here.

Thank you for your support. Together, let's build a regenerative future.
story_txt:
Climate Resilience through Community Empowerment
Across the African continent climate change is having catastrophic consequences such as unpredictable and extreme weather, drought and famine, and species extinction. Tragically, these effects are leading to conflict, social dislocation and poverty for thousands of communities.
For decades and in recognition of such challenges, the Global Ecovillage Network (GEN) and thousands of ecovillage communities worldwide have been pioneering and demonstrating best practices and success stories both to mitigate and adapt to climate change.
GEN is spotlighting how locally-led climate resilience can be replicated and scaled up to achieve dramatic results and substantially improve the lives of people living in poor and rural communities - especially in the Global South.
Introducing the Pan-African Ecovillage Development Programme: an initiative forwarding participatory community consultations that couple locally-led needs analysis with international expertise in holistic design. This process is bringing regenerative solutions to African communities to support climate change mitigation and adaptation.
With your support, we can continue to expand the Ecovillage Development Programme across Africa.
Why Ecovillage Development?
Experience is showing us that community-led regenerative development works for communities. Now this approach is beginning to become recognised in the mainstream. GEN is supporting continued lobbying and implementation of the ecovillage development model. 

The Senegalese government is transforming 14,000 rural villages into ecovillages across the country.
In Egypt, the Sekem Farm and Ecovillage has developed programmes and initiatives over the last four decades that have transformed sustainable agricultural practices, provided access to herbal medicines and teas, and provided employment opportunities and holistic school programs that have benefited more than 40,000 local villagers.
The Democratic Republic of Congo is considering setting up a Ministry of Ecovillages.
Burkina Faso has decided to transition 2000 traditional communities to ecovillages by 2020.
Many ecovillage projects and national networks in other Sub-Saharan African countries such as Kenya, The Gambia, Zimbabwe, and Zambia are also adopting this approach.

Across the globe, ecovillages are already demonstrating that accessible solutions exist to mitigate and adapt to climate change. From low-tech natural carbon sequestration techniques, regenerative agricultural practices, large scale water retention landscape regeneration methods, and radically low ecological footprints, ecovillages are showcasing that the changes in lifestyle and consumption necessary to achieve ecological sustainability are attractive and attainable.
In addition to working on-the-ground, GEN is directly engaging governments and other powerful actors across Africa to spotlight the evident benefits of ecovillage development from countries already using the approach. Thus far we have seen remarkable buy-in. In this way, our strategy involves working directly with communities, national governments, United Nations agencies, and allied international civil society organisations to bring the benefits of the Pan-African Ecovillage Development Programme to communities across the continent.
GEN is supporting long-term climate resilient strategies that are transforming lives here and now.
We need to boost our funding by £10,000 in order to continue supporting ecovillages across the African continent. Simultaneously, we are enabling a platform for climate activists from the Global South to attend the UN COP23 Climate Conference to spotlight practical solutions to climate change.
In exception of a 5% Indiegogo administration fee, 100% of your donation will support African communities through the expansion of the Pan-African Ecovillage Development Programme.

Perks
As a big thank you for your support, we are offering:

- £5 = A shout out on our Wall of Contributors!
- £20 = E-Book of Ecovillage: 1001 Ways to Heal the Planet (Kosha Joubert & Leila Dregger)  + wall of contributors
- £35 = Digital Communities Magazine: Ecovillages Around the World (#171) + E-book of Ecovillage: 1001 Ways + wall of contributors
- £50 = All of the above + Print book of Ecovillage: 1001 Ways + Print Communities Magazine (#171) (please specify your delivery address)
- £75 = All of the above + Personalised signed copy from Kosha Joubert of Ecovillage 1001 Ways & Communities Magazine (#171) (please specify your delivery address)
- £250 = All of the above + One hour consultancy session (with your choice from ecovillage experts: Kosha Joubert, Luc Lutala, Margarita Ozethelius, Samuel Kaboba, or Sarah Queblatin). You can find descriptions of their expertise in the perk sidebar.
- £500 = All of the above + Tap into the ecovillage expertise held within the GEN team: join us for a two hour creative session on any ecovillage questions of your choice.

To choose a perk, please select directly from the right-hand of your screen.

Changing Climate Change
Increasingly urgent action on climate change is vital.  NASA has announced that 2016 was the third hottest year running on record. Recent scientific modelling reveals that continued business as usual will score the range of temperature increase by 2100 between 4.78C to 7.36C -  temperatures not reached for at least 784,000 years... The extremity of hurricane Harvey weather events in the US has been linked to climate change...
Interestingly, the recent US government political backsliding on Paris climate agreements have in fact rallied US states and cities to uphold the agreement and evidence shows that the majority of US citizens oppose the administration’s decision. This has only strengthened our belief that active concerned citizens are central to the realisation of a carbon-neutral future. Against a backdrop of increasingly concerning data, thousands of community activists are taking action. We have a long way to go in ensuring meaningful action on the part of all states. We believe it is up to concerned citizens to call for action and propose how our carbon footprint can be lowered while also addressing the other UN pillars: peace, the Sustainable Development Goals and human rights.

Examples include support for ecological agriculture practices that regenerate topsoil, water collection techniques that support water security, community decision-making-processes that value all, including women, or low-tech clean cooking technologies.

story: Campaign has ended.
story_txt: Campaign has ended.

story:
Help us save people and snakes. Together we can do more!

 

Who are we?

Sakaerat Najas Project is a small independent non-profit research project, dedicated to advancing current scientific knowledge and conservation of True Cobras. Our target species, the Indochinese Spitting Cobra Naja siamenis and the Monocled Cobra Naja kaouthia, both listed on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species and have population which are in decline throughout their range. Based at the Sakaerat Environmental Research Station, the project aims to improve cohabitation between humans and snakes to reduce human- snake conflicts within the rural communities of the UNESCO Sakaerat Biosphere Reserve. Oure small leadership team is supported by an internationally diverse mix of volunteers, eho allow the project to fulfil another of its goals - to provide opportunity and professional development for early career ecologists and research scientists from around the world.


Sakaerat Najas Project team as of September 2017.

 

What do we do?

Throughout the ages people have been fascinated by venomous animals. Often defenceless looking wildlife can be deadly to its prey, and to potential predators. Among the venomous animals, snakes are one of the most widespread and lethal to humans. Arguably one of the most misunderstood taxa in animal kingdom, there is little research conducted on these cryptic and seemingly uncharismatic slithering creatures. Venomous snakes, however, are of great medical importance.

To address the problem of wildlife conservation and human welfare we dedicate our lives to study one of the most recognisable genus among the venomous snakes – Naja (the True Cobras). Our focal species the Monocled Cobra Naja kouthia and the Indochinese Spitting Cobra Naja siamensis are together responsible for the second highest number of snake bite mortalities in Thailand.

We use radio telemetry to follow our study animals in the forests, villages, and agricultural areas of the reserve. This is the best available research technique to gather long term data on animals that are so elusive and shy. We collect information on their activity periods, habitat preferences and behaviour, with special attention towards human - snake interactions. To date, in 3 years of research, we have learned that cobras and other snakes live among people on a daily basis. They movie through fields, gardens and around houses in the villages while looking for food and shelter, usually completely unseen by their neighbours - humans.


Curtis and William at work radiotracking cobras in the vegetation. 

 

To keep both people and snakes safe, we provide a free snake removal service to the local communities.  Rescued snakes are then released back in to the surrounding fields. We make every effort to keep the snakes within their own natural home range. This may seem strange to some, but studies have shown mortality rates in translocated snakes may be as high as 70%. The aim of our project is to bring about long term benefits to people and snakes through improved cohabitation, not short term fixes by snake relocation.




Rescue of Indochinese Spitting Cobra Naja siamensis in the local village.


4 m King Cobra Ophiophagus hannah rescued by local volunteers made its way to TV news.

 


Photo after safe rescue of King Cobra Ophiophagus hannah in local temple grounds.

 

To empower the local communities, we participate in a snake handling training programme for local rescue teams. This initiative hosted by Sakaerat Conservation and Snake Education Team, provides training to rescue teams throughout the reserve and further afield. Using different handling techniques, we help Thai people to establish the skills necessary to safely work with potentially dangerous snakes. It is seen as a key aspect of our work in the community so that they may utilize, develop and pass on these skills for themselves long after we have gone.


Rescue teams snake handling training. 

 

Why not just get rid of the snakes?

With the decline in large and medium sized mammalian predators, such as tigers and other cats in tropical forests, large snakes may play an increasingly important role in ecosystems as upper level predators. Cobras provide a valuable ecosystem service to small scale farming communities by predating  crop pests such as mice and rats. Without natural controls, areas can quickly become overpopulated with rodents, which can carry diseases like leptospirosis or Lymphocytic Chorio-meningitis (LCM) which pose real threats to humans.


Monocled Cobra Naja kaouthia feeding on rat.

Despite the evident danger to humans, chemical analyses of snake venoms have resulted in major advances in medicine. Venom composition (and its use in medicine) varies from region to region even among the same species. Therefore, losing a single population of venomous snakes may severely limit the potential for future human medical advancements including possible treatments for cancer.

 

Indochinese Spitting Cobra Naja siamensis is listed as vulnerable on the IUCN red list and the Monocled Cobra Naja kaouthia is listed as a species of least concern. Both species are recognized as being in decline throughout their range. Despite their red list status, there is currently no conservation work being conducted. Both species of cobras are listed on appendix II of CITES.


Indochinese Spitting Cobra Naja siamensis  killed in local village. 

 

Snake bite problem

Rural communities play a vital role in the Thai economic system as the primary producers of agricultural products. Agriculture in Thailand poses many human health risks, one of which is venomous snake bites. At highest risk are agricultural workers in rural fields. Treatment of envenomated patients is both costly, and sometimes dangerous to victims, especially in cases where hospitals misidentify the venomous snake. In Thailand, cobras (Naja kaothia and Naja siamensis) account for a large proportion of envenomations each year and result in a high incidence of mortality. Eaven when not lethal, the effects of the venom can leave snake bite victims with debilitating and life changing injuries making them incapable of work. This shows a strong need for research on these animals to better understand their ecology and habitat use to reduce the number of future envenomations.

Links to some more reading about envenomation problem and video on venom effect on blood  are below:

  1. WHO Guidelines for snake bite management
  2. Russell's Viper venom effects on blood 
  3. Classic Google search

Recent study suggest a high percentage of envenomations are, in fact, the result of humans deliberately harassing snakes (The following are links to videos of professionals getting bitten on camera link 1, link 2), Our field observations to confirm that human harassment of snakes probably increases chances of snake bite. Many of the snakes we encounter during rescues only want to get away from the observer. We aim to address this issue through education and training, preventing accidental envenomation by developing a list of recommendations for rural communities to reduce unwanted encounters. However, continued long term research and community work are vital to the success of these project goals.


Our friend Hans helping us to deliver informational materials in local villages. 
 
 

Why we need your support?

As a non-profit project, our project does not generate any personal income for the researchers. Due to unpopular nature of our study species, there is limited interest for potential donators. Additionally, scientific grants often impose strict limitations on how funding can be used. Having financial backing from a source like crowd funding will allow us to allocate funds as they are needed. Should we be successful, funds would firstly be used to maintain and support the current project at Sakaerat Biosphere Reserve. Once the Sakaerat project is secured any extra funding or support would go towards the establishment of a second study site based at the Than Sadet National Park on the island of Koh Phangan in Southern Thailand.

The list below shows the equipment and expenses needed to maintain and develop the project:

  1. Food and accommodation for workers and volunteers,
  2. Petrol,
  3. Vehicles (motorcycles),
  4. Radiotracking equipment:
    • Radio transmitters (chips)
    • Radio receivers
    • Antennas
    • GPS
    • Kestrel weather device
  5. Camera traps
  6. Handling/safety equipment
  7. Processing equipment
  8. Snakes housing equipment
  9. Educational materials
  10. Promotional materials
  11. Endoscope
  12. Laboratory equipment
  13. Radiotracking drone

If you would like to support us with any of these items or in any other way instead of money, please feel free to contact us at najaresearch@gmail.com. We are especially interested in developing a drone to be used for radiotracking.

Let’s meet our friends!

Currently we radiotrack 10 individual snakes within forested and rural areas.

Naka012 -> Monocled Cobra male number 12 is the longest in our study. We have followed him in the Dry Evergreen Forest of Sakaerat since April 2015. He is our most beloved and demanding individual. He is capable of moving up to 1.5 kilometers (1 mile) through the dense forests. Over the years he's shown us great deal about his secretive life. Even now he can surprise us and disappear for days making us spend long hours wandering around the forests looking for a signal from his transmitter. During this time we have witnessed his struggles to survive. On several occasions he manage to outsmart a 3.5 m snake eating King Cobra Ophiophagus hannah, a Hog badger Arctonyx collaris  and a huge monitor lizard Varanus sp. His convex polygon home range is the biggest from all of our study animals with over 540 ha which makes our work a great challenge.

 

Nasi025-> This male Indochinese Spitting Cobra is living in a nearby village. This snake is often found in people's gardens and under their homes. This is very shy individual that is rarely seen even by us. Recently he took shelter behind our favorite ice cream shop which makes tracking this guy sweet change from chasing forest cobras.

 

 

Other ways you can help us

  • SHARE this page with all your friends!
  • Follow us on social media!  Like us on Facebook watch us on Youtube and visit our website.

Talk to us - we'd love your feedback about our project! (najaresearch@gmail.com)

Thank you!

story:
Harvest Chapel Mission Inc. (HCM) is a 501C-3 non-profit started in 2004, to help develop small farm equipment for farmers in the U.S. and abroad.  We have a diesel powered hammer-mill and other equipment currently operating at missions in Sierra Leone, Ghana, Uganda, and Haiti.  This equipment has helped reduce farm labor substantially. 

In the case of grinding cassava root, which is labor intensively hand processed mostly by women; a 3 week task for 2 women, has been reduced to 4 hours using less than a gallon of fuel. (A 60 fold productivity increase)  Additionally, we currently have press equipment in Sierra Leone undergoing testing that is able to press palm oil, on the farm, that can be used as an alternate (carbon neutral) fuel.  

The 10 hp air cooled diesel engines we have been using in our equipment currently do not meet EPA emission standards. Our goal is to certify these engines to the latest emission standards for, off road, stationary use, compression ignition, engines, and offer them for sale to homesteader's in the U.S. and to missionaries working overseas.  The 7.5 Kw per hour LSE power plant is lower cost than a 5 Kw per day solar panel system.  It will run on  a carbon neutral fuel, and supply enough power to operate most small farm equipment, a shop, or other homestead needs.

Design Features/Goals:

10 hp (7.5 kw) multi-fuel engine

30 percent better fuel economy than a similar size gasoline engine

2 tank system to start/stop on diesel fuel with heated vegetable oil tank

Water induction

Hand/electric start

Easy to disassemble for air transport as checked baggage

 

We project the cost to develop and certify the LSE power plant to be 35,000 dollars.  Any additional money received above the actual costs will be used to send LSE powered farm equipment with missionaries working overseas.

Please visit our website for additional information: www.harvestchapelmission.org.  If you have a mission that you think could benefit from this equipment please e-mail us at:  harvestchapelmission@yahoo.com.

THE ENERGY CONTENT OF ONE GALLON OF DIESEL FUEL OR VEGETABLE OIL IS EQUIVALENT TO THE PHYSICAL LABOR OF ONE PERSON FOR 3 WEEKS

THANK YOU!

story:
Have you seen cats in yellow hats popping up in your Instagram feed? Cute as they are, they are really cats for a cause. 

In 2014, I launched a GoFundMe campaign when I could no longer work a traditional job due to complications from severe Lyme disease. With the help of family, friends, and one generous soul I've never met, I raised a few thousand dollars, which enabled me to self-publish my first children’s book, Oliver Poons and the Bright Yellow Hat, of which I am the author, my mother is the illustrator, and my lovable rescue cat, Oliver, is the inspiration behind the main character.

It’s now two years later and we have incorporated our books into the Oliver Poons Children’s Company with a mission to inspire “Happy Children, Happy Causes, and Happy Careers” through the sale of our products. 

We have several causes close to our heart:

  • Animal Rescue. Those cats in yellow hats are a part of our #YellowHatsforCats campaign where a portion of our proceeds from our children’s books are donated to animal welfare organizations to help other rescue cats like my Oliver. 
  • Children in Need. Oliver Poons and his friends are happy children’s characters who bring a little whimsy and fun into the day, yet whose sweet and innocent nature make for the perfect bedtime story. At the Oliver Poons Children’s Company, we believe every child deserves a happy day and happy dreams. By sponsoring a book for a child in need, you, too, will bring a smile to a child’s face. 

  • Alternative Work. The Oliver Poons Children’s Company was created partly because of my inability to work a traditional job from a prolonged illness with Lyme disease. My mother (the illustrator) was also recovering from a severely broken ankle and unable to work a traditional job herself for an extended period of time. We have been able to repurpose our skills and create new work for ourselves despite challenges. Now, we’re helping others do the same through a new website, differentwork.org. By purchasing a book, a portion of the sale will go toward helping to further develop this platform. 

Why is it the time for this campaign NOW?

As our #YellowHatsforCats campaign has grown online, thousands of people have now read our story. On almost a daily basis, I receive heart-wrenching messages from followers who find themselves in situations similar to mine. They are experiencing the first hand effects of a debilitating illness or life-altering circumstance. They are at a loss as to what to do or where to turn. Everyone I talk to has a unique skill set and a desire to be productive despite their limitations, but cannot do it alone. The solution that came to me was developing an online platform, differentwork.org, to connect people to share their skill-sets and create new possibilities. 

Goals

We are aiming to initially raise $100,000. With your support, we will be able to:

  • Send books to children in need.
  • Support animal rescue efforts.
  • Help create alternative work for those who find themselves in unfortunate situations. 

The more messages from others in need of help I receive, the more I realize how much more could be done to build out our platforms (and how much quicker it could be done) with additional funding. We have the foundation in place, it's with help from generous contributors like YOU that can make it grow exponentially and have a significant impact on those in need.

Perks

We're keeping the perks strictly donation-based and simple for this campaign. For each $20 contributed, a book will be sent to a child in need. We are partnered with children's hospitals, relief organizations, and literacy programs for children in underprivileged communities. Your contribution will also support animal welfare organizations and differentwork.org.  

Additionally, EVERY contributor is going to receive a special thank you on a "Contributors" page on differentwork.org. If you'd like, you can also write a short message to inspire others that will appear on the site. If you have a website of your own, you're welcome to include that too. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Since we're keeping our perks for this campaign limited to book sponsorships for children in need, if you'd like a signed copy of our books or other Oliver Poons products for yourself or others in your life, please order from our website at oliverpoons.com. You're supporting us just the same!
  • Post your cat in a yellow hat on Instagram with #yellowhatsforcats! 
  • Tell your friends about differentwork.org and/or make a profile with your own skills! The more users on the site, the more useful the site will become!
  • Share our campaign with others & follow us on social media!

Post your cat in a yellow hat on Instagram with #yellowhatsforcats!

Share our campaign with others & follow us on social media!

story:
Short Summary

Four years have passed since we started this journey. This is the year it all comes together:

  • Since Fetch began in 2012 we have visited 39 states, helped raise 1.5 million for other charities, started the country's first Service Dog Education Conference, connected dozens of people with canine assistance, published a book, were honored by the AKC, AHA, Rotary Club, The 10th Congressional District and more, and we performed acts of kindness for people around the world all thanks to the generosity of our community and we have impacted companies large and small and even changed many a corporate culture to make accessibility for people with assistance dogs easier.
  •  From the beginning, our goal was to simply write a book about our travels and raise awareness about PTSD, Suicide Prevention and Canine Assistance. This year we are heading back in that direction while not abandoning missions we have accepted along the way.
  • With your help this year we can impact millions. 

What We Need & What You Get:

There are $25,000 worth of perks listed below to reward you for your help. 

Here is our plan for 2017:

  • We now have almost 180,000 on our vehicle. It is less than four years old. We need a reliable vehicle and one that can carry our supplies to expos and events. We have found several used vans with very low mileage that can suit our needs. 
  • I have dreamed of traveling the U.S. for these last four years. I have sought hard for an inexpensive camper that can save us travel money and give us the security we need to be safe, and secure during our travels. We have found one!  
  • We have added several very cool perks and we have included those older popular perks that we will be phasing out this year. 
  • We have to reach our goal to continue!

Exciting News: 

Team Oliver, the UK group that donates to dozens of initiatives worldwide and has helped us reach goals many times, is providing matching funds for this campaign! They will match any donations up $1000!!

The Impact

Here is the plan:

  • We will travel to two dozen states and give presentations to groups as we go. We are now part of the Rotary Club Speakers Bureau and have a goal to give over a hundred presentations in 2017. 
  • We will play taps every day at sundown beginning January 1, 2017. We will live cast daily and read the names of 22 veterans and civilians who lost their lives to suicide.
  • We will present a flag with ten of thousands of signatures, memorials and well wishes at an SEC football game during the week of veterans day. More on that later.  
  • We will finish our book Fetch: Travels with Gander 
  • We will perform acts of kindness where and when we can with the support of this community.
  • We will hold the third annual service dog education conference.
  • We will maintain our online community of 400,000  .

Risks & Challenges

 

  • We WANT to travel. We have the generous support of the folks at Amazing Pet Expos and will travel to over a dozen of their events in 2017. We will sell treats and merchandise to fund our overall journey at these expos. 
  • We cannot do any of this without a new vehicle and a camper trailer. .

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
My story, My campaign.

Hi dear, i am Emmanuel Authentic, a tertiary student and a part-time rice farmer. i reside on campus and hardly get time to work in my farm plantation in seasons or times like this when school has resumed. Due to financial constraints, i am unable to employ people to work and look after my farm for me when school resumes. my rice plantation by far is about 200metres wide and 400metres long. With the explicit cultivation tools, i can expand it doubly but lack of finance has been an obstacle.

Contributers support is going too give me the mandate to employ 10 to 15 people to work in my rice farm and also enable me to expand my rice plantation and save it from collapsing.

I need $1000 from this campaign of which 60% shall be used to employ people to work in my rice farm. the remaining 40% shall be used to acquire cultivation equipments.

i also have available some perks which are worth acquiring.

my funds when met shall be used judisciously as described and effeciently in other to yield greater returns to finance the paerks.

my project provides a major source of food to the people living in the locality where i find myself. to the contributor, my project shall grant him a sense of achievement in changing the lives of other people somewhere in the soils of Africa precisely Ghana.

To the country in which i reside, it will aid reduce the number of unemployment rate.

The only risk i stand facing in my rice plantation business is the risk of lower crop yield, which most often than not occur as result of birds feeding on my matured / riped rice. with the financial support i shall receive, i will purchase a net to cover the plantation to prevent birds from destroying the riped/matured rice.

 

your inabiity to support my project financially notwithstanding, i would love you to comment on my project by providing feedback and would pray you also to share my project campaign so as to attract sponsors. dont forget to use the indiegogo sharing tools.

thank you very much.

 i really appreciate your financial and other supports.

story:
Short Summary

Aloha, my name is Raven Ea, I am the Founder and Chief Science Officer for Second Skin Organics. 

  • When I was 18, I moved to Hawaii to start a farm and raise a family. I was pregnant with my son and literally getting eaten alive by mosquitoes, but because of the potential side effects of DEET, I went seeking an organic solution instead. Second Skin was created out of a personal need to organically protect myself, my unborn child, my 4 year old and my family safely and effectively. 
  • It has never been so urgent to get these Solutions into more hands. Second Skin has been tested around the Globe for over a decade with a 99.99% Efficacy rate and is Doctor recommended as safe and effective. 
  • We have been in production and distribution in Hawaii since 2004. I started Second Skin with a measuring cup in my kitchen, now we stock over 150 stores throughout Hawaii, the US Mainland, and ship globally via USPS. 
  • Large Scale Global distribution requires Large Scale Global production, you will help us achieve this!

What We Need & What You Get

Thank You for Your Generous Support to this Campaign!

  • It costs $2.00 to produce 1 bottle of spray.
  • We are launching this campaign to raise $100,000 to expand our global distribution and multinational manufacturing to get these solutions into the hands of more people in need! 
  • Our perks are specialized in our way of saying THANK YOU to support everyday needs and self empowerment for a busy lifestyle on the go! 
  • We Must Reach Our Goal, so that we can expand our footprint here in Hawaii by implementing more Sustainable Organic Agriculture practices and continue to grow exponentially.

The Impact

Your contribution will enable us to help more people in more places immediately. We will expand production and the global availability for those in need. 

  • We are already partnering with Contract Manufacturers in the US and abroad who are ready to GO with mass production.
  • Once funds are raised, we will immediately produce the massive scale of inventory that is being demanded globally. 
  • Your donation will also support the expansion of Sustainable Organic Agricultural practices in Hawaii by increasing the Organic NonGMO footprint, by educating and training more Hawaiian Farmers to generate an additional stream of income through this economic opportunity. 

Risks & Challenges

The Risk is not producing fast enough. We need to reach our goals quickly so that we can compound inventory production to meet the Global demand as it continues to grow exponentially.

  • No one in our industry does what we do. That is probably why it has had the intense challenges of a grassroots company as this is a HUGE Mission and Vision, not only for Hawaii, but for Our Planet as a whole. 
  • I have been producing and manufacturing Second Skin for over a decade, our formulations are solid and ready to be quantified, but without funding to produce the inventory we cannot meet the demand.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't financially contribute to this campaign, you can help us in other ways!

  • Please Like and Share this video on your Social Media Channels
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!

Mahalo Nui Loa for your generous support of this Mission and Vision for the future generations to come. We cannot do it without you!

story:
Friends of the Trail has been conducting large scale cleanups on your public lands and waterways in Washington State since 1996.  This work directly benefits the public, the environment, and the communities where our projects are ongoing.  Our program is the most efficient and effective way to deal with the problem of illegal dumping/littering.  We utilize volunteers and folks who owe community service hours to society, and cleanup and properly dispose of 100 tons of debris per year on average, as well as tires, vehicles and appliances.
Our work trucks (2) are the lifeblood of our organization, and our 2002 truck is plum wore out.  Please help us to continue our efforts and help fund a new truck.

story:
A jar of Beeyond honey saves elephants!

Deforestation, poaching, and fragmentation have comfortably secured the Asian elephant a spot on the endangered species list. Human-elephant conflicts, often resulting in death, are increasing every day. Methods to stop elephants from crop raiding are often expensive and unsustainable.

Researchers in Africa, however, have discovered that elephants are afraid of bees. As such, beehive fencing is the latest and greatest hope in avoiding human-elephant conflicts. No other solution protects humans and elephants simultaneously in such a sustainable way.

Why should you care? Because without bees or elephants, even our own future is at risk! We need your help now to realize this project so that people and elephants can live together and so that biodiversity can thrive once again. 

Please visit the Bring the Elephant Home website to contribute now!

Thank you!

Antoinette van de Water

and the Bring the Elephant Home-team

Bring the Elephant Home

Project Dragonfly, Miami University


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $3,000 in order to install beehive fences in the areas that need them most. The more the raise, the better we can do.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this campaign on all of your social media pages. Check out the Indiegogo sharing tools!
  • Join our elephant art auction at Ebay-Bring the Elephant Home
  • Join us on Facebook www.facebook.com/BTEHpage/?fref=ts
  • Travel sustainably: take your time to visit National Parks to see elephants in the wild, instead of tourist camps to interact with elephants in captivity. 
  • Plant bee-friendly flowers and herbs. 



Perks

  • PLEDGE $1 - THANK YOU!

    • We appreciate your support. Every dollar helps.

  • PLEDGE $5 - SOCIAL MEDIA SHOUT OUT!

    • We will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. 

  • PLEDGE $10 - YOUR NAME ON OUR WEBSITE

    • YOUR NAME will be listed in the “Supported By” page of our bring-the-elephant-home.org website. Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. 

  • PLEDGE $15 - PERSONALIZED E-CARD FROM BEE THE CHANGE

    • We’ll send you a personalized E-CARD signed by our team. Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.

  • PLEDGE $25 - BEE THE CHANGE T-SHIRT

    • A unique collection, exclusively for scientists, rangers, staff and volunteers of the project... and you! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.


  • PLEDGE $35 - A JAR OF BEEYOND HONEY

    • Get a little honey for your money! A small jar (120 ml) will give you a taste of the first harvest of Honey! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.


  • PLEDGE $50 - EXOTIC BEEYOND HONEY GIFTSET

    • A small jar of honey (120 ml), packed in a gift box with some elephant and bee related items from Thailand! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.


  • PLEDGE $100 - EXOTIC BEE THE CHANGE GIFTSET

    • A small jar (120 ml) and a big jar (220 ml)of honey, a Bee the Change t-shirt, packed in a gift box with some elephant and bee related items from Thailand! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.


  • PLEDGE $250 - ADOPT A BEEHIVE

    • We will write your name on a beehive or the name you give to the queen bee! You will receive a set of pictures of your hive and bees as well as a jar of honey from your very own hive! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.

    Conservation action needed now! 

    Recently, Bring the Elephant Home conducted two surveys in order to measure the impact of human-elephant conflicts (HECs) on the livelihood of people living near the wild elephant habitats in Kanchanaburi. HECs are intense in this area: 54% of participants stated that their plantations are raided by elephants on a daily basis. The attitude of plantation owners toward wild elephants is far from positive, with 70% of plantation owners preferring that elephants be eradicated altogether.

     Wild elephant electrocuted by an electric fence at a farm in Kanchanaburi.

    The interest in beehive fencing among this group is exceptionally high. Even farmers with a very negative attitude toward the elephants are interested in trying a new sustainable solution to find a solution and to live in harmony with them. 

    Why should you care?

    Because without elephants or bees, even our own species future is at risk. 

    Elephants and bees have something in common: as keystone species, they both make life possible for a range of species and, therefore, are important in maintaining the ecosystem and even our lives. The removal of a keystone species will have negative consequences on many other species that depend on them. Honeybees are keystone species because they are pollinators. Elephants make life possible for others by creating grass fields, salt licks, trails, and water holes, and many plant species depend on elephants for seed dispersal and germination. 

    Beehive fencing is a new and sustainable solution to avoid crop raiding in areas highly trafficked by elephants. It is a natural solution that shows that everything in nature is connected and provides many benefits for all involved. Local communities generate income through the harvest of honey. Bees improve the biodiversity of forests and increase crop yields by means of pollination, and elephants suffer less from encounters with farmers.

    By using beehives as a deterrent strategy, the bees are helping to create harmony in a situation of conflict, whilst improving the biodiversity of the world. 


    WE NEED YOUR HELP!

    If you would like to help us creating  more beehive fences, please donate to this campaign.


    HELP SPREAD THE WORD!

    After you complete your transaction, Indiegogo will give you the option to send a message to your friends and followers on Facebook and Twitter.

    This message will inform your friends that you just backed “BEE THE CHANGE” and will include a link to our campaign page (you'll be able to edit the text). Please send these messages! It only takes a second and it'll be a huge help!


    THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!


    Pictures by Vivi Sriaram, Ana Grillo and the Phuluang Wildlife Research Station.

    THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

    Special thanks to:

    Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund (CEPF) of IUCN, Fondation Ensemble and ASN Foundation for their financial support for this project.


    Go to www.bring-the-elephant-home.org 

    for more information about this project.
story_txt:
A jar of Beeyond honey saves elephants!



Deforestation, poaching, and fragmentation have comfortably secured the Asian elephant a spot on the endangered species list. Human-elephant conflicts, often resulting in death, are increasing every day. Methods to stop elephants from crop raiding are often expensive and unsustainable.Researchers in Africa, however, have discovered that elephants are afraid of bees. As such, beehive fencing is the latest and greatest hope in avoiding human-elephant conflicts. No other solution protects humans and elephants simultaneously in such a sustainable way.
Why should you care? Because without bees or elephants, even our own future is at risk! We need your help now to realize this project so that people and elephants can live together and so that biodiversity can thrive once again. Please visit the Bring the Elephant Home website to contribute now!
Thank you!Antoinette van de Waterand the Bring the Elephant Home-teamBring the Elephant HomeProject Dragonfly, Miami University

What We Need & What You Get 

We are looking to raise $3,000 in order to install beehive fences in the areas that need them most. The more the raise, the better we can do.







Other Ways You Can Help




Please share this campaign on all of your social media pages. Check out the Indiegogo sharing tools!

Join our elephant art auction at Ebay-Bring the Elephant Home


Join us on Facebook www.facebook.com/BTEHpage/?fref=ts

Travel sustainably: take your time to visit National Parks to see elephants in the wild, instead of tourist camps to interact with elephants in captivity. 
Plant bee-friendly flowers and herbs. 







Perks
 


PLEDGE $1 - THANK YOU!
We appreciate your support. Every dollar helps.
PLEDGE $5 - SOCIAL MEDIA SHOUT OUT!
We will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. 
PLEDGE $10 - YOUR NAME ON OUR WEBSITE
YOUR NAME will be listed in the “Supported By” page of our bring-the-elephant-home.org website. Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. 

PLEDGE $15 - PERSONALIZED E-CARD FROM BEE THE CHANGE
We’ll send you a personalized E-CARD signed by our team. Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.
PLEDGE $25 - BEE THE CHANGE T-SHIRT
A unique collection, exclusively for scientists, rangers, staff and volunteers of the project... and you! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.
PLEDGE $35 - A JAR OF BEEYOND HONEY
Get a little honey for your money! A small jar (120 ml) will give you a taste of the first harvest of Honey! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.









PLEDGE $50 - EXOTIC BEEYOND HONEY GIFTSET
A small jar of honey (120 ml), packed in a gift box with some elephant and bee related items from Thailand! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.

PLEDGE $100 - EXOTIC BEE THE CHANGE GIFTSET
A small jar (120 ml) and a big jar (220 ml)of honey, a Bee the Change t-shirt, packed in a gift box with some elephant and bee related items from Thailand! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page.

PLEDGE $250 - ADOPT A BEEHIVE
We will write your name on a beehive or the name you give to the queen bee! You will receive a set of pictures of your hive and bees as well as a jar of honey from your very own hive! Plus, we will personally thank you for your generous donation via the Bee the Change event page of our Facebook page. And you’ll be listed on the bring-the-elephant-home.org “Supported By” page. 



Conservation action needed now! 
Recently, Bring the Elephant Home conducted two surveys in order to measure the impact of human-elephant conflicts (HECs) on the livelihood of people living near the wild elephant habitats in Kanchanaburi. HECs are intense in this area: 54% of participants stated that their plantations are raided by elephants on a daily basis. The attitude of plantation owners toward wild elephants is far from positive, with 70% of plantation owners preferring that elephants be eradicated altogether.


 Wild elephant electrocuted by an electric fence at a farm in Kanchanaburi.

The interest in beehive fencing among this group is exceptionally high. Even farmers with a very negative attitude toward the elephants are interested in trying a new sustainable solution to find a solution and to live in harmony with them. 


Why should you care?Because without elephants or bees, even our own species future is at risk. 
Elephants and bees have something in common: as keystone species, they both make life possible for a range of species and, therefore, are important in maintaining the ecosystem and even our lives. The removal of a keystone species will have negative consequences on many other species that depend on them. Honeybees are keystone species because they are pollinators. Elephants make life possible for others by creating grass fields, salt licks, trails, and water holes, and many plant species depend on elephants for seed dispersal and germination. 
Beehive fencing is a new and sustainable solution to avoid crop raiding in areas highly trafficked by elephants. It is a natural solution that shows that everything in nature is connected and provides many benefits for all involved. Local communities generate income through the harvest of honey. Bees improve the biodiversity of forests and increase crop yields by means of pollination, and elephants suffer less from encounters with farmers.
By using beehives as a deterrent strategy, the bees are helping to create harmony in a situation of conflict, whilst improving the biodiversity of the world. 



 
WE NEED YOUR HELP!
If you would like to help us creating  more beehive fences, please donate to this campaign.

HELP SPREAD THE WORD!
After you complete your transaction, Indiegogo will give you the option to send a message to your friends and followers on Facebook and Twitter.
This message will inform your friends that you just backed “BEE THE CHANGE” and will include a link to our campaign page (you'll be able to edit the text). Please send these messages! It only takes a second and it'll be a huge help!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!





Pictures by Vivi Sriaram, Ana Grillo and the Phuluang Wildlife Research Station.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!
