story:
Our waste problem in the US is massive and growing

Despite being only 4% of the world's population, the U.S. contributes over 12% of waste.  The majority of this waste is either incinerated or will end up in a landfill where it will endlessly pollute the earth, leach into the groundwater, and emit greenhouse gasses into the air.  All of these issues increase the health risk to our planet as well as every living creature inhabiting it.  

With most of the focus on the 268 million tons of municipal solid waste produced each year in the U.S., you may think that is the full extent or bulk of the problem.  In fact we produce 2x as much in our construction and demolition waste and 28x for our industrial waste.  These are massive problems that have been given little attention or investment and the destruction of our planet is the result.  With your support we can make a difference.

RE:PURPOSE

We are facing many challenges in America today, and we thought, what if we could find a project that could solve more than one problem, help us fund our projects for improving our nation's sustainability, increase awareness and represent our principles.  What would this project be?  This would have to be a product or service that people need and want, without creating more waste.  This would have to be something easy to understand and explain.

As the mission of our first campaign had the theme and purpose to Reduce Waste, our project had to line up with that goal.  We settled on the repurposing of textile waste in the creation of new items.  By upcycling these materials designed for landfills or incinerators, we could both divert waste and eliminate the resource-intensive process of creating the textiles that would otherwise be required to produce the same item.

It was obvious that it would be better for the environment if we could create desirable, needed products from diverted waste textiles and materials.  Save natural resources and prevent the further polluting of our environment.  But we thought we can do even better than that.  We can increase awareness with a brand that not only represents the practice of waste reduction and sustainability but supports the mission of The Zero Waste Projects.

But perhaps the best part of this project was the idea to use our American workforce, displaced by globalization and the covid pandemic to create these products right here in America.  We can use sustainable (waste-reducing) practice to clean up our country, create value in our marketplace, generate income for the American workforce, and improve our nation's economy, all in one project.

This was the birth of our brand RE:BEL.  A purpose brand, on a mission, to make America the global Zero Waste leader and clean up our country.

A little about us

Nearly 20 years ago an episode of This Old House visited a Material Recovery Facility where Norm toured what appeared to be a new way that all trash should and would be processed. This was the first time I had seen a single-stream recycling project and that concept excited me and I had never forgotten that experience. Back to present-day America and 4 billion metric tons of waste​ later, why are we still making mountains of trash throughout our nation's communities? And better yet, why are we not maximizing and capitalizing on this valuable resource?

We took a look at the issue and found some clear and disturbing reasons why our country still produces so much waste and has fallen behind in the effort to effectively manage our waste​-​stream.

This is why we decided to do our part, with the clear and ambitious goal of "Zero Waste," and with your help, we can make America the world leader in waste recovery and sustainability.

Three Principles

We established three principles where we would identify the opportunities for improvement within our economy and waste-stream.  Reduce, recycle, and reclaim.  We have set off to create projects aimed to maximize these three principles in a fashion that would provide the most beneficial impact in the most economical way to maximize both the reduction of waste and economic benefit.

  • Reduce - Our projects should incorporate the principle of reducing waste that enters the stream.  This can be through eliminating items or even repurposing them to divert waste away from our waste management process altogether.
  • Recycle - The idea to recycle has mostly fallen short of expectations.  We can take a material and return it to the production line in the same form (recycle), return it to the production line as a more valuable material (upcycle), or return it to the production line as a less valuable material (downcycle).  All three of these methods are viable and will divert material for better use and reduce the need for virgin resources.
  • Reclaim - The final step in this process is to turn the material into energy or a biological process designed to recover the potential of a material destined to be wasted in a landfill.  A complete transformation of this material will provide a new use while preventing waste, pollution, and resource exploitation.

Each project should take into account these three principles through designs that maximize these principles in an economically profitable solution to a waste-stream problem.

Mission

The mission of the Zero Waste Projects is to address the reduction, recycling, and reclamation of waste through various projects and partnerships to reenvision how we manage waste to achieve our mission of a sustainable nation.

It is no longer sufficient to seek economically viable solutions.  Breaking even is not a scalable business model.  With​ a truly profitable waste reduction and sustainability projects, we can attract the kind of investment and interest required to address the scale of this problem faster.

Landfills

Every year approximatly 90% of the 268 Million tons of Municipal Solid Waste produced in the U.S. each year is incinerated or burried. About half will be sent to one of 2000+ active municipal landfills.  With over 3000 active and closed landfills and tens of thousand of additional private dumps that currently or will eventually present an ecological crisis for a local community.  Below is a map showing the extent of the problem as it is know to exist today.

 

Recycling

Recycling has a role to play in our waste solution, but what most people do not see is how little waste is recycled and the effect that this illusion has on how much waste we produce.  After all, if we recycled everything, why not just produce as much as we want.  The reality is that even a recycled item requires energy to produce and transport.  The best item to use is one that you already own, saving the resources and pollution that would have otherwise resulted.  Below is a chart showing the current averages of recycling for the base constituents of our waste. 

There is a misconception that when you place your items in a recycling bin in the U.S. that those items will be sent to a local facility and turned into a new item, creating a system of regeneration.  In fact, for decades, our inability to profitably manage these materials has lead to the majority being exported to less developed nations, promarily China.  Our recycling programs were a creation of the plastics industry, were never designed to 

After China banned the importing of plastics for recycling the amount of plastic that was landfilled an incinerated exploded as there were not enough buyers of the kind of plastic waste we produced and we have long been deficient in our ability to profitable recycle most plastics domestically, 40 years later.

With new technologies and a rise in the international pressure of developing counties to better manage waste, we are starting to see for the first time, viable solutions for making cost-effective recycling a domestic reality.  But this will represent an enormous challenge as it will require massive capital inventment to create the thousands of facilities that would be required to address these 268 million tons of waste annually for a zero waste solution.

Ocean Plastics Problem

Even if we are able to recycle plastic 100%, plastics themselves still represent many environmental challenges that would require attention.  The damage to the environment from the drilling and fracking aside, plastic will still find its way into our environment, outside of our waste stream, and into natural habitats.  One such alarming case is the rise of the Ocean Plastic threat.  A material that does not degrade and only gets smaller has become a crisis for aquatic life.  Plastic is found in nearly all wild fish, with many marine animals starving with stomachs full of undigestable plastics, making them feel full or unable to eat or digest food.  In fact, this same microplastic is found in nearly every human on the planet.  We consume volumes of plastic but are not yet aware of the prolonged heath effects of these microplastics in our bodies as they increase with no end in sight.

The Good News

With awareness, education, and technological development, we can solve this problem.  Now that the problem is evident we can use that knowledge to direct logical effort to solve the problems we have created and preventing new ones.

The Zero Waste Projects were created with the mission to promote zero waste practices and sustainability within the U.S., end the practice of landfilling, and find the best ways to utilize our resources for a healthier planet.

There is no one solution and even solutions like recycling create complacency that increases waste and pollution.  We must treat our resources as finite and valuable, conserving these resources and through this, our planet.

The Zero Waste Projects

Through a series of projects, we will bring real solutions to our communities to address the reduction of waste to improvements in recycling waste and then reclaiming the resources that cannot be recycled.

 

We intend of starting with three projects that you can support through this campaign.

Business:

Bring to local businesses a simple platform to find and order sustainable products to replace those they already use while supporting "The Zero Waste Project.

Educate business owners on "best practices" for reducing business waste and environmental pollution.

Education:

Youth engagement is a pivotal part of our campaign as grade-schoolers will champion environmental advocacy and resilience in the future.

Teaching ways students can help solve our waste crisis and help achieve circularity by giving students tools and information to learn about Society's role in waste production and Climate Science.

Awareness:

Social Media outlets allow us to spread our information across different mediums and platforms to allow us to engage and connect to a plentiful and diverse audience.

With the common goal of achieving Zero Waste through a variety of games, challenges, and informative anecdotes.

Contribute to our campaign

Help us to bring zero waste solutions, education and awareness to our comunities with your docation.  You can choose just one project, all three or an overall Super Supporter and donate to the mission as a whole.  Join our network and newsletter to follow the progress and see how your contribution is making a difference in our communities and bringing us closer to the sustainable future we desere for which you will be proud to pass on to our future generations.

If you support Zero Waste how else can you contribute?

For anyone simply unable to contribute financially, there are things that you can do to help us with our mission and you can play an important role:

  • Add our campaign to your social media feeds so that like-minded people can find our message and support our cause.
  • Tell your friends personally and ask them to check out our website.
  • Reduce your waste personally and encourage others to do the same.

Add us to your social media platforms

                         

And that's all there is to it.

We are facing many challenges in America today, and we thought, what if we could find a project that could solve more than one problem, help us fund our projects for improving our nation's sustainability, increase awareness and represent our principles.  What would this project be?  This would have to be a product or service that people need and want, without creating more waste.  This would have to be something easy to understand and explain.
As the mission of our first campaign had the theme and purpose to Reduce Waste, our project had to line up with that goal.  We settled on the repurposing of textile waste in the creation of new items.  By upcycling these materials designed for landfills or incinerators, we could both divert waste and eliminate the resource-intensive process of creating the textiles that would otherwise be required to produce the same item.
It was obvious that it would be better for the environment if we could create desirable, needed products from diverted waste textiles and materials.  Save natural resources and prevent the further polluting of our environment.  But we thought we can do even better than that.  We can increase awareness with a brand that not only represents the practice of waste reduction and sustainability but supports the mission of The Zero Waste Projects.
But perhaps the best part of this project was the idea to use our American workforce, displaced by globalization and the covid pandemic to create these products right here in America.  We can use sustainable (waste-reducing) practice to clean up our country, create value in our marketplace, generate income for the American workforce, and improve our nation's economy, all in one project.
This was the birth of our brand RE:BEL.  A purpose brand, on a mission, to make America the global Zero Waste leader and clean up our country.
A little about us
Nearly 20 years ago an episode of This Old House visited a Material Recovery Facility where Norm toured what appeared to be a new way that all trash should and would be processed. This was the first time I had seen a single-stream recycling project and that concept excited me and I had never forgotten that experience. Back to present-day America and 4 billion metric tons of waste​ later, why are we still making mountains of trash throughout our nation's communities? And better yet, why are we not maximizing and capitalizing on this valuable resource?
We took a look at the issue and found some clear and disturbing reasons why our country still produces so much waste and has fallen behind in the effort to effectively manage our waste​-​stream.
This is why we decided to do our part, with the clear and ambitious goal of "Zero Waste," and with your help, we can make America the world leader in waste recovery and sustainability.
Three Principles
We established three principles where we would identify the opportunities for improvement within our economy and waste-stream.  Reduce, recycle, and reclaim.  We have set off to create projects aimed to maximize these three principles in a fashion that would provide the most beneficial impact in the most economical way to maximize both the reduction of waste and economic benefit.

Reduce - Our projects should incorporate the principle of reducing waste that enters the stream.  This can be through eliminating items or even repurposing them to divert waste away from our waste management process altogether.
Recycle - The idea to recycle has mostly fallen short of expectations.  We can take a material and return it to the production line in the same form (recycle), return it to the production line as a more valuable material (upcycle), or return it to the production line as a less valuable material (downcycle).  All three of these methods are viable and will divert material for better use and reduce the need for virgin resources.
Reclaim - The final step in this process is to turn the material into energy or a biological process designed to recover the potential of a material destined to be wasted in a landfill.  A complete transformation of this material will provide a new use while preventing waste, pollution, and resource exploitation.

Each project should take into account these three principles through designs that maximize these principles in an economically profitable solution to a waste-stream problem.
Mission
The mission of the Zero Waste Projects is to address the reduction, recycling, and reclamation of waste through various projects and partnerships to reenvision how we manage waste to achieve our mission of a sustainable nation.
It is no longer sufficient to seek economically viable solutions.  Breaking even is not a scalable business model.  With​ a truly profitable waste reduction and sustainability projects, we can attract the kind of investment and interest required to address the scale of this problem faster.
Landfills
Every year approximatly 90% of the 268 Million tons of Municipal Solid Waste produced in the U.S. each year is incinerated or burried. About half will be sent to one of 2000+ active municipal landfills.  With over 3000 active and closed landfills and tens of thousand of additional private dumps that currently or will eventually present an ecological crisis for a local community.  Below is a map showing the extent of the problem as it is know to exist today.

 
Recycling
Recycling has a role to play in our waste solution, but what most people do not see is how little waste is recycled and the effect that this illusion has on how much waste we produce.  After all, if we recycled everything, why not just produce as much as we want.  The reality is that even a recycled item requires energy to produce and transport.  The best item to use is one that you already own, saving the resources and pollution that would have otherwise resulted.  Below is a chart showing the current averages of recycling for the base constituents of our waste. 
There is a misconception that when you place your items in a recycling bin in the U.S. that those items will be sent to a local facility and turned into a new item, creating a system of regeneration.  In fact, for decades, our inability to profitably manage these materials has lead to the majority being exported to less developed nations, promarily China.  Our recycling programs were a creation of the plastics industry, were never designed to 
After China banned the importing of plastics for recycling the amount of plastic that was landfilled an incinerated exploded as there were not enough buyers of the kind of plastic waste we produced and we have long been deficient in our ability to profitable recycle most plastics domestically, 40 years later.
With new technologies and a rise in the international pressure of developing counties to better manage waste, we are starting to see for the first time, viable solutions for making cost-effective recycling a domestic reality.  But this will represent an enormous challenge as it will require massive capital inventment to create the thousands of facilities that would be required to address these 268 million tons of waste annually for a zero waste solution.
Ocean Plastics Problem
Even if we are able to recycle plastic 100%, plastics themselves still represent many environmental challenges that would require attention.  The damage to the environment from the drilling and fracking aside, plastic will still find its way into our environment, outside of our waste stream, and into natural habitats.  One such alarming case is the rise of the Ocean Plastic threat.  A material that does not degrade and only gets smaller has become a crisis for aquatic life.  Plastic is found in nearly all wild fish, with many marine animals starving with stomachs full of undigestable plastics, making them feel full or unable to eat or digest food.  In fact, this same microplastic is found in nearly every human on the planet.  We consume volumes of plastic but are not yet aware of the prolonged heath effects of these microplastics in our bodies as they increase with no end in sight.

The Good News
With awareness, education, and technological development, we can solve this problem.  Now that the problem is evident we can use that knowledge to direct logical effort to solve the problems we have created and preventing new ones.
The Zero Waste Projects were created with the mission to promote zero waste practices and sustainability within the U.S., end the practice of landfilling, and find the best ways to utilize our resources for a healthier planet.
There is no one solution and even solutions like recycling create complacency that increases waste and pollution.  We must treat our resources as finite and valuable, conserving these resources and through this, our planet.
The Zero Waste Projects
Through a series of projects, we will bring real solutions to our communities to address the reduction of waste to improvements in recycling waste and then reclaiming the resources that cannot be recycled.

 
We intend of starting with three projects that you can support through this campaign.

Business:
Bring to local businesses a simple platform to find and order sustainable products to replace those they already use while supporting "The Zero Waste Project.
Educate business owners on "best practices" for reducing business waste and environmental pollution.
Education:
Youth engagement is a pivotal part of our campaign as grade-schoolers will champion environmental advocacy and resilience in the future.
Teaching ways students can help solve our waste crisis and help achieve circularity by giving students tools and information to learn about Society's role in waste production and Climate Science.
Awareness:
Social Media outlets allow us to spread our information across different mediums and platforms to allow us to engage and connect to a plentiful and diverse audience.
With the common goal of achieving Zero Waste through a variety of games, challenges, and informative anecdotes.

Contribute to our campaign
Help us to bring zero waste solutions, education and awareness to our comunities with your docation.  You can choose just one project, all three or an overall Super Supporter and donate to the mission as a whole.  Join our network and newsletter to follow the progress and see how your contribution is making a difference in our communities and bringing us closer to the sustainable future we desere for which you will be proud to pass on to our future generations.
If you support Zero Waste how else can you contribute?

For anyone simply unable to contribute financially, there are things that you can do to help us with our mission and you can play an important role:

Add our campaign to your social media feeds so that like-minded people can find our message and support our cause.
Tell your friends personally and ask them to check out our website.
Reduce your waste personally and encourage others to do the same.

Add us to your social media platforms
                         
And that's all there is to it.

story:
This is a story about humanity and the earth, about creation and gratitude, and about expanding consciousness through art. 

My name is Orly Faya and I paint people into the world. I have been a travelling artist for 12 years, have a background in anthropology and a passion for creation and collaboration. This campaign is to support me launch The Gaia Project through my debut art exhibition on May 9th at Burrinja Cultural Centre Upwey Victoria. The exhibtion will be open to the public from May 8 - June 7 and will include a collaborative event called "Creation's Calling" that will be held on May 22nd, a night to celebrate our relationship with the earth through the creative expressions of music, poetry, story telling and of course, my favourite combination of paint, nature, human form, realtime, and photography.
My intention is to help humanity re-member ourselves as the children of the earth, to reestablish balance, harmony and gratitude so that we may elevate consciousness and live sustainable lives with the resources of our planet. In addition, I intend that the sales of my artwork will not only elevate consciousness but will also enable me to expand my projects to supporting community initiatives that aid sustainable environmental projects around the world. 

These artworks also form part of a bigger initiative called The Gaia Project , a co_op for establishing creative collaborations that aim to impact social and environmental changes, and ultimately create a more sustainable way of living in the world.

Support and Exchange 

Your support helps me launch The Gaia Project via two events that span over my four week debut exhibition in Burrinja Cultural Centre, in Upwey Victoria. These events are:

 1) May 9th - The opening of the Exhibition which will include a live painting installation and a talk about my journey painting people into the world, canapés and wine. 

2) "Creation's Calling - Collaborating for sustainability" - A collaborative creative event with music, poetry, food and drinks to support the work of uniting humanity with the earth. 

So where is the money going?

Printing and framing artworks!

Transporting artworks between Sydney and Melbourne

Food and drinks at both events

Invitations, marketing, written articles for papers and magazines about The Gaia Project, what why and how we are creating movement

Equipment:  digital camera, SLR lens, tripod, computer

All donations are welcome and all will be rewarded with gifts. The amounts are allocated with particular rewards, artworks in all forms. Everything is appreciated and everything makes a difference!

The Impact

Although I am the vessel for these creations, the intention is vast and extends to the whole world. Our children and our children's children may grow up in a world that has forgotten where we came from, riddled with trash, pollution and disrespect.. or we can work towards reuniting humanity with the earth, honouring the sacred feminine and caring for our mother planet so that we may drink clean water and live sustainably, and enjoy the fruits of the garden of eden that we have been blessed to be born into.

This is my calling in life: to create projects that inspire and make a difference in the world. For me, there is no bigger reason to be alive other than to work towards a conscious existence, create awareness through art and inspire my fellow humans to imbue their lives with joy, creativity and service.  

Risks & Challenges

Despite the fact that each piece of art is an expedition in of itself, full of challenges, difficulties, intensity and pain, the truth is that there is nothing other than funds that can get in the way of these goals. I am committed and compelled to continue making art that inspires the people of the world. I am completely driven to be involved in collaborative creative projects that elevate consciousness. 

Through my work of blending people into the landscapes of the world, I hone my personal relations, further my sense of compassion, become more patient, and realise the importance of respect in order to be harmonious with the energies in the world. 

Knowing that I have support from the people who are watching these creations emerge gives me the sustenance to continue and become stronger in my visions. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Like my page on Facebook "Fayotopia Artistry" 
  • Share my artworks from my page on Facebook 
  • Come to my exhibition!
  • Share this campaign!
  • Think about the issues
  • Ask yourself how you can contribute to our story on earth and take action. 
  • Practise Gratitude

Thank you for your support. Blessings x

story:
My name is Charles Collie, I am a retired airline employee and now involved in permaculture and committed to natural and eco-living. I own beach-side land and my dream is to preserve it as eco camping grounds for the enjoyment of campers, back-packers and families;... together you and I can make this dream a reality.    

We are seeking funding for the devopment of this beach side camping and hiking facilities whereby you can become a part of it. You would earn free stays and a 25% discounted passport to be used, anytime you visit the camp. Our home camp is located beach side and will come with, His and Hers shower/restrooms, camping equipment (if needed)... a convenient store, camp ranger, cooking and food facilities and fun planned events for the pleasure and benefit for campres.. Our projected date for opening is Aug, 2015.

By supporting this project you will enjoy and  provide the opportunity to share and spread the educational value of eco living for children and adults alike; it offers first hand participation in exploring an untaped island and bring awareness to the beauty of raw nature. The freedom to explore at one’s own pace help relieve the stress of city life; the benefit is a renewed person.

 

South Andros is serene, all natural and surrounded by miles of quiet white sandy beaches with turquoise tides flowing to and from shore. The camp ground is adjoined by miles of interior lands that include caves, lakes, blue holes, bird sanctuaries and ponds. This natural wonder is ready to be explored and enjoyed. When I am there, every day is a "brand new" experience of an exciting adventure, swimming, fishing, sailing, hiking, bird watching, snorkeling, and if you want, also relaxing. The Island Andros, Bahamas...is quiet lovely and a most peaceful place to be.

 scuba diving,

story:
We will use the funds to launch Plant Its educational workshops. We will provide each student with resources to take action today and each student will leave the sustainability workshop informed and equipped. All of our workshop products are hand crafted using 100% post-instrustrial recycled materials in St. Louis, MO. Here are just a few of the hands on lessons the students will learn: Reduce Waste, Reduce Chemicals, Reuse- the art of Upcycling & Restore the Earth.

Funds generated above our goal will increase workshop quantity and allow us to hold workshops in larger venues so we can have a broader impact. We understand not everyone can donate so please SHARE!

story:
As an animal enthusiast and an active participant in animal rehabilitation and environmental conservation, I am fulfilling my dream of going to work with Chimpanzees and many other endangered animals in the forests, plains and savannah regions of Africa.
But I cannot do this alone; I need your help to raise awareness and funds. With the money donated, I will buy a portable, foldable Solar Panel and Battery Pack which should give me free unlimited energy supply throughout my year of travelling. Most places where I will be working are isolated, far from power lines, and only in rare cases do volunteer centers have their own solar panel to charge batteries, flashlights and some important electrical devices. This device will make me independent no matter where I go.


Not only will I be able to charge a DSLR, a GoPro, laptop, batteries and flashlights, but I can also provide free electricity to the centers during my stay. My adventure will begin the first week of July, when I will head to Sanaga Yong Rescue Center in the forests of Cameroon, about 3 hours away from a small town called Bertoua. I will stay there for 6 months, trying to learn all there is to know about our closest relative - the Chimpanzee. The Center has over 70 Chimps all which have been rescued out of dangerous areas and poor living conditions due to habitat loss and poaching. 

After this I will head to Kenya, where I hope to work at a school for orphans, a seaturtle rescue station and a national park. Further plans include travelling through Ruanda and Burundi until reaching Tanzania and Zambia! I have applied to many wildlife centers and national parks there which focus on special animal care and as soon as I am accepted, I will post here! 

While traveling this year I plan to make a weekly video diary of my experiences, mainly my impression of the volunteer centers, the animals in the centers (due to special restrictions of some centers, I won't be able to show everything), educational and informative footage considering volunteer work and of course some of Africa's most fascinating wildlife and beautiful landscapes which I will encounter during my travels! Also, I will be taking requests and hope to interact with sponsors allowing you to be part of this amazing opportunity.

In sharing my goals with you, I invite you to donate and not only share my journey and help me achieve my dream, but be inspired to do the same. 

If you choose not to support me, please think about donating or even volunteering at one of the many wildlife and humanitarian organisations around the world!

And since I am always getting asked, how to find one of these many institutions,
here are some website, which should give you that information:

http://www.wicovo.com/
http://www.vaops.com/africa/default.aspx

Here are some centers where I have worked before and where I will be working:

http://www.arcasguatemala.com/
http://www.wfft.org/
http://www.ida-africa.org/


Deutsche Version

Als wahrer Tierfreund und aktiver Helfer sowohl in Tier-Auffangzentren, als auch bei Umweltschutz-Programmen werde ich nun endlich meinen Traum realisieren, mit Schimpansen und vielen anderen gefährdeten Tieren in den Wäldern, den Steppen und in der Savanne Afrikas zu arbeiten und deren Verhalten erforschen.

Diesen Traum kann ich jedoch nicht ganz alleine erfüllen, denn ich brauche Eure Hilfe sowohl zur Bewusstseinsbildung, als auch für die Finanzierung des Projektes. Mit dem gespendeten Geld würde/werde ich mir eine tragbare, faltbare Solarpanele sowie einen Akku finanzieren können, der mir freie, unlimitierte Energieversorgung meine ganze Reise hindurch ermöglichen wird. Die meisten Plätze, an denen ich arbeiten werde, sind isoliert und von jeglicher Energieversorgung abgeschirmt und nur in den seltensten Fällen gibt es in Zentren der Freiwilligenarbeit die Möglichkeit, Batterien, Taschenlampen und andere unablässliche elektrische Geräte aufzuladen. Diese Solarpanele macht mich unabhängig, wohin mich mein Weg auch führen wird. 

Es wird mir somit nicht nur möglich sein, eine DSLR, eine GoPro, Laptop, Batterien und Taschenlampen aufzuladen, es bietet mir außerdem die Möglichkeit, freie Elektrizität für die Center, in denen ich arbeiten werde, zur Verfügung zu stellen. Mein Abenteuer wird in der ersten Juliwoche beginnen, in der meine erste Etappe das Sanaga Yong Rescue Center in den Wäldern Cameroons sein wird, das sich ungefähr drei Stunden entfernt von einer kleinen Stadt namens Bertoua befindet. Dort werde ich sechs Monate verbringen und alles Erdenkliche über unsere nächsten Verwandten – den Schimpansen - zu lernen versuchen. Das Center an sich beherbergt über 70 Schimpansen, die allesamt aus gefährlichen Gebieten und Teilen des Landes gerettet wurden. Die Gründe dafür sind schlechte Lebensbedingungen aufgrund des Verlustes von Lebensraum und Wilderei.  

Nach dieser Station werde ich weiter nach Kenia reisen, wo ich hoffe, in einer Schule für Waisen, einer Auffangstation für Seeschildkröten und einem Nationalpark arbeiten zu dürfen. Weitere Destinationen stellen Ruanda und Burundi dar, bis ich in Tanzania und Zambia angekommen bin! Ich habe mich bei etlichen „Wildlife-Center“ und Nationalparks beworben, die sich jeweils auf eine spezielle Pflege der dort lebenden Tiere spezialisieren und so bald ich dort aufgenommen bin, werde ich hier laufend Einträge posten.


Während meiner Reisen in diesem Jahr plane ich, ein wöchentliches Video-Tagebuch meiner Erfahrungen zu führen – hauptsächlich von meinen Eindrücken im Auffangzentrum, von den dort lebenden Tieren (aufgrund spezieller Beschränkungen einiger Center wird es mir jedoch nicht möglich sein, alles genau zu dokumentieren), Filmmaterial betreffend Ausbildung und anderen Informationen der Freiwilligenarbeit und selbstverständlich von Afrikas faszinierender Wildnis und der wunderschönen Landschaften, die ich dort während meiner Reisen antreffen werde! Außerdem werde ich persönliche Anfragen beantworten und hoffe, mit den Sponsoren interagieren zu dürfen, um euch die Möglichkeit zu geben, ebenfalls Teil dieser wunderbaren Gelegenheit zu sein.

Indem ich meine Ziele mit euch teile, lade ich euch ein, meine Reise nicht nur zu teilen, sondern auch finanziell zu unterstützen, um mir dabei zu helfen, meinen Traum realisieren zu können und vor allem selbst inspiriert zu sein. 

Wenn ihr euch gegen eine Unterstützung entscheidet, bitte ich euch, es in Betracht zu ziehen, zu spenden oder sogar selbst uneigennützig in einer der vielen Tierschutzorganisationen und Organisationen zur humanitären Hilfe auf der ganzen Welt, tätig  zu sein!

Aufgrund dessen, immer wieder gefragt zu werden, wie ich zu diesen breitgefächerten Institutionen komme, könnt ihr diese in den folgenden Webseiten einsehen, worauf ihr weitere Informationen dazu finden könnt. 

http://www.wicovo.com/
http://www.vaops.com/africa/default.aspx

Und hier noch die Websiten der Center in denen ich schon Zeit verbracht habe, bzw die ich in naher Zukunft besuchen werde!

http://www.arcasguatemala.com/
http://www.wfft.org/
http://www.ida-africa.org/

While traveling this year I plan to make a weekly video diary
of my experiences, mainly my impression of the volunteer centers, the animals in the centers (due to special restrictions of some centers, I won't be able to show everything), educational and informative footage considering volunteer work and of course some of Africa's most fascinating wildlife and beautiful landscapes which I will encounter during my travels!
Also, I will be taking requests and hope to interact with sponsors allowing you to be part of this amazing opportunity.

In sharing my goals with you, I invite you to donate and not only share my journey and help me achieve my dream, but be inspired to do the same. 

If you choose not to support me, please think about donating or even volunteering at one of the many wildlife and humanitarian organisations around the world!

And since I am always getting asked, how to find one of these many institutions,here are some website, which should give you that information:

http://www.wicovo.com/http://www.vaops.com/africa/default.aspx



Here are some centers where I have worked before and where I will be working:http://www.arcasguatemala.com/http://www.wfft.org/http://www.ida-africa.org/


Deutsche Version


Als wahrer Tierfreund und
aktiver Helfer sowohl in Tier-Auffangzentren, als auch bei
Umweltschutz-Programmen werde ich nun endlich meinen Traum realisieren, mit
Schimpansen und vielen anderen gefährdeten Tieren in den Wäldern, den Steppen
und in der Savanne Afrikas zu arbeiten und deren Verhalten erforschen.
Diesen Traum kann ich
jedoch nicht ganz alleine erfüllen, denn ich brauche Eure Hilfe sowohl zur
Bewusstseinsbildung, als auch für die Finanzierung des Projektes. Mit dem
gespendeten Geld würde/werde ich mir eine tragbare, faltbare Solarpanele sowie einen
Akku finanzieren können, der mir freie, unlimitierte Energieversorgung meine
ganze Reise hindurch ermöglichen wird. Die meisten Plätze, an denen ich
arbeiten werde, sind isoliert und von jeglicher Energieversorgung abgeschirmt
und nur in den seltensten Fällen gibt es in Zentren der Freiwilligenarbeit die
Möglichkeit, Batterien, Taschenlampen und andere unablässliche elektrische
Geräte aufzuladen. Diese Solarpanele macht mich unabhängig, wohin mich mein Weg auch führen wird. 
Es wird mir somit nicht
nur möglich sein, eine DSLR, eine GoPro, Laptop, Batterien und Taschenlampen
aufzuladen, es bietet mir außerdem die Möglichkeit, freie Elektrizität für die
Center, in denen ich arbeiten werde, zur Verfügung zu stellen. Mein Abenteuer
wird in der ersten Juliwoche beginnen, in der meine erste Etappe das Sanaga
Yong Rescue Center in den Wäldern Cameroons sein wird, das sich ungefähr drei
Stunden entfernt von einer kleinen Stadt namens Bertoua befindet. Dort werde
ich sechs Monate verbringen und alles Erdenkliche über unsere nächsten
Verwandten – den Schimpansen - zu lernen versuchen. Das Center an sich
beherbergt über 70 Schimpansen, die allesamt aus gefährlichen Gebieten und
Teilen des Landes gerettet wurden. Die Gründe dafür sind schlechte Lebensbedingungen
aufgrund des Verlustes von Lebensraum und Wilderei.  Nach dieser Station werde ich weiter nach Kenia reisen, wo ich hoffe, in
einer Schule für Waisen, einer Auffangstation für Seeschildkröten und einem
Nationalpark arbeiten zu dürfen. Weitere Destinationen stellen Ruanda und
Burundi dar, bis ich in Tanzania und Zambia angekommen bin! Ich habe mich bei
etlichen „Wildlife-Center“ und Nationalparks beworben, die sich jeweils auf
eine spezielle Pflege der dort lebenden Tiere spezialisieren und so bald ich
dort aufgenommen bin, werde ich hier laufend Einträge posten.




Während meiner Reisen in
diesem Jahr plane ich, ein wöchentliches Video-Tagebuch meiner Erfahrungen zu
führen – hauptsächlich von meinen Eindrücken im Auffangzentrum, von den dort
lebenden Tieren (aufgrund spezieller Beschränkungen einiger Center wird es mir
jedoch nicht möglich sein, alles genau zu dokumentieren), Filmmaterial betreffend
Ausbildung und anderen Informationen der Freiwilligenarbeit und
selbstverständlich von Afrikas faszinierender Wildnis und der wunderschönen
Landschaften, die ich dort während meiner Reisen antreffen werde! Außerdem
werde ich persönliche Anfragen beantworten und hoffe, mit den Sponsoren
interagieren zu dürfen, um euch die Möglichkeit zu geben, ebenfalls Teil dieser
wunderbaren Gelegenheit zu sein.
Indem ich meine Ziele mit
euch teile, lade ich euch ein, meine Reise nicht nur zu teilen, sondern auch
finanziell zu unterstützen, um mir dabei zu helfen, meinen Traum realisieren zu
können und vor allem selbst inspiriert zu sein. Wenn ihr euch gegen eine Unterstützung entscheidet, bitte ich euch, es
in Betracht zu ziehen, zu spenden oder sogar selbst uneigennützig in einer der
vielen Tierschutzorganisationen und Organisationen zur humanitären Hilfe auf
der ganzen Welt, tätig  zu sein!


Aufgrund dessen, immer
wieder gefragt zu werden, wie ich zu diesen breitgefächerten Institutionen komme,
könnt ihr diese in den folgenden Webseiten einsehen, worauf ihr weitere
Informationen dazu finden könnt. 
http://www.wicovo.com/http://www.vaops.com/africa/default.aspx

Und hier noch die Websiten der Center in denen ich schon Zeit verbracht habe, bzw die ich in naher Zukunft besuchen werde!http://www.arcasguatemala.com/http://www.wfft.org/http://www.ida-africa.org/

story:
The Clean Sea Fuels Story

4 billion people can't recycle. This is a crisis. But why can't these communities recycle? One word: Access. Many countries, cities, and communities in the developing world don't have the money or the political will to invest in recycling infrastructure such as recycling trucks and centralized recycling facilities. Without access to recycling, plastics and oil run into waterways and end up in communities' ground water and the world's oceans. We have created an innovative, scalable, and sustainable solution to give everyone in the world access to recycling. Now we need you're generous support to launch.

We have invented the Micro Recycling Facility ("Mike" for short), that fits on the bed of a truck and recycles plastic and waste engine oil into diesel, kerosene, and gasoline. The Mike uses a process called "pyrolysis" - the same process and technology done at a big expensive recycling facility but we've shrunk it down to make it mobile and decentralized. 



What makes Mike revolutionary is that we are using its unique portability to practice "Compensated Recycling" - meaning paying people to collect and separate recyclable waste. 

In rich countries we all separate our waste for free and pay taxes to have a centralized agency recycle, but in poor countries it lays on the ground, gets burned, or dumped in the ocean.  We want to change this by paying people for their garbage. We can afford to do this because we turn the waste into salable fuels which allow us to buy more machines, go into new communities, and buy more garbage. By paying systematically we effectively plant and cultivate a recycling culture everywhere.


Imagine Cape Coast, a city of 250,000 people in Ghana. There is roughly 10 million tons of plastic and waste engine oil dumped in this city every year because there is little to no recycling. Imagine we deploy three Mike's each with a locally trained team of technicians. Word gets out in the neighborhoods where Mike's are stationed that our teams are paying for $1.50 per 10 KG of recyclable waste. The next day the plastic waste pours in: plastic bottles, old fishing net, plastic bags, bottle caps, buoys, etc. Fishermen start fishing for waste plastic as well as for fish, groups of people are combing the beach, and still others are going from mechanic to mechanic retrieving waste engine oil and transmission oil.  The community begins to recycle, the beach and water are cleaner, and the community's economy improves. All of sudden everyone wants to recycle and are looking for new things to clean up - computer parts, lead batteries, old car engine blocks. It's everyone's part-time job -flexible hours, no boss….We've transformed waste into income. People make money and their world gets a lot cleaner.

From day one, our teams will be:

1. Cleaning up the environment and  recycling 
2. Making communities money through Compensated Recycling and hiring teammates
3. Creating a valuable cleaner DIY diesel, kerosene, and gasoline instead of polluting the waterways with plastic garbage and dumped engine oil.
Making fuel from waste plastic leaves a much smaller eco footprint than fuel from crude oil.  It is cleaner with far less sulphur and other contaminants, and it can provide and income for poor communitIes.  It is better to make fuel by cleaning up the ocean rather than polluting it!

By The Numbers

Our technology makes economic, social, and environmental sense. 

With our supporter's help one Micro Portable Recycler will process 1000kg of waste plastic or 2,000 liters of waste oil per day. About 85% of that becomes useable fuel (gasoline, kerosene, and diesel). A single "Mike"  running 5 days a week for fifty weeks will process over 250,000kg (130 tons) of waste plastic or 500,000 liters of waste oil a year. Within 5 years we want to have 100 "Mikes" in operation, meaning we can be recycling over 13,000 tons of waste plastic or 50,000.000 liters of waste oil a year.

The economic impacts are as big as the environmental impacts. By paying 1$  or  more per 10kg of plastic or 10 liter of waste engine oil, each Mini is paying $50,000 plus into the local economy through our network of pollution collectors while keeping plastic and oil pollutants out of the ground and water ways. The Mini team sells each liter of diesel we produce for a little less than $1, meaning each Mini also makes about  $200,000 per year which is used to build more Mini's.  Through our profits and your continued support our goal of 100 machines in 5 years is attainable. Can you imagine? 100 "Mikes" recycling where recycling is now impossible.


We need your and your friends' donations and word-of-mouth support to raise $50,000 this spring to accomplish four critical goals. 

1. Double the Mike's output to 2,000kg of waste a day ($25,000)

2. Put the Mike on a trailer and giving it a 12 KW generator so it can be truly mobile  ($10,000)

3. Apply for government licenses to recycle and to sell fuel ($5,000)

3. Buy cargo motorcycles and containers to help communities transport, separate, and store plastic and waste oil to our sites. ($10,000)

LET'S GET THIS GOING.  DONATE NOW!  THANK YOU.


To understand MORE about the technology check out these videos

Pyrolysis: plastic to fuel  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZ6Rv6hERfY

More about our machine  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1HPTpGsR4IM

story:
Short Summary

Operation SPLASH Volunteers have been cleaning the Long Island waterways for 25 years with boats in 6 south shore communities.


This year SPLASH is funding a new baby! The custom built Babylon boat will reach even further east. Be a part of this solution!


In 2014, SPLASH collected more than 198,000 pounds of garbage from the Western Bays along Nassau County. This new boat will mean that we can help protect and restore the Great South Bay,too.
Give your support to keep our bays clean!

What We Need & What You Get

We can break it down for you!

The $20,000 goal will fund a new boat that will be docked on the Nassau/Suffolk border. This boat was launched in July 2015, but the bills are still coming in!

Your generosity and concern could never be fully compensated, but please check out our 'perks' to see how we would like to acknowledge your contributions!


Even if we don't reach our goal, every dollar will go to pay off the fiberglass guy, the non-toxic bottom paint, the folks who installed the engine, oh yeah, the engine!, the windows, steering wheel, zincs, batteries, pumps, steering cables...need we go on?

The Impact

On Long Island, street trash gets washed directly down the storm drains on your streets. This trash is carried untreated, directly into the bays. Let's add garbage cans and recycling bins without lids, construction debris from SANDY rebuilds and mix in some strong winds. What do ya got? 
A whole lot of garbage that fish think is food.
 


No municipality funds the removal of the trash once it hits the water.

Operation SPLASH does!

Save the lives of marine creatures from the comfort of your computer screen by increasing our fleet by one more boat this year! Be someone who makes this happen! 

From one small Garvey in 1990 to a fleet of seven in 2015, SPLASH chapters have developed all the way from Queens to the Suffolk border. This season, the new boat will push our area of service into the Great South Bay!

  • In addition to making us yell, 'Yippe-yi-yo-yi-yay-Yabadaba-doo!", your generous gift will go directly to :

    • Design and building costs of the hull, especially designed for volunteers to jump on and off into the marshes with their nets, buckets and garbage pickers
    • One brand new -115 Evinrude outboard motor
    • Important safety equipment for the 100+ volunteers who will go trash fishing each season, saving the creatures in our ecosystem from sickness and death.
Risks & Challenges

SPLASH  has already received a free dock space and dumpster from Marine Max in Lindenhurst, lots of volunteer folks raising their hands to crew the trash hunting trips, qualified boat handlers to captain the boat....

.....now we just need you to help us pay off the boat building costs.

We are hoping, dreaming that our ridiculously frugal volunteer leaders will relax when they see the dollars streaming in. With our careful planning, we will just scrape by in 2015 fueling all the boats this season, replacing worn out life vests, repairing nets and restocking gloves. Oh, and the hundreds of black trash bags we fill up each month. 

So, we hope your help will keep us out on the water, doing that thing we do best. Collecting Garbage!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remind friends to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Every new friend of SPLASH is a friend to the creatures of the bays.

Your voice counts. Help improve our world for future generations.



*Thank you to Ian Somerhalder for the quote used in the video.

story:
Click on the Bee above to see our video

"BeeSafe® Mission 50" is about converting 50% of all
lawn care to Organics by the year 2025.
Every year millions of pounds of harmful synthetic chemical fertilizers and toxic pesticides are used on lawns all across our country.

Do you care about protecting kids from cancer and learning disabilities?
Do you care about dogs getting lymphoma and bladder cancer?
Do you care about preventing water pollution and damage to ecosystems?
Do you care about the collapse of Bee colonies?

Then please help us! Even a $5 or $10 contribution will help get the word out that there is a safer and natural way to have a beautiful lawn. Please join the BeeSafe® Mission 50 movement.

Why aren't more people concerned?  Good Question!

People go to Whole Foods, or buy "green" products, but most people just aren't aware of the hazards from lawn chemicals.

 Pesticides and Kids

What do your kids do outside in the summer?  Play ball?  Throw a Frisbee?  Maybe they run through the sprinkler? 

What are they doing when they are at a friends house or the local ball field?

Playing on the grass!

How could you have known that by doing these simple things on a "chemical" lawn they might have quadrupled their risk of soft-tissue sarcoma and leukemia?  (Independent study of Denver children under that age of 15 published by Am. J. Public Health 1995).

Did you know that the American Academy of Pediatrics cited that there is a link between exposure to lawn chemicals and pediatric cancers and behavioral problems? 

You probably didn't  and that's what our Mission is all about, because you need to know!!!


Pesticides and Pets

My dog loves to catch golf balls as you hit them.  She'll run through the grass sniffing and searching for her trophy over and over again.  My friend has a dog  that actually likes to eat the grass!  I'll bet you or somebody you know has a pet that loves to be outside playing in the grass too.

Did you know that research done by Purdue University and the University of North Carolina shows that weed control chemicals can be found in the urine of three of every four dogs who's homes use synthetic chemical lawn care?

Maybe that's why the University of Pennsylvania found that exposure to lawn chemicals "significantly increases" your dogs risk of bladder cancer.

Even wild birds commonly die from pesticide poisoning.  According to the National Audubon Society, millions die each year.

The biggest question here is why do animal lovers continue to expose their pets to lawn chemicals.    Why do they?

The fact is that they just aren't aware and that's what the Mission is all about.


Fertilizers and Water Pollution

You see it happen every summer.  A local beach is closed because of an "Algae Bloom."  When fertilizers run off from lawns they end up in the water.   The algae bloom caused by this run off depletes the water of oxygen, creates toxic bacteria and can destroy the local ecosystem.

Did you know that last year, over 400,000 people in Toledo, Ohio went days without drinking water, because their water was made toxic by algae blooms?

Did you know that there is a "dead zone" in the Gulf of Mexico at the mouth of the Mississippi River?  It's caused by runoff of nitrogen and phosphorous from fertilizers. BeeSafe® is phosphorous-free and has natural sources of nitrogen that don't run-off.

Did you know that certain studies of major rivers and streams have documented that 100 percent of all surface water samples contained one or more pesticides at detectable levels?  Or that 96 percent of all fish analyzed by the US Geological Survey contained residues of one or more pesticides at detectable levels?

You probably didn't and this is what the Mission is all about!


Pesticides and Pollinators

The next time you are at the supermarket take a good look at the produce department.  Try to fathom that 70% of all fruits and vegetables are grown thanks to the fact that the plants are pollinated by bees.  Now try to fathom them gone.  Did you know that the most commonly used class of insecticides (neonicotinoids) in the U.S. has been linked to the acute die off of bees and other pollinators.

Colony Collapse Disorder is when worker bees become disoriented and don't return to their colony.  Without the worker bees, the Queen dies and the colony is destroyed.

Researchers of this environmental disaster estimate that nearly one-third of all honey bee colonies in the country have vanished.

Did you know that the use of common pesticides affects your food supply? 

If only more people were aware....

This is what the Mission hopes to accomplish.


                                  


Who is BeeSafe®?

BeeSafe® Organic Lawn Care is building a network of like-minded lawn and landscape professionals that provide their customers with wonderful lawns using organic inputs instead of traditional pesticides and chemicals.  You could say a BeeSafe® Program is a healthy alternative to a typical chemical infused lawn care program.

We provide thick, healthy, weed-resistant lawns by focusing on the soil.  While it's somewhat complicated, our proprietary technology helps local lawn and landscape services transition to an organic lawn with ease. 

BeeSafe® has created a proprietary,  cutting edge, scientifically elite line of products that are key to the success of a true organic lawn.  We aren't talking about bags of compost or fertilizer made from chicken manure here.  Other organics either don't work well, or are way too expensive. BeeSafe® has solved this problem.  This isn't an ordinary, or typical lawn care program, but products that we feel can change the world.  Visit our website at www.beesafelawns.com to learn more.

Right now we we work with more than 80 lawn services across the country to help their customers go organic.  It's going AWESOME!! 

So whats the hard part you ask?

Reaching more people!!!!! 

That's what  "BeeSafe® Mission 50" is all about!

We're all in this together and here's why we are asking for your help.
Our plan revolves around three specific phases. 

Consumer Education and Awareness
 "BeeSafe Mission 50" is all about awareness.  With the funds we raise we will strive to make more people aware of the Organic alternative to synthetic chemical fertilizers and pesticides.  We want to enlighten home owners about a better choice for their own lawns. We also want to reach out to facility managers who are responsible for lawns at universities, towns, schools, athletic fields, golf courses, hospitals, etc.

We will increase our web presence and also create a series of "How To" videos showing consumers how to create a toxic free environment for their home and family.

Community Outreach
There is a growing movement of activists and advocates all across the country who are working hard to be heard.  With the funds we raise we will create a variety of tools to help them succeed.

We will work to train hundreds of lawn and landscape companies around the country how to make more environmentally friendly choices when running their  businesses.  Help us get their attention!

Research and Development
Lastly, we need to invest funds into researching and developing more and better products.  We've had great success so far, but constantly improving our products and programs is an absolute requirement to make "BeeSafe Mission 50" a success.

With "BeeSafe® Mission 50" your support can make a huge difference in the health of your children and the state of our environment.  Please help us today.

Thank you for your support.

Tom Kelly

BeeSafe® Organic Lawn Care

Natural Technologies Inc., Auburn, NH 03032

603-587-0384

An Actual "BeeSafe® Lawn" this Spring!

Even a $5 or $10 contribution will help get the word out that there is a safer and natural way to have a beautiful lawn. Please join the BeeSafe® Mission 50 movement.Why aren't more people concerned?  Good Question!People go to Whole Foods, or buy "green" products, but most people just aren't aware of the hazards from lawn chemicals.  Pesticides and Kids


What do your kids do outside in the summer?  Play ball?  Throw a Frisbee?  Maybe they run through the sprinkler?  What are they doing when they are at a friends house or the local ball field? Playing on the grass!How could you have known that by doing these simple things on a "chemical" lawn they might have quadrupled their risk of soft-tissue sarcoma and leukemia?  (Independent study of Denver children under that age of 15 published by Am. J. Public Health 1995).Did you know that the American Academy of Pediatrics cited that there is a link between exposure to lawn chemicals and pediatric cancers and behavioral problems?  
You probably didn't  and that's what our Mission is all about, because you need to know!!!
Pesticides and Pets 
My dog loves to catch golf balls as you hit them.  She'll run through the grass sniffing and searching for her trophy over and over again.  My friend has a dog  that actually likes to eat the grass!  I'll bet you or somebody you know has a pet that loves to be outside playing in the grass too.Did you know that research done by Purdue University and the University of North Carolina shows that weed control chemicals can be found in the urine of three of every four dogs who's homes use synthetic chemical lawn care?Maybe that's why the University of Pennsylvania found that exposure to lawn chemicals "significantly increases" your dogs risk of bladder cancer. 
Even wild birds commonly die from pesticide poisoning.  According to the National Audubon Society, millions die each year.The biggest question here is why do animal lovers continue to expose their pets to lawn chemicals.    Why do they?The fact is that they just aren't aware and that's what the Mission is all about.
Fertilizers and Water Pollution
You see it happen every summer.  A local beach is closed because of an "Algae Bloom."  When fertilizers run off from lawns they end up in the water.   The algae bloom caused by this run off depletes the water of oxygen, creates toxic bacteria and can destroy the local ecosystem. Did you know that last year, over 400,000 people in Toledo, Ohio went days without drinking water, because their water was made toxic by algae blooms?Did you know that there is a "dead zone" in the Gulf of Mexico at the mouth of the Mississippi River?  It's caused by runoff of nitrogen and phosphorous from fertilizers. BeeSafe® is phosphorous-free and has natural sources of nitrogen that don't run-off.
Did you know that certain studies of major rivers and streams have documented that 100 percent
            of all surface water samples contained one or more pesticides at
            detectable levels?  Or that 96 percent of all fish analyzed by the US Geological Survey contained residues of one or more pesticides
            at detectable levels?You probably didn't and this is what the Mission is all about!Pesticides and PollinatorsThe next time you are at the supermarket take a good look at the produce department.  Try to fathom that 70% of all fruits and vegetables are grown thanks to the fact that the plants are pollinated by bees.  Now try to fathom them gone.  Did you know that the most commonly used class of insecticides (neonicotinoids) in the U.S. has been linked to the acute die off of bees and other pollinators.Colony Collapse Disorder is when worker bees become disoriented and don't return to their colony.  Without the worker bees, the Queen dies and the colony is destroyed.
 Researchers of this environmental disaster estimate that nearly one-third of all honey bee colonies in the country have vanished.Did you know that the use of common pesticides affects your food supply?  
If only more people were aware....This is what the Mission hopes to accomplish.

                                   
Who is BeeSafe®?BeeSafe® Organic Lawn Care is 
building a network of like-minded lawn and landscape professionals that 
provide their customers with wonderful lawns using organic inputs 
instead of traditional pesticides and chemicals.  You could say a 
BeeSafe® Program is a healthy alternative to a typical chemical infused 
lawn care program.We provide thick, healthy, weed-resistant lawns
 by focusing on the soil.  While it's somewhat complicated, our 
proprietary technology helps local lawn and landscape services 
transition to an organic lawn with ease.  BeeSafe® has 
created a proprietary,  cutting edge, scientifically elite line of 
products that are key to the success of a true organic lawn.  We aren't 
talking about bags of compost or fertilizer made from chicken manure 
here.  Other organics either don't work well, or are way too expensive. 
BeeSafe® has solved this problem.  This isn't an ordinary, or typical 
lawn care program, but products that we feel can change the world.  
Visit our website at www.beesafelawns.com to learn more.Right now we we work with more than 80 lawn services across the 
country to help their customers go organic.  It's going AWESOME!!  So whats the hard part you ask?  Reaching more people!!!!!  That's what  "BeeSafe® Mission 50" is all about!We're all in this together and here's why we are asking for your help.Our plan revolves around three specific phases.  Consumer Education and Awareness "BeeSafe Mission 50" is all about awareness.  With the funds we raise we will strive to make more people aware of the Organic alternative to synthetic chemical fertilizers and pesticides.  We want to enlighten home owners about a better choice for their own lawns. We also want to reach out to facility managers who are responsible for lawns at universities, towns, schools, athletic fields, golf courses, hospitals, etc.We will increase our web presence and also create a series of "How To" videos showing consumers how to create a toxic free environment for their home and family.Community Outreach There is a growing movement of activists and advocates all across the country who are working hard to be heard.  With the funds we raise we will create a variety of tools to help them succeed.We will work to train hundreds of lawn and landscape companies around the country how to make more environmentally friendly choices when running their  businesses.  Help us get their attention!Research and DevelopmentLastly, we need to invest funds into researching and developing more and better products.  We've had great success so far, but constantly improving our products and programs is an absolute requirement to make "BeeSafe Mission 50" a success.With "BeeSafe® Mission 50" your support can make a huge difference in the health of your children and the state of our environment.  Please help us today.Thank you for your support.

Tom KellyBeeSafe® Organic Lawn Care Natural Technologies Inc., Auburn, NH 03032603-587-0384
An Actual "BeeSafe® Lawn" this Spring!

story:
IAAS and its Mission

IAAS, International Association of Students in Agriculture and Related Sciences, is a student operated worldwide organization that connects students in the field of agriculture and food science. We connect students to make knowledge exchange possible on a global scale. We create a better understanding of new technologies and approaches, globalised processes and recognize emerging challenges. To achieve our goal the annual World Congress is the most important event, where up to one hundred international students visit local research institutes and companies related to agriculture and food science. Enriched with lectures and discussions with experts, participants receive a uniquely important insight to the world outside our universities. We, IAAS, believe that education and the exchange of experience and knowledge is a key factor in building a better future.

The World Congress

The World Congress is our largest and most important event. In addition to the regular knowledge transfer and networking opportunities, our General Assembly (GA) takes place. The participants will represent over 25 different countries. In 2015 several member countries work together to organise a Europe tour. Starting in the Netherlands, the participants will travel over Belgium to Switzerland to end the journey in Italy. During this journey, our 80 international participants will have the unique opportunity to experience Europe from a scientific, entrepreneurial, but also cultural, political and historical perspective. An introduction to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) reform, a visit of the European parliament in Brussels, tours through the visiting cities, company visits and lead discussions about current topics will all be key components during this international conference. Klick on this link to see the program in detail.

Why we need your support

The most challenging point besides organizing the world congress is financing it. We devoted much effort to pursue our financial objectives. Thanks to our great sponsors, we’re close to reach them. Yet, another 10 per cent of the planned financial support is missing. Your support will further eliminate this gap. Prove your generosity and help us realize this World Congress, we will eternally be thankful for your largesse.

Special case: Companies

If you are a company that considers supporting us, you may want to contact our sponsoring responsible (vppartnership[at]iaasworld.org) for further information about your possibilities of supporting us with interesting offers in return.

Risks and Challenges

Already now, we are convinced that the World Congress is going to take place. But if we won't reach our finance goals, we need to shorten the congress or omit costly activities. This implies the more supportive you are, the more elaborate the program will be and the more you bring our World Congress to fruition.

story:
At GreenAtom, we are currently building a mobile application that allows the user to capture a plant's image and identify that plant in seconds.

PlantSnap is a mobile app that helps you identify plants, flowers and trees. Simply snap a photo of the plant, and PlantSnap tells you what it is!

We spent 3 months proving the concept, and are now ready to develop the application.

Our plant identification app for mobile devices will not only identify over 200,000 types of plants worldwide, but gather data from users that can be used for education, gaming, safety, gardening, landscaping and much more.  We have a partner company with experience creating a similar app for light bulbs, and now all we need is financing to complete the project.

GreenAtom has developed a conceptual application capable of classifying images of leaves. The mobile app user captures an image of a leaf on a white background, and the application displays the most probable species and plenty of relevant scientific information about the plant.

The selected algorithm for this project is shown to be working despite some limitations.  From the programmers:

“We tested the classifier on a limited selection of leaves images. A set of images for each species was divided into training and testing samples. Training sample is used to generate a recognition algorithm for each species and testing sample was passed to the classifier input. Our algorithm is able to detect some species with 100% accuracy. So basically we are feeding new, unknown images to the classifier and it's still able to recognize the species by image. “

Building a full-featured mobile application will require further work.We will have to implement the iOS application itself, API server, classifying server and a web backend.

API server is intended to handle requests from mobile applications. It include all the business logic, species database, user management etc. Classifying server is a stand-alone application with a single responsibility – images processing and classifications.

Making it a stand-alone solution will allow us to scale the service for a larger userbase in the future, and also build new apps for animals and insects. The web backend will allow administrators to manage users' data, species data and tune classification by reviewing new images and adding them to a training samples.

During the research we figured out some limitations: 

•  A lot of species have very similar leaves which makes it difficult to classify them between each other. To solve this issue we plan to group such species together and show the user a list of possible options after recognition. We can also make use of comparing geographical data for given species and current GPS location.

•  Training and classifying images can be a CPU-heavy operation. We will probably have to set up multiple scalable servers

•  Classification quality can be improved in many ways. There are a lot of options to try and we plan to reserve funds for further research

We have already proven the concept of the application, so we know that the technology is there to complete the project. The challenge will be adapting the image recognition platform to recognize different shapes and sizes of the same plants, flowers and trees. But it can and will be done!

story:
Anthea Norman-Taylor wanted to share some of her beautiful land in between Abingdon and Drayton, and enable others to benefit from the nature, the biodiversity and the potential of the land she owns.

Much of it untouched and un-managed for years, our site has grown into a thriving fruit and vegetable organic garden with hens and bees; a perfect learning environment for everyone to enjoy.  

We are open every Wednesday to everyone, sharing in the work of managing the garden and enjoying the produce together.

Our users benefit from our garden in many ways:

  • Learning about growing food, soil health, reducing waste and environmental impact
  • Outdoor exercise
  • Education on healthy eating
  • Access to green spaces
  • A chance to enjoy and learn about nature
  • Social interaction
  • Building community around food

The garden is coordinated by Richard, a local gardener with many years of experience and long term connection to the site, and Rachel, a local edible horticulturalist with experience in community projects and permaculture.

They are supported by the many and varied volunteers who visit the garden on Wednesdays, and many hands contribute to the running of the garden.

We have many funding applications in progress but as yet have not secured funding for our second year and we will have to close at the end of September if this doesn't change.

Help us keep the garden open for all who enjoy it currently and may enjoy it in the future - this is an opportunity to create an outdoor project for the people of Abingdon and Drayton to enjoy.

We currently support 10-15 visitors each Wednesday, with more people popping in, and other groups using the site throughout the months.

Our minimum target raise is £2,000 which will enable us to stay open for the rest of 2017, welcome over 100 people to the garden and secure funding going forward (it costs us £300 per week to keep the garden open, watered, the chickens fed and all our plants, tools and materials included).

We have lots of exciting ways you can support us - both with your time and with your money, and our perks make great presents even if they're not for you!

Even if we don't reach our target, your money will still go towards the perk you bought, and we will continue to work hard on keeping the garden open - every little bit really does help, so if you can, please support us in any way you can.

This is your chance to keep our chickens warm, support our solar hot water system or grab yourself a place on one of our exciting workshops learning new skills and meeting other locals.

 
 
Our visitors to the garden say:
"better than X-Box"  Ethan, a Damascus visitor
"this is a real community" from Danny a Styleacre visitor.
 
Our future plans include a pick your own of unusual crops such as chillies, a herb and flower nursery and educational courses for teenagers and adults, as well as encouraging cross generational attendance at the garden; all of which will enable us to be financially independent. 
 
Community projects like ours which receive no statutory funding are always at risk in the first few years until the project is established and independent.  We are providing support to many who get no support elsewhere, and have seen the positive differences we have made in the last 12 months - we want to continue doing this.
 
Combined, we have lots of community project, gardening and educational experience which will enable us to keep offering learning opportunities to all who visit us and support them in learning all about growing food, nature and related skills.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can still support us without money:

  • Help spread the word about this campaign - send the link to your friends, share it on Facebook
  • Volunteer with us - as well as Wednesday sessions, we have many opportunities for you to support us - from leafleting to social media to driving to helping with plants

story:
Nicky has been volunteering for Manx BirdLife for more than a year now! MBL is a charity based in the Isle of Man and working for the conservation of wild birds.

Nicky is taking part in the 2015 ‘End to End Walk’ where she will have to walk 39 grueling miles (63km) in less than 10 hours. The race has several cut off points along the way, meaning that if they don’t walk fast enough they are taken out of the race and do not get the chance to finish it.

Last year, Dora and Sophie raised close to £900 for the charity but this year MBL got someone with a tracking record of sucess already!  

The race will take place on Sunday the 21st of September starting at the Point of Ayre at 8 am and ending at The Sound, both invaluable areas for wild birds in the Isle of Man.

Follow Nicky's campaigning progress via:

  • Facebook: www.facebook.com/ManxBirdLife
  • Twitter: twitter.com/ManxBirdLife
  • Website: www.manxbirdlife.im   
Please spread the word amongst your friends and family too!


Contributions by cheque can be sent to our Office: 35 New Road, Laxey, Isle of Man, IM4 7BG

We would be immensely grateful for you to give whatever you can to help build on our legacy and achieve more in conservation.


About Manx BirdLife

Having already contributed significantly to bird conservation on the Isle of Man by publishing the Manx Bird Atlas in 2007 and releasing a Manx wildlife documentary in 2014, Manx BirdLife is keen to grow in both achievements and ambition.

How Your Contribution Will Help

  • Upgrading a decayed network server: our struggling old server needs retiering. 
  • Raising awareness of conservation issues affecting bird populations on the Isle of Man via social and traditional media channels. 
  • Equip our invaluable database with updated tools 

Our Aims 
  • Providing an oasis for wildlife: Manx BirdLife is in the process of creating a nature reserve at the Point of Ayre in partnership with a gravel extraction company, the Island Aggregates.
  • Increase public engagement and brand awareness: reaching out to more people to show them how special the Isle of Man and its wildlife is. 


Our Current Work

  • Completing two more years worth of research on a Repeat Bird Atlas which is critical in finding out which species are in need of conservation action.
  • Gathering data through the public with a garden birdwatch scheme and bird sightings reports.
  • Maintaining the most comprehensive data set on bird populations in the Isle of Man, an invaluable resource for conservation


Our History

  • Founded in 1998 by Chris Sharpe in order to produce a ‘Bird Atlas’ for the Isle of Man, a comprehensive study of populations of all species, published in 2007. It greatly improved knowledge on and conservation strategy for the island’s birds.
  • Chris’s perseverance led to production of ‘The Isle of Man – A Natural World’ film. As you can see from the trailer at the top of the page, it showcases the spectacular wildlife of the island superbly.
